you really cannot go wrong with any of casting crowns music. mark, the main singer, puts so much work into the music and it is truly filled with biblical truths. from mark reading a few scriptures he is able to make beautiful songs. this band is really talented and i was fortunate enough to see them in concert.
if you like casting crowns, you'll love this album.  if you don't know casting crowns, i still think you'll love this album.

this will probably be an all-time favorite album.  the theme of being in process -- trying to get to the place of steady, mature faith -- but not being there yet is beautifully articulated in several songs.

i have gotten ripped on previously casting crowns reviews because i gave them 4 stars instead of 5...so there is no doubt people will go crazy with this review.  but with that being said, this cd just wasn't very good.  once again casting crowns does what it does best - write songs pointing the finger at the church.  yes, it was a good song with "if we are the body" and "does anybody hear her," but with "what this world needs," it's just gotten old now.  it starts to become annoying when a band harps on one point, especially one that is as generalizing as saying the church isn't doing what it is supposed to.  move on to another topic!!!  this cd also lacks the catchiness of the last 2 albums.  and where the last 2 cd's had a solid 6 or 7 songs on them, this album has 2 at most.  i just couldn't get into any of the songs.  musically, it is average and the lyrics are not up to par.  looking forward to the new david crowder band album, though, which will surely not disappoint.  hope casting crowns pulls it together for its next album.  this one will sell a lot of units, but will not stand the test of time.  it will collect dust on my shelf.

sweet charity was director/choreographer bob fosse's valentine to his then wife, the beloved broadway dancing star gwen verdon.  she had been off the stage since their last collaboration the murder musical comedy hit "redhead" which closed in 1960.  after that she'd had a baby girl nicole, and had been maintaining a low profile.  fosse wanted to get her back on the boards, and he tailored the role of charity hope valentine to her dazzling talents.  ms. verdon was a triple threat, besides being a dancer par excellence, she also possessed a limited but beguiling singing voice and was a fine actress as well.  this was an americanization of a classic 1957 italian film by director federico fellini starring his chaplinesque wife guiletta masina, "the nights of cabiria".  this was a tragicomedy about a little waiflike roman streetwalker, cabiria, who gets trampled on by life, yet despite this and the sordidness of her profession, manages to maintain a guileless hopeful optimism and go on with her life.  to make her character more palatable to american audiences, fosse changed the character to a dance hall hostess.  neil simon, then the red hot broadway playwright wrote the libretto, cy coleman composed the score, his best in my opinion and dorothy fields the witty, clever lyrics.  fosse of course was the director /choreographer, and this contained some of his most innovative work.  it triumphantly opened at the newly refurbished palace theatre on january 29, 1966 and ran for 608 performances.  this is yet another stellar addition to that unqualifiedly marvelous series that began in the mid to late 1990's, the "columbia broadway masterworks" which were expanded editions of some of the greatest broadway musicals of all time with their original casts.  the tone is set by the brassy, resounding overture, edgy and exciting, in the tradition of "gypsy" and "funny girl"; it gets the blood pumping and sets the tone.  the best songs understandably, go to ms. verdon, and she does them full justice.  the showstopper and one that became a musical standard is "if my friends could see me now!"  ms. verdon performed this on the ed sullivan show on television in glorious color, and her gleeful, ebullient virtuosity is a joy to watch if you get the dvd.  listening to the cut on the cd is just as pleasurable.  "i'm a brass band" is charity's joyous declaration of being blissfully in love, very charming, and also was done on the sullivan show by ms. verdon.  my personal favorite however is the raw, pulsating lament "where am i going?" which shows off ms. verdon's talent as a dramatic actress as charity comes to a crossroads in her life and doesn't know what path to take.  this song musically was so challenging, that sometimes gwen verdon would cut it on matinee days, which was a pity.  her comic sense is well displayed in two wry numbers, "you should see yourself", and "charity's soliloquy".  listening to her inimitable voice, gwen verdon's unique star quality shines through.  the listener is able to realize why along with ethel merman and mary martin, ms. verdon was one of the american musical theatres' most treasured female assets in the latter half of the twentieth century.  "big spender" is the other standard that came out of the show, as the dance hall hostesses led by nickie (helen gallagher) and helene (thelma oliver) try to entice potential customers in an aggressive yet deadpan manner.  there is a staccato, latin sounding number for charity, nickie and helene when all three are weary of the dance hall and dream of escape "there's gotta be something better than this", where you can hear and imagine the vigorous dancing that accompanies it.  helen gallagher has a very funny moment where she nails down a ny urban accent "but baby, what can you doo?" misses. gallagher and oliver sparkle in a sardonic, bouncy pop duet "baby dream your dream".  the male lead john mcmartin playing oscar, charity's neurotic boyfriend gets to sing the title number "sweet charity" and has a low keyed ingratiating duet with ms. verdon called "i'm the bravest individual".  finally i don't want to forget the instrumental "the rich man's frug" which always gives me a smile, it is such an on the head parody of 1960's music heard at then trendy discotheques like "arthur" or "the peppermint lounge".  i can imagine the "beautiful people" doing the "frug" and the "watusi"!  the extras are very special, we are transported back to the opening night on january 29, 1966 as radio announcer fred robbins records the curtain calls, with the audience going wild, followed then by interviews at the party at the skylight roof of the waldorf - astoria where he interviews an exuberant ethel merman who sings the praises of gwen verdon, a gratefully articulate helen gallagher for whom this was a broadway comeback and neil simon who touches on his writing inspirations.  lastly, it's gwen verdon's turn, who though gracious, seems somewhat reserved and detached as if her mind was elsewhere.  there is also the first release of "i love to cry at weddings", hardly different from the final cut.  finally composer cy coleman sings a trio of songs, in a pleasant voice much better than stephen sondheim on the "anyone can whistle" cd.  one song "you wanna bet" was reworked with a different tempo and lyrics into the title tune "sweet charity".  the booklet is nicely done with black and white photos, the original liner notes that were on the album, and an interview with cy coleman from the late nineties.  the stereo sound is clear and sharp, and a tip of the hat to the late producer and president at columbia records goddard lieberson who did such an impeccable job preserving these broadway jewels from the glory days of the broadway musical.  forget about the shirley maclaine, debbie allen, and christina applegate recordings, this is the definitive version and at $7.99 it's a real bargain!
the stylistics is one of those soulful groups who always sound great no matter what the occasion.  go get this cd and relax and enjoy.

despite all of the talented people involved in this project , it is not a product that is greater than the sum of it's parts . yngwie spends most the time out of sync with the orchestra . the fact that his work was recorded on a different continent shows . this is not yo yo ma here . it isn't even rick wakeman ( am i showing my age ? ). if you like modern musicians working with an orchestra try nightwish, the moody blues or renaissance . i actually like yngwie's work and have been buying his material since his 1st. rising force album . he is one of the most talented guitar players in the world . his baroque style stands in stark contrast to the blues or jazz based chord structures that most other guitar greats use . it is just disappointing that when yngwie gets his chance to take his material and talent to this level , it fails to impress .

have the original vinyl and later cd release. the cd was stolen in the early 2000s from my car, and the replacement i tracked down was lost in a flood at my office. the third copy i spent a good so months locating, combing through the bins of used cd stores. it was all totally worth it. best boc album ever. also, i didn't see it in other reviews, but ellen foley (meatloaf and night coury) sings backing vocals.  the song "blue oyster cult" is a mind-shattering experience.  enjoy!
a great album from maybe the greatest band on earth (and beyond) a great return to the best form for blue oyster cult!

albert bouchard was blue oyster cult's best songwriting secret. it's a shame that this band's worst infighting and conflict happened during this time.  this is easily the album that many b.o.c. fans including myself, wanted to see them make.  a little hard to fully understand, this album boasts a pletora of soaring guitars with axe heavyweights such as robbie krieger and joe satriani and jack rigg.  i wished that all of us could have heard the long lost demos of this album, originally slated as an albert bouchard solo project.  the lovecraftian quality of the album as well as its front and back cover easily suggests that this group overdosed on horror films a long time ago.

this is boc on beyond their last legs, making their last major label album and heading straight for the over the hill circuit. this album sounds even worse to me today than it did in '89. come on now, we all know a group has  had it when they start re-recording their own songs(usually means they  can't write quality new ones).the reason they give for this is that they  were a part of some great lost conceptualized work that the record label  wouldn't let them do way back when(yeah, yeah,yeah). from what i'm told  this was originally supposed to be an albert bouchard solo album, hence the  million guests guitarists. that brings up another point, with a great  guitarist like roeser, why did you need any of those guys(satriani, aldo  nova, robby krieger[and what exactly did they do anyway])the label probably  made them call it a boc album, or they wouldn't have let it come out.  hardly anyone is even on their right instrument(ie the one they play live).  stick with the original classic records(debut through fire of unknown  origin).

what can i say that hasn't already been expressed by the other reviewers?  this cd "the experience: praise-intimacy-worship-celebration" by gideon band is the absolute best praise cd i've heard since fred hammonds' pages of life. the cd has so many genre's rolled up in blessed annointing, that you can't help but praise god and continually thank him for gideon band. it's hard to pick just one song as my favorite, because they are all amazing.  and the drummer "the animal" is giving up some serious praise on the drums.  i didn't know it was really possible to praise god with an instrument other than piano until i got this cd and heard the drums. this is one you don't want to miss out.  whether you are a reverend or babe in christ, you want this cd, you need this cd!!! many blessings to the gideon band family and continued success! lorna :o)

having studied rand's philosophy prior to watching this movie, i was put off by her uncompromising, unemotional, atheistic ideas. by watching this movie, i was happy to learn that not even the creator of this pseudo-philosophy could abide by its rules. ayn rand is introduced as a cold and calculating philosopher, berating people who do not follow her ideals entirely. but she turns out to be as human as anyone. no john galt, no superman (superwoman?), her very actions revealed the emptiness of objectivism. rand is the best-portrayed character, although the movie would have benefited from more of her background - the only hint of her past is a brief conversation at a wedding reception. there was a lot more to ayn rand than her philosophy and her libido, and the movie failed to show this. breathing onto a nyc store window, she draws a dollar sign and proclaims it her emblem. why is this? what personal experiences led rand to develop this view? the movie leaves these important questions unanswered. the other characters seem one-dimensional, especially the angst-ridden, emotionally fragile narrator. the production of this movie, while okay for a made-for-cable show, leaves much to be desired. perhaps the most revealing scene is when rand is asked, during a lecture, what "love" means to an objectivist. she cannot truly answer this question. this fits with so-called disciples of rand i've encountered: empty souls, a lack of compassion and confusion. rand's so-called philosophy still has a cult following, and this movie may anger them. to those who reject this film's message, i suggest the following adage: "never let a few facts get in the way of the truth."

the brandens have made a career through defamation of charector of a dead woman. they have become rich entirely based on unproven claims as a means to discredit a rational uncompromising philosophy. they propogate a pragmatic view of objectivism that is adored by libertarians, anarchists and any who build their sad philosophies to fit their pathetic life styles. in a world of compromise, some don't; i wouldn't watch this again if they paid me the $22 to take it.

this is the record that introduced the fab four from sweden to me at the age of thirteen years old. i loved it then and still do. i play the record still as the cd is almost impossible to find(brand new i mean)!agnietha's voice really comes through in s.o.s. what a jewel! frida's shines in the fernando. why this group never did a reunion tour is understandable (if you're an abba fan,like me).it's hard to believe that they had hard times that led to the couples' divorce and the group's break up. i saw abba,the movie,and they looked to get along fine. alas,reality sets in,and life goes on. i still remember hearing on the radio that bjorn and agnietha had announced they were divorcing. if i had one wish....well,you'd know what it would be. all abba fans should look for this album on cd,and listen to the sounds of the group that helped to define the '70's.

i own everything done by enya.  the music goes directly to the soul.  the closest visual i can offer is an offshore wave--finally crashing on the beach.  at each point of the waves travel it has a distinct 'personality' or affect on the listener.  i buy all things enya--because she is (with sarah brightman) the standards by which i assess pleasing sensorial experiences. any cd by enya is valuable---as like the metaphor of the deep sea wave finally crashing on the beach---no two are the same.  each is beautiful in and of itself.  love, maureen

if you're a dan hicks fan (how could you not be?) this import cd is worth the few extra bucks it costs. there are a number of things to like about it, but the bottom line is this: you can't live the rest of your life without hearing vinnie's lookin'good (i can play this song a hundred times in a row and never get tired of it!) and crazy cuz he is. it isn't his best cd, but it's all relative. i've loved dan hicks stuff since the early 70's and this is a great addition to his more readily available works.  if you're new to dan hicks, try this and any of his more readily available stuff.  i'd especially recommend where's the money? and check out sid page's violin solo on i scare myself (on the strikin it rich album).  also, original recordings songs like jukie's ball, evening breeze, how can i miss you..., and milk shake mama are beyond fantastic.

having been a glass fan since music in 5 parts and a r. shankar fan for even longer, i eagerly anticipated this collaboration.  individually, both glass and shankar challenged my listening in many directions.  when passages finally arrived, it was a real disappointment. this work challenged only my patience and ability to stay awake.  every two years or so i give it another listen to see if a new perspective emerges.  it doesn't.

if you really want further revelation of what life was like behind the scenes at grey gardens, pick up a copy of lois wright's my life at grey gardens, thirteen months and beyond.  the few audible bits that could be picked up from this poorly recorded and painfully brief offering are just that:  bits. i listened several times, thinking that i must have accidentally missed something.  i was that sure that there had to be more to it than what i'd heard, (or misheard.)  walter newkirk, the annoying and opportunistic interviewer and self-appointed "gentleman caller" to little edie, has ridden this one to the end of the line.  i feel foolish for having listened.

since perry como, bing crosby and all the rest have now passed on. i felt what better for christmas than an osmond! what was i thinking? marie has abandoned her beautiful and heartfelt vocal interpretations for a more r and b aka ghetto vocal style. gone is the marie of class and style and in with the marie of the 20th century with bad vocal arrangements. what are you thinking marie? i don't want to hear another singer imitating another singer who sounds like another whitney or mariah. neither of those girls know how to sing, you used to. i want my ol' marie back, till then i'll be using this cd as a coaster, while i sip hot cocoa while i enjoy your older albums. btw you butchered the christmas standard sliegh ride...thanks alot!

first let me say that i am a long time fan of al, going back to the beginning in the 80's.  so one could say that it would be hard for a person like myself to be truly objective on this subject, because i'm such a huge al fan.  however, the fact that this is al's least commercially successful album is truly a boggle to my mind.  this is a very solid effort from al.  "living with a hernia", a parody of "living in america" by james brown, is just fantastically brilliant and hilarious.  also "addicted to spuds", the parody of "addicted to love" by robert palmer, is very good.  "dog eat dog" which is an al original written and recorded in the style of the talking heads.  also "one of those days", another al original written in his own style is very funny. 10 songs in all on the album which are all entertaining.  sometimes it's just good to lighten up, have a little fun, and laugh some, regardless of your age.  and al truly does know how to entertain, make you think, and make you laugh all at the same time.  if you're an al fan, you probably already have it, if you don't have it, get it.  if you're new to al, this one is as good a place as any to start.  buy it, and enjoy a classic effort from the king of musical parody.

this would be a awesome recording, it even has alternate words to "less than zero" i've never heard anywhere else! however, there is one jackass in the audience who is whooping and yahooing through almost every song, and he's close enough to the mike that he's about as loud as the band. someone really needs to remaster this and get rid of those sounds, but until they do i can't recommend this for anybody. sorry elvis, i love you, but this is a defective product.

people still use holosync? you can literally make your own "holosync" with neuro programmer 3. just go to [...] "holosync" is not a technology, it's just a brand name. the only thing holosync does is lower the binaural beat pitch and you can do that using neuro programmer 3. holosync is a complete rip-off. don't be fooled. i find it amazing that people take offense to this revelation. you tell them that they're getting scammed and they get upset with you. don't be one of "those" person's. educate yourself and be smart.

i prefer guided meditation, insight meditation using breathwork, and monroe's hemisync cd's to meditate with. i really didn't like holosync at all. i gave these cd's a good try, listening to the initial cd's for a good 10 months before i finally gave up on it completely after a year. i really didn't like listening to the sound of water constantly and crystal bowls - which was all one hears on these cd's. i've listened to plenty of subliminal cd's with one type of white noise or another, but none had the effect the holosync cd's had on me. i actually felt depressed after listening to holosync. initially i thought i was clearing out some sort of subconscious material, but i never got to the point where i felt differently, or better, and had to give these up.  you might ask why i listened to them for so long if they made me feel depressed - it was because they were $150 for the initial set - so i wanted to give it my best effort. there are those who can listen to white noise, and those who prefer their own breath - which is great, but i tend toward guided meditation most often.  i've been meditating and doing self hypnosis for over 30 years. i'm certified in medical and dental hypnosis, and like to use both applications for different needs. i record and use my own, as well as having other favorites - silva, bernie siegel, omvana, to name a few. i also use many of the monroe institute products and love them. they help while i'm painting, drawing, or doing most of my learning and creative work.  update: adrienne mentioned the neuroprogrammer software - i had the 3 cd software set. it is very good. there is a learning curve - very doable, and if you enjoy making and using your own programs it can be very fulfilling. there is so much available on frequencies and resonance healing on amazon prime or youtube these days though, if you don't want to learn, you can start there if you'd prefer, also the monroe institute has free downloads available: https://www.monroeinstitute.org/free-audio-downloads

jason reeves is a songwriter who first received critical acclaim as the songwriting partner of colbie caillat.  having co-wrote the songs that appeared on her debut, reeves took the remainder of songs that didn't make it and placed them on his ep `hearts are magnets.'  after receiving further notoriety on his debut, `magnificent adventures of heartache' he earned a deal with warner bros. in 2008.  reeves is a lovelorn soul and his songs are reflective on relationships, breakups and reunions.  when i first heard this album, i thought it sounded like a josh rouse collection recorded around the time of `dressed up like nebraska,' his debut.  reeves' vocals could be a dead ringer for rouse and the subject matter is fairly similar.  while rouse often stays morose and somewhat distant, jason reeves tempers his melancholy streak with slightly upbeat songs.  clearly some girl has broken this guy's heart, but he's moving on.  jason reeves also has a knack for writing decent pop melodies but it seems that the album could have used a better editor, there is a lot of sameness to some of the songs with many being midtempo rockers.  standout track include, "happy accident," "you in a song," "gasoline," and "hearts are magnets."  jason reeves is a songwriter to watch and it will be interesting to see what direction his career takes.
marie osmond's voice is pure and fresh, so reminiscent of karen carpenter. i'd recommend this one for anyone who loves the osmonds.
if you loved the movie and the music this is the perfect cd for you.  if you wish you were back in those days, this cd will help you dream.

i've been using the holosync cd's for 16 days now and am really enjoying them.  i'm not good at meditating, because i have trouble quieting my mind.  with holosync technology, you don't have to -- it works anyway.  these cd's are inspiring me to take the time for meditation, because they're relaxing and beneficial to my often stressed mind.

lettuce is a group of incredibly talented musicians with a deep appreciation for funk music.  and they spread the funk thick and dirty on rage!  my introduction to the band was the live at the blue note disc, so this is the first time i've heard them in the studio.  what i like most about rage! is that the album stands on its own as a solid collection of tunes that'll get your head bobbin' and your booty shakin' to the undeniable groove.  however, if you're familiar with their live show, you'll be well aware that they leave plenty of room on the disc to explore the songs further when they hit the stage.  i can't wait to catch them on tour, and see how they expand and develop these tunes.  when funk is left in the wrong hands, tragedy can occur.  however, when a band like lettuce comes around to carry the mantle of funk's forefathers, you realize that there is still hope for funk in the world.  i can't recommend this disc highly enough...

regardless of your political affiliation, if you love the freedom to debate your views with others and not fear for your life, the story of the struggle our founding fathers went through to bring us this freedom will bring a tear to your eye.  the love and the passion that mike church has for this country, the founding fathers, and her founding documents are refreshing.  this is obviously a labor of love and should be listened to by every freedom-loving american.  maybe we'll start to appreciate how fragile our freedom really is and how close we came to not achieving it.  and, because some people only post things like "did you even read/listen/ect this?" and it's still only a pre-order, i've heard it twice on the radio and will be listening again on july 4th . . . sirius radio (144).

absolutely love these cds.  my 3 year old dances and sings along with them.  what a wonderful way to hide the word in our hearts.

love these! easy to put biblical truth into the hearts and minds of little ones! i play these while the children are playing legos and doing puzzles. i love them, too. easy to memorize the words, and the tunes are pleasant.

i think this is awesome.  children seem to enjoy these short songs and even i've been known to listen to a couple of them on the way to work. i think it's a neat way to expose children to god's word, and i've got to say the tunes are kind of catchy.  i praise god for this ministry and also keith green's music ministry.  "your word i have hidden in my heart, that i might not sin against you." - psalm 119:11

i was ecstatic to see that this second edition was finally made available on cd. for years, their first album was the only evidence that they even existed. let me say right up front, if you're expecting 'albion doo-wah' to be basically the same genre as 'the street giveth...', think again! the band slightly changed personnel after their first offering, and thusly slightly changed their sound. not to say this second course isn't good; quite the contrary. what i would like to see now is someone to step up and digitally remaster and re-release their third and fourth albums (titled 'cat mother' and 'last chance dance'). they were a good band; probably one of the most underrated of all time.

i hate doing this but it has been over a month, waiting on real gone to fix the problem with this cd. the 1 star is for real gone not cat mother, i would give cat mother 10 stars on the album. i pre-ordered it from them got it early. sent numerous emails with no reply. i had to post on their fb page to get a respond. where was quality control on this? why did they keep selling the cd's when they new it was bad? i told them they should have posted on their web site about the problem. now it states not available for order? still no mention of the problem. the problem is track 2 and 9 drop in volume to less than a quarter of the rest of the songs. you have to turn the volume way up to hear the track, and if you are not fast enough turning it back down before the next song it will blow you out of your seat. real gone was on the right track putting out these great lost albums, but where is the customer service? i had been telling all my friends about them. but now i'm on hold with real gone, afraid it might happen again.  ok now i have to eat crow they came through!!  hey real goners--soon after the cat mother "albion doo wah" cd was shipped to our customers and to retail, it was brought to our attention that there was a mastering issue on this cd. track 2, "turkish taffy," and track 9, "albion doo wah," were at a distinctly lower volume than the rest of the  tracks on the album. we listen to a "reference master" for all of our releases, and the reference master for this one sounded perfect (we wouldn't have approved the project for release if it didn't). but somewhere in the process the studio (battery studios, sony's own mastering studio) used to create the master, these two tracks dropped out in volume. battery itself can't explain what happened, this has occurred  perhaps one other time in their long, august history. to their credit, they (and universal, the licensor) have worked with us to speedily supply a new master, and we are now happy to announce that we have a brand new, corrected pressing in house and ready to ship. if you ordered the cd directly from us at [...] we will automatically send you a free replacement of the entire package including disc, booklet, tray card and jewel case. furthermore, even if you ordered from another source than [...] we are willing to send you a replacement disc as well in good faith. please email us at orders@realgonemusic.com any  type of proof of purchase (a scan or picture of the receipt, an email of the receipt or even a picture of your cd is fine-- just get us something) and we will mail you a free copy of the replacement disc only (we will not send a new jewel case, booklet and tray card in these cases). we stand by our label and our releases and we sincerely apologize about  this-- it truly was a fluke, the first time this has happened in our careers of releasing thousands of records.

i purchased this album(and michael w. smith's new hallelujah) in lifeway christian book store in ga in 2009. i almost have don's album-from give thanks to this lastest cd. as a big fan of mr. moen, these are so smooth just like hiding place.  i don't know what music was came from(hillsong and whatever band and artist). but in my opinion, be praised gonna be very good for young generation. and o god of abraham gonna suitable for hillsong music. chorus part is reminding one of their music.  and finally i could compare two different version of mighty to save. as i said before, i bought this cd with smitty's lastest album-live in lakewood church. it is so interesting to compare both !! :)

hmm, where to start with this album?...i've been a propagandhi fan since i first started listening to music when i was 15 and how to clean everything was easily one of my very favorite ablums.  gradually as i grew older and my taste evolved and matured i had stopped listening to them as well as similar sounding types of music.  years later, i think i was drawn to this album because of the artwork when i happened to come across it in the store and decided to try and 'rekindle'.  although it took time, i have started to listen to it more and more and have recently been blown away over and over as i realized what a brilliant album this is.  the musicianship and songwriting is second to none.  the guitar arrangemetns are highly original and technical.  the sound is tight, crisp and extremely well-delivered.  in conclusion, it is a masterpiece, really and unfortunately it will always be doomed to under-appreciation.  purchase and enjoy!

so basically some of the arguements are that prince does diverse stuff here. ok, fine. but there's plenty of ecletic stuff. i believe people are becoming ever more schizoid, and you have all sorts of musical combinations from artists on myspace and elsewhere, people who mix jazz with death metal, reggae with metal, no exaggeration.  but is this inspired? uh... not neccessarily. maybe to those who lack imagination. it's great as a display of instrumental ability, but it's otherwise cold.

i gave up on prince in the early nineties when his music started to suck. reading al the positive reviews here, i thought i give it a try once more. but i find his music the same old uninspired crap it has been for the last 15 years. sure, the man got skills, but his vision has left him long ago. even the mpls sound cd going back old skool is uninspired and kitsch(same drummachine on every track) it's almost like a parody on his 80's material. no, mr prince i have moved on since. time for you to do the same. but the guy is living in a bubble, so no chance.

i wanted to try the new hair soundtrack because i thought that the mix would be superior to the original.  unfortunately, the new hair lacks any conviction and just sounds show-tuney. the male singers sound really corny and most of the female voices have a quality like kristin chenoweth, childish and cutesy.  the original hair was gritty and soulful -- stick with that one.

stumbled on jack savoretti while watching an episode of one tree hill and was floored by the song they featured.  cw is always known for finding amazing new artists for their show,but this one blew many out of the water.  i am so happy with this cd.  i can listen through it in its entirety, enjoying every song.  his voice hitting every emotional indentation and with such honesty, it draws me into a bliss every time.  i also find myself closely listening to every line of the lyric through his crisp and clearness of his voice, and the lyrics do not dissappoint at all. they are so poetic, deep and impacting.  i have to say this is by  far one of my favorite cd's in the last 5 years. i highly recommend this album to all you music lovers out there!

thanks to my young niece and nephews, i was introduced to the animated movie how to train your dragon and enjoyed it as much as they did.  i was pleasantly surprised to find it to be delightfully clever with witty, endearing characters.  the music soundtrack is always such an important element, it can often make or break a movie.  in this case, this excellent musical production has merged with an already-wonderful animated production to create an extraordinary work.  if i had heard the music without ever seeing the movie, i would still have bought the cd because i love the beautiful celtic flavor woven in between energetic, toe-tapping segments and dramatic crescendos that spark the imagination.
this was an overall excellent sound track that complements the movie so well. the music is so good that it can stand alone with out the movie... great quality, shiped fast... love it!

with such a great film, i did not expect anything less from the soundtrack. the soundtrack is absolutely beautiful. it fits very well with the mood of the story. the music is energetic and epic. it reflects the speed of the dragons in flight and really gives you the feeling that you yourself is also flying on the back of a dragon. by all means, the music has added an all new level of fun to the film. my favorite song is "test drive". powell is a great composer and i'm looking forward to listening to more of his creations.

i purchased gastric band hypnosis by kimberley tylor and found it to be too basic and just falls short. i have been hypnotized before and have an extensive understanding of the process.  the most popular lap band hypnosis packages (granger, shiran, and others) typically conduct their sessions over 2 to 4 days (about 7 to 20 sessions).  this cd does nothing to educate, and is just the surgery and a separate adjustment sessions as well. if anyone is truly looking to do something like this i would suggest that they visit a local hypnotist and discuss what your trying to achieve. simply pull a google search for 'lap band hypnosis' or 'gastric band hypnosis' and there you go.  the one i found offered a free consultation and gave me some valuable info before i eventually got started.

i too was disappointed. i opened it and played it on christmas day, and was disappointed when the music proved to not be trans siberian orchestra as i was expecting. i have reread all of the information provided in ad, and it seems that i am to blame. i see nothing that would have led me to believe that it is tso. all my fault. the album itself is ok. it might be better if i knew what i was ordering. review carefully before ordering, buyer beware.

do yourself a favor and get the in the round in your face dvd and the video archive one, get a dvd ripper and get those 2 dvds into mp3, and you'll get a better deal than this live cd from def leppard.  this record brings nothing of value to music, and you'll forget about the new tunes by tomorrow.  if you expected the classical intro's for hysteria or rocket, forget it, not here.  if you liked the led zeppelin medleys they used to do with rock of ages or rocket, or the black betty intro for armaggedon it, forget it too.  if you liked pour some sugar on me, you'll see how vivian campbell can completely mess up a classic (steve clarke nailed it on the first live dvd i mentioned).  oh, and instead of bad actress (who the hell cares about that song!), action and rock on, they could have included something from slang or euphoria, or even better, wasted or mirror mirror from on through the night and high n dry.  they added nothing special to any of the songs, they just played them the same as if you bought the original songs and added screams in the background, except for sugar, which they messed up big, and lets get rocked, which the only speed up.  oh, and on the bringing on the heartbreak chorus, you'll hear the public singing it perfectly, but you'll notice that probably only 40 year old and older chicks sing in there.  now, regarding the new songs, all forgettable.  undefeated is as boring as they can get.  kings of the world is a queenesque song and they're not even good at it, and the last it's all about believing is more pop than rock, and kind of a u2 wannabe song.  get the older live dvd's and move along, this ain't no classic.  i just gave it 2 stars just because of the rock! rock! intro.

not what i expected from two of my favorite guitarist of all time. as a musician, the production is pretty average and the song writing? well, let's just say that they just started jamming out to some basic twelve bar blues and that pretty much sums it up. there were a few tracks 6 & 7 that had potential to be great songs if they really worked on them. but realistically it sounded like two great players just got together for a weekend and said, what the hell! let's jam and make a record. neither of them are showcasing their skills!

great music from a fresh voice! enjoyed most of the cd, which is hard to say these days about a lot of the stuff that comes out.  note: i returned the cd because it wasn't the version that came with "bass down low," make sure you get the cd with all 12 songs! don't know why but some people are selling an 11 song version.

the "come on" was that preview samples[product play list] slipped "i got the moves like jagger" --in;-- as if it were on  "hands all over"--well it wasn't; amazon lied--- sold "click one' to me ---for entire album that i didn't want--- unless it had that cut---so the lies are repleat

as a fan of the pet shop boys since west end girls, they have always been ahead of the music scene. they started releasing albums of b-sides because they had so much music that people never heard. it also put it all together as opposed to trying to hunt down rareities and limited editions that they are know for. format is their latest collection of great music that sounds pretty damn good. some songs you may recognize, and the rest you'll just dance to. it took me a while to find this cd and it is worth it.

i really liked alternative album of their early b-sides through 1990 or so.  i thought this collection of b-side material would also be good but i was disappointed.  and psb usually never disappoint me.  i only found 3 new tracks that i liked on the whole 2 cd set.  i already had how i learned to hate rock & roll, delusions of grandeur, and the view from your balcony.  the new tracks i liked were we're the pet shop boys and blue on blue.  the other tracks are not very catchy & my attention wasn't kept long enough for me to judge the lyrics.  the songs are much more personal than what was on pbs alternative so i can't relate to the songs.  unless you are a big fan of neil, i recommend downloading the above individual tracks from amazon or itunes.

although i try to get the limited edition 2 cd version of each psb cd, there were many songs on this collection that i did not own, many on the cd singles that i don't always buy.  this does complement all of the regular cd's well, and is an important addition to your collection if you are a big psb fan.  not for the people that still think psb is a one hit wonder.

...it's so much fun to turn over a rock and discover new sounds by these boys who i can never really get enough of....many of the tunes really aren't that new, but my ears hadn't laid lobes on them.  i had a blast adding even a couple of new favorites to my growing psb fav list.  i think you will too.  ~s

this is a great show and i love it as you can read the lyrics in the booklet.  i am keen to see the show as i have read the book and it is a great adaptation to the book by roald dahl.  i wish they had more photos in the booklet.  this is a great cd for musical theatre lovers.  i believe they have changed some of the lyrics for the broadway version and am keen to purchase that version in the future.
not a zac brown cd. three mediocre songs by zac and the rest are by unknowns.  i played it once and don't have interest in ever playing again.

with most bands, the sophomore effort isn't as good as the first. the killers are poster children for a less than stellar sophomore album. while i wasn't expecting "hot fuss v. 2.0", i was expecting the same level of awesome, if you will. unlike hot fuss which was refreshing and memorable, this is rather dull and forgettable. one word that keeps coming mind to describe this album is "themed". all the tracks seem to related somehow; they all sound the same. they seem to just blend together. it's so boring that with as many times as i've listened to it, none of the songs really stick out to me. i'm honestly surprised i can even sing along to any of the songs. you're much better off just sticking with "hot fuss" and "sawdust".

the only thing that upset me was that there is no killers c.d that has all my favorite songs by them on it. i do like most of the tracks on this one and on each c.d. that i bought they have  great opening songs to start you out.
this is not music this is junk. this guy will talk you to death.

sam's town by the killers is their best album to date. why does everybody despise this album so much? it's amazing, catchy, has great hooks, and just pure fun. standout tracks include: read my mind, for reasons unknown, this river is wild, my list, bling, and sam's town. the killer's style of music is somewhat similar to my other favorite band, garbage. the music is incredible, brandon flowers vocals are spot-on. give this album a chance and forget what the critcs have said. i highly recommend this masterpiece!
this started out a little different than their last album but grew on me quickly to become one of my favorite albums.

it took me a couple spins to really get a feel for their second album. this seems to be the consensus for all the reviews here.  i was a huge fan of their first album and didn't really expect anything to topple their singles from their last album (midnight show was great, though not a radio topper). however, as a whole and complete album, this one beats their freshman effort. i can sit down and listen to this from beginning to end!  i'll tell you that i'm more of an electro-synthpop fan, so for me to enjoy this album more than the last one, speaks volumes about the quality of the music here. flowers' vocals are much more raw and unfiltered, which for me, seems like a throwback to the 80's. the music stylings are varied yet keep the mood consistent throughout. in the back of my mind, i can visualize the energy they were going for (springsteen energy) and it definitely works for them... and for me too!  excellent!

i don't know what all of the 5-star reviewers are listening to; maybe i got a different version of sam's town.  all i know is this album is a complete mess.  i don't understand how a band can put out a nearly flawless debut album, a couple of good extra tracks in the interim ("glamorous indie rock and roll" and "the ballad of michael valentine"), and then crank out something as bad as this.  i wasn't expecting them to give us hot fuss 2, but i certainly wasn't expecting this.  it is hard for me to put my finger on exactly what is wrong with this album, but i think alot of it has to do with the absolute disconnect between the vocals and the background tracks.  i'm not exaggerating when i say that i could only listen to about 5 or 6 tracks before i got a headache.  it sounds like they laid down the background tracks first and then had flowers stand at the mike and make up the vocals impromtu--it's that bad.  what makes things even worse is that the lyrics are as insipid as lyrics get.  you get gems like "feel my bones on your bones"  and "i see london i see france"--no wait it's "i see london i see sam's town."  all in all, sam's town was a tremendous disappointment to me.  this was an album i had been looking forward to for months because their first album was so great.  but, it looks like some people really liked it, so i maybe i just don't get it.  but i would definitely borrow it and give it a listen before you go and drop $15 for it.

i haven't read all of the reviews for sam's town yet, so i don't know if anyone else has touched on this. but, what blows me away about this album is the raw emotion and energy that the killers display on this album. it's so obvious to the listener that the band is absolutely loving playing these songs. for the most part, the songs are up tempo, they're loud, they're energetic. i've seen the word "epic" thrown around a lot in regard to some of the tracks, and i think that word is a perfect way to describe the album.  much respect to everyone that appreciates the difference between sam's town and hot fuss. i, too, am glad that the killers switched things up on us.  not all of the songs are going to be instant classics, but they are all good and fun to listen to. i do agree with the many people that believe it may take a few listens to get used to and fully appreciate this new album. you may hear it for the first time and expect to hear another mr. brightside or another all these things that i've done. i sort of expected that. of course, you don't really hear those type of songs on here, and that's fine. songs like "sam's town", "when you were young", and "bling" are amazing songs, as well others throughout the album.  killers fan or not, give this album a chance. the songs are great. brandon is really singing with raw feeling and energy, the music is damn near inspiring with its energy and the production of it is flawless.  major props to the killers on this album and best of luck to them in the future.  don't let the critical reviews turn you away from trying this album. it's well worth it to hear for yourself.

welcome to sam's town! to me this album plays a lot like a film or even a broadway show. it is such an imaginative way to make a album and you have to give this band credit for that. they took a chance and it worked out. the album is like a view into the world of the people living in vegas not the nightlife like hot fuss. now don't get me wrong hot fuss is just amazing. sam's town is one of those albums that has to grow a bit on you before you can compare. and its just addictive in that way. you just want to keep on listening to the songs and that's what makes it amazing. in the long run this is a great album to own, and if you liked hot fuss i don't see why you won't like this. 5 stars all the way! welcome to sam's town everyone hope you enjoy your stay!  key tracks:  "bling (confessions of a king)"  "when you where young"  "uncle jonny"  "bones"  "this river is wild"
beautiful!  a journey into the soul. i love this album.
oooo! f****k. this is amazing!!
i've had previous versions and this one sounds amazing.the 5.1 version is insanely wonderful.

this blu-ray audio disc is freaking amazing.  i listen to this on a 7.1 surround sound system and it completely blows away anything else i have ever heard.  i don't really need to review this album here.  there are lots of good reviews out there.  i will say that standout tracks for me are the prophet's song and the obvious bohemian rhapsody.  this is one of my all-time favorite albums, so to me it is all good.  if you love this record and have the sound system for it, you are in for an audio treat with this and other blu-ray audio discs.

i got this because my new (at the time) rescue dog was adjusting to being crated during the day, and i wanted something to soothe her anxiety. i've since played it every day, and that was months ago! the music itself is great--excellent composers, sound quality, etc. much better than the cheesy "classical" music i was expecting! from the first few beats of the first piece, you really do feel relaxed! it must work, because i put my laptop webcam on my dog and check in on her throughout the day (through an app on my phone), and she sleeps all day! i would, too, if i had this playing on repeat.  this really is a quality cd that you could play for a baby, kid, or even just yourself. i like it better than those cds that play bird and other animal noises, because that would just get my dog riled up!  good cd...worth a try if you're worried about your dog being lonely or having anxiety. bonus--it blocks out sounds (mailman, phone ringing, etc.) that might disturb the dog.
it's a shame they broke up but what they left behind is like nothing else out there. this is the cd to own as they are at the top of their game.

here are the lads of il volo again, and they are even better than in their earlier cds and dvd. even in the early dvd from detroit opera, they were totally at ease with their audience. the ladies simply ate up the flirting.  but they are not about cheap flirting. they deliver each song with trained voices but with totally idiomatic renditions of pop ballads: soaring high notes, multi-languages, and diction to put many pop stars (including winners of american idol) to shame. whether these "kids" will ever tackle opera roles remains to be seen. they are too young for that yet. their voices are healthy and growing in expressiveness. they even bring out the youthful sound in placido domingo in his guest shot in "il canto." there is none of the breathy, falsetto singing some young men use trying to be sexy. (it  really never is.) their sound is masculine and yet young. ideals good enough for me!  all the texts are printed except for the christmas tracks. there are no translations, but frankly i don't care.  the dedication to their art and the sublime assurance they already show gives il divo a firm run for their money - and il volo wins.
with each album i am appreciating their talents more and more. i wait in anticipation for their next album. they are an amazing talent.

i have been waiting for this new cd to come out.  i was fortunate enough to see these boys when they first came to the u s.  my, how they have grown up in the last year.  i do hope they are right when they said that they hope to be singing together 40 years from now.  god has blessed them with a great talent.

i attended the phoenix concert and have played "in flight" a great deal.  we are love added a couple of dimensions and did not dissapoint.  i liked the key changes.  i appreciate listening to each voice and guessing who is singing although by now i know pretty well!  the italian songs are more beautiful even though i can't understand them and the english ones add a good change up.  you don't need placido domingo (you sound better) or the other guy.  why not add solo numbers as you did in phoenix?  one tiny criticism, the orchestra needed to be a notch quieter.  can't wait for a new album.

they have grown so in a year.  their voices are more magnificant.  totally different than their last cd(very excellent)  we are love is so grown up for teenage boys.  love love love!!!  i can't wait for the dvd to come out.

magnificent.  at first you know its different but once you listen to it twice you appreciate the maturity and their unbounding talent.  they are not your everyday teeny bopper group.  music is more mature than their ages.  they are magical and magnificent.  bravo.

prime cuts: great i am, song of the beautiful bride, glory came down  it is interesting where singer-songwriters find their inspiration.  many have often found their creative muses in the happenstances of personal and church relations; others were inspired to write after being piqued by a testimony, a conversation, a film, a newspaper article, a book or a sermon.  yet, other songs are birthed out of the writer's own tales of struggles and pains.  for paul wilbur, it is clear that the hebrew scriptures (or the old testament) are his major afflatus. wilbur, in the words of charles haddon spurgeon, bleeds bibline.  these 11 cuts are so soaked in the grand truths espoused by the old testament that they drip with a penetrating cry to us to take hebrew bible more seriously.  this comes as no surprise as wilbur is a messianic christian.  this means that wilbur believes that it is never surreptitious that god would call israel out of all the nations of the world.  and out of israel came jesus the messiah of whom all jews as well as gentiles are called to obeisance.  thus, deep within wilbur's heart expressed through his own music, there is a deep passion for israel as well as the nations to be reconciled in the worship of jesus.  whether or not one agrees with wilbur's dispensational theological paradigm, "your great name" is choke full of songs steeped in the motifs, images, phrases and ideas from the old testament giving us a rich trove of biblically-driven worship songs.  such an approach is not novice to wilbur: ever since his 1990 integrity music debut "up to zion," wilbur has always infused hebraism into his style of modern worship music.  and to season his recordings with an even more jewish flavor, three of his former records ("shalom jerusalem," "jerusalem arise" and "lion of judah") were even recorded in jerusalem on their important festive days.  unlike his preceding live records, "your great name" is his first studio recording in 20 years.  however, patterning after his 2010 live album "desert rain," this album is again thematically focused around a major motif conjured up from the old testament-this time around it is "the name of yahweh."  and just like his more recent records, there is a fuller sound created by an amalgamation of the sounds of the orchestral and the rhythmic of modern worship.  like the unfolding of a james horner-movie soundtrack, album opener "song of ezekiel" is a sprawling and dramatic cinematic orchestral piece calling us back to how god unveils the power of his name via at ezekiel's valley of dry bones.  the prophet ezekiel is not the only prophet evoked, isaiah's new exodus message is at the cynosure on "prepare the way" (a track that could actually work as a christmas worship song across churches).  while the story of moses and the burning bush shadows behind "great i am."  reverently introduced with just vocals and piano before it is joined by a bevy of strings, "great i am" is a beautiful ballad about the worship of god's name that causes the demons to flee and the mountains to crumble.  one of the reasons why wilbur is such an endearing worship leader lies in vocal prowess.  while many male worship leaders have a light tenor, wilbur possesses a full-bodied fernando ortega operatic base. trained in high-italian opera in milan, italy, wilbur utilizes his pedigree well:  when he hits the low notes there is such a gravitas of emotional depths that send shimmers down one's soul.  this is most evident in the guitar driven "who is like you."  and when it is time to soar, listen to some vocal-power exuberance especially on "glory come down."  however, wilbur is at his vocal best with the climax-building worship pop ballad "nobody like you."  starting off soft and slow before building and building up his vocal intensity this is a track where you can hear wilbur in his full vocal glory.  vocal gymnastics aside, one song not to be missed is "song of the beautiful bride."  keying on the biblical theme that we are the bride of christ made up of various nations this song is a passionate call for all of us to be united in reflecting the light of our coming bridegroom.  all in all, "your great name" is not just one of your average worship albums.  the messianic worship songs steeped in the language of the old testament is itself a reason to warm up to this album.  add to this wilbur has a gorgeous voice; it's one that truly makes songs exalting the great name of yahweh even more majestic and contagious.

when i heard dido had a fourth album (two years later!) i ran out and bought it. it pains me to write such a negative review, because i am a huge fan of dido. but this album just doesn't cut it. there are simply no memorable melodies, or lyrics, here. most of the lyrics seem like free verse forced into weak and nondescript melodies, and none of them are interesting, with the bare exception of "no love no freedom", but even that one is too repetitive. there is no sense of a verse leading up to a strong chorus, like some of her past songs like "white flag" or "if i don't believe in love" or "two little gods". the songs are unfocused and forgettable. and many of the percussion effects are annoying. and a rapper on track 3? ugh. her voice is great as ever, and the production is superb. but that's about it. i hope dido has a better album in store. i hate to see her end with this one.

dido's previous albums are regulars in my play lists and i was excited to see she had released this one. i ordered the cd without having heard any of the new songs, just based on my enjoyment of all her previous material. she has always had a good mix of music and lyrics with music that complements her voice. unfortunately she has made a complete departure from the music that had served her so well. instead of supporting her vocals, the new style is a complete distraction. just make sure you listen to several of the songs before you buy so so know what you are getting.

her last few albums have left something to be desired. i am waiting for the time where i have listened to it enough to maybe like it. definitely not like her first two albums where every song was a hit from the start.
i love her voice, but the material needs inprovement. i'll be taking this cd to "disk replay" to sell it.

i was trying to put my finger on what the crux of the problem was, when her live ep came on my ipod, and it hit me.  this album lacks "music" due to three main issues.  the first issue is that dido does not actually sing, but takes her breathy vocals to a new extreme.  she whispers the lyrics, making me question if she really feels what she is singing.  there is no passion or immediacy to the song.  these songs could be spoken by anyone, let alone sung.  the second issue is the lack of musicians.  while dido and her brother have relied on electronics for many of her recordings, it was not as sparse and complete as this album.  many songs are nothing more than a click track with random sounds in the background.  her previous albums have had a lush sound to them.  this is just breathy vocals with electronic's straight off a poor casio keyboard.  and the final issue is the use of the poor rap vocals.  while she has blurred the lines between pop and rap with eminem, this seems just strange.  nothing really connects.  there are a few songs that have enjoyable moments, but most sound like unfinished songs or ideas from previous albums.

first let me say that purple has been one of my favorite bands since 1972.  i have every album/cd they have ever put out, as well as "bootleg" recordings they they used to sell in rare vinyl stores.  but since blackmore left, there has been a steady decline in great songs, and after jon lord left, it really went downhill.  every cd has the same problem, very few great songs.  ( blackmore's cd's have the same problem).  since the guitar and keyboards basically make  most of the music, they need to replace them and get some fresh writing.  on this cd, i only liked 2 out of 12 songs, which is not so good. up to blackmore's departure, i would love all or nearly all of each cd.  it's a shame, because they all are wonderful musicians, but  most of the songs  just don't do it for me.  i always vowed to buy any cd that purple put out, but after so many so -so cd's, i think i've had it with this lineup.  the dvd was ridiculous in the fact that there is a long interview with the band, and then 3 audio tracks, which have one great song live.  when you spend 15 bucks for a cd/dvd,  there should be some great concert footage on it, not interviews and audio tracks.  what were they thinking?  as long as blackmore and lord are gone, they will only be as good as their old material.  but for the devoted fans of purple like me, there is a few good songs to add to your ipod.

what a jewel of a cd - i don't know which is more beautiful: the music, orchestration, voice, or poetry (which i sometimes read and reread just as i begin to play the cd). i "discovered" it listening to an early morning npr review of it on early march 2013, immediately ordered it via amazon, and it has taken me through the rest of a long, cold new england winter. love both strong women artists, and also the "artistshare" concept - great to see a fair and just approach to producing music. i bought a second cd and sent it on to a friend in auckland, new zealand, just needing to share the beauty - and to help my kiwi friend through her own (nz) winter. the writings on the cd jacket are a warm welcome inviting the listener into the lives of the artists. this beautiful cd already feels like an old friend.

i excitedly pre-ordered "prism" by katy perry (deluxe version) due to my previous music enjoyment of "teenage dream" (from 2010) and a strong intuitive feeling to purchase this collection. i am glad that i followed my psychic hunch because many of these songs are happy and symbolize a message of cheerfully relishing  various facets of life.  there is something for many men and women in "prism" such as the being unstoppable and resilient in life through the song "roar" and being in love with someone who is a kindred spirit to you: such as through the music track "double rainbow".  obviously, i'm fully aware that personal song favorites are going to be as varied as the listeners of "prism".  my personal favorites are "birthday", "international smile", "dark horse", "legendary lovers" and "walking on air".  however, there are many more music tunes to enjoy on "prism" such as "unconditionally", "this how we do", "this moment", "by the grace of god", and "it takes two." "prism" (deluxe version) by katy perry is definitely recommended if you enjoyed katy perry and/or you like music collections sprinkled with pop, hip-hop, and eurodance melodies.

prism is much better than teenage dream. but the whole album is still not for children. there are several songs that are not for children the main one is "birthday" do not buy this or let your children listen to this! there are some songs that are okay for children but not the whole album and definietly not the song caleld "birthday" so if you hear your children listening to this stop it immediately, also do not let them listen to teenage dream almost any song other than firework is very sexually explicit! the title track teenage dream, california dreams, et, peacock, last friday night are all sexually explicit and no children should listen to those, if you let your children listen to those you are a horrible parent.  now as for this album there is at least way way less sexuality...the only major sexual song is birthday and the lyrics in the other songs are much better, but the major problem with this one is another problem teenage dream album had is that it forces way too much high pitched vocals that don't sound good because there's just way too many high pitched vocals in that song...luckily not all songs like are like that...but even the more decent songs are just completely generic and suffer from poor vocals...they're just not as bad as the others but still not worth listening to. a lot of these songs are clearly influenced by if not directly copying many other songs so the originality is not there, even roar is highly similar to several other songs including eye of the tiger by survivor, plus the song this moment copies what made trapped in the closet by r. kelly famous there is no way that similarity was done on accident. lack of originalty and too many repetitive bad sounding high pitched vocals ruin the majority of the album. some bad lyrics. cannot recommend the album has a whole despite the album not being all bad there are some decent [very generic] tracks but still not really worth listening to because there is way better music out there. this album and the artist themselves is fake. this artist never would have had a hit song if it weren't for buying her own radio airtime [confirmed by radio stations] and buying youtube views [also confirmed by youtube and vevo] what ultimately makes these songs just horrible is just the fact of how horrible of a person katy perry is. she is a lying, cheating, and backstabbing person who doesn't belong in the music industry. she never would have ever charted if she didn't cheat to chart.

you want to turn the most mundane task into an epic event? just do whatever it is to the accompaniment of this stirring original score for "thor: the dark world." i listened to it twice while putting away holiday decorations and cleaning house and my energy level never dropped. i expect it to become a work out staple on my ipod and that i will listen to it at work, anytime i need to feel inspired, energized, and motivated. the rousing main theme is carried through on many of the tracks, with varying embellishments, at its most rousing on "untouchable" and "legacy," which gives me goosebumps every time i hear it. the minor key tracks "the trial of loki" and "shadows of loki" are understated, yet perfect for the character. vocals beautifully accompany gorgeous instrumentals on "lokasenna" and "into eternity." the music of brian tyler's score stuck with me after i saw the movie in a way that patrick doyle's did not for "thor." i love a great original score and for my money, this is the best score of 2013.

the set list is great, the dvd is well done.  but his vocal tic (as noted before) makes this set unlistenable.  almost every single line ends with "ah". i can handle the dvd since i won't watch it very often, but the cd's that i'd like to listen to over and over because of the great set list are impossible to get through even once.  the tic just grates on my nerves like fingernails on a chalkboard.  worth owning for the dvd though.

listen, when you find a cd where every single song is beautiful and amazing, you need to have it in your life.  there's just too much to say about it, and truthfully, i find myself echoing all of these other great reviews.  i heard "testimony" on the radio a few months back and loved it. and when i heard his testimony behind the song when he sang on bobby jones, i had an even greater appreciation for it! but i had no idea until this past week that the entire project was so amazing! i was stuck on track 1 "group therapy" for 2 days before i could move on to hear the rest of it.  the music is incredible, the vocal arrangements are criminal, and the entire project is absolutely anointed! anthony brown is a very clever songwriter. his tunes are melodic and catchy to sing along with, but if you're planning to sing them at your local church assembly.... good luck on executing these tunes with the beautiful, saavy, rich, and scrumptious vocal parts that he's put together. lol! "better days" will set you ablaze! "harvest song" and "water" will take you innnn! but for real, there is no need to skip songs on this project. it is absolutely amazing.  you owe it to yourself to get it!

this only gets 2 stars because i am a pink floyd fan.  thank god i did not buy this when it was $20 instead i only wasted $5 on it.  i am not a fan of the early pink floyd stuff like piper at the gates of dawn so i was hoping with this being a lot of stuff recorded at the same time but cut out of division bell that it would be just as good as division bell or close.  well its not hard to know why this crap was left off division bell.  this is on par with the garbage they first made.  there was 1 song that sounded like it was left off division bell that was alright, but thats it.  i can't believe this was released or that anyone listening to it told dave or nick yeah man that sounds great we should make that an album.

i just listened to this; with great anticipation. i cannot convey how utterly disappointed i am!!!! the members of this group who are still alive should be absolutely ashamed of what they just did to the icon that is pink floyd!!! i absolutely hate this. it seems the only reason they did this was for the $. i understand doing things for money, but i feel completely ripped off! it should have been released under another group name. this material is not deserving of being included in the discography of one of the most brilliant bands in history!!!

musically, it's nothing that will make you think "this is the best album, ever".  it's a mash up of wrights leftovers from the division bell.  they really make something solid out of it though.  some moments are very reminiscent of welcome to the machine from the wish you were here album.  but,  overall, it's that kind of album where i ask myself, "if this weren't pink floyd,  would i care?".  i think not.  as a final album,  it fails.  as a stand alone album,  it's nothing remarkable and easily forgettable.  as a tribute to a fallen band mate,  it does well.  if some new band made this album,  and didn't have a legacy to fall back on, would you take the chance on this?  probably not.

pink floyd is one of the greatest rock groups of all time, but you wouldn't know it by listening to this travesty. in the past, pink floyd has issued many songs that begin with slow musical ramblings that suddenly open into recognizable and endearing melodies. here, you only get the musical ramblings that go absolutely nowhere. you keep waiting for the melody, the tune, the song.........forget it. it isn't there. i own every pink floyd album on their original vinyl pressings. in other words, i have been a fan since the beginning. this is not a pink floyd album. this is a compilation of outtakes from the "division bell" album. to compare this mess to "wish you were here" which some reviewers have done, is insulting to anyone with one or more ears. this album comes very close to ruining pink floyd's musical legacy. a proper title for this album would have been "endless musical noodling."
another balcony sacrifice. they should be ashamed of themselves
merry christmas to my son. got him this the day it was released he's pissed because i am making him wait until christmas. a lesson in patience....now he knows what its like to wait! love, mom

nope i am 49 years old,seen pink floyd live. i listened to this once at work and once in my truck. these are the only two spins this one will get from me! i just don't here much on this worth listening too.:( think i will just pop in some of my old floyd stuff.

one word, "awesome." this album, although sad that it is pink floyds last, i would consider this the frosting on the cake. they are going out with an awesome explosion of pure awesome music that rings power. i just can't say enough about it, but that i am proud to have been on this long ride with floyd, and now the ride has ended, but im sure that there will be bits and pieces pop up throughout the coming years, if not more lost pink floyd music. thanks pink floyd for the great music to tickle our minds. i am comfortably numb.

yes it musically sounds like pink floyd of latter day. but where are the lyrics? pink floyd have always had a story to tell and without lyrics and am just not interested i am afraid. this album will not be getting many listens from me. farewell floyd.

the endless river, the "new" pink floyd album seems more like a bonus disc that would accompany a rerelease of "the division bell" than it does a brand new floyd record.  usually i listen to a bonus disc, as i did with dark side of the moon, wish you were here, and the wall once or twice than put it back in it's case and forget about it while still enjoying the original content.  the first side of the record struck me as a discount version of "shine on you crazy diamond" before morphing into a discount version of "welcome to the machine".  c'mon, you can't tell me those chords don't sound familiar.  sound effects from previous floyd recordings are recycled throughout making it seem less new.  finally, the last song on the album is the only one to contain lyrics.  it's called "louder than words" and is perhaps the worse song pink floyd has ever released.  the lyrics are juvenile and the intro guitar but sounds as if it were lifted from a queensryche track called "waiting for 22".  peace.

i'm a lifelong fan of pink floyd and think they are the best band ever and when i heard this album was coming,out, i was so looking forward to it, especially since it had been 20 years, but when i downloaded it today, i was totally disappointed.  i've listened to it three times today, trying hard to like it, but can't.  i know it is a tribute to richard wright but that makes it worse as it is a bad tribute.  there is a reason these weren't added to division bell the first time as they should have been left alone and never seen the light of day.  i wasted my money on the deluxe edition.  it is very baaaaaaaaddddd!  i give two stars as it is my favorite band, but, it is a total failure!

lacking the structural tension of a "true" pink floyd album, like the title, these tracks---they aren't songs,they are just tracks--drift past you with the exception of one of david's occasional searing guitar solos.  as everyone knows, this is simply background music. if you want some fully realized music by richard wright, buy his solo cds, wet dream or broken china.
well the supposedly new copy they sold me was obviously not new i could've done a better job recording it off the internet and they did. sound quality was horrible and for 20 not worth it

if anyone is looking to get this album by david garrett after watching the film, "the devil's violinist," you'd be disappointed. if anyone is looking to get this album because you want to appreciate his technical brilliance in intimacy and intricacy of his violin sound, you'd be disappointed. why? because the album pretty much butchered his art with the modernized, jazzed up accompaniment that is highly suitable as a grocery store music than for anyone serious about the "classical" component of the album. "the devil's trill sonata," for example, gets lost in the jazzed up accompaniment that basically goes boom boom boom, drowning the sound of the violin. if you like that cheapened stuff, go ahead and purchase this album and listen to it while cooking your dinner. what about the most charming "carnival of venice"? it'd have been whole lot better if it was just accompanied by a simple string plucking as opposed to, again, this poor choice of jazzed up accompaniment that essentially destroyed the magic of this piece.  what saved this album from a total loss are the ones that have nothing to do with garrett: bocelli and scherzinger.

i bought the dvd of this concert direct from amazon and loved it.  i wanted just the audio, but wasn't sure if the cd had all of the concert (i'll elaborate later) and reviews here didn't help.  but, i'm a lindsey stirling fan, so i pulled the trigger on it.  to get to the point: yes, this cd only has the recordings of the songs being played.  i'll elaborate, but be warned, i'm going to slightly spoil some of the content.  those of you who have watched the dvd know that lindsey talks over the beginning of the dvd, and her speech carries into part of the first song of the concert.  and throughout the concert, lindsey talks, chats, and interacts with the audience multiple times between songs.  i don't mind this while watching (it's funny, uplifting, and inspiring for the most part!) the concert, but i wanted just the songs for times when i'm otherwise occupied (exercising, cleaning, etc.) and won't be watching a screen.  i saw this cd and wondered if it had all of lindsey's dialogue or not.  going back to the beginning of my review, it does not.  this cd only has the audio from the performed songs, and they were edited quite well, nothing was cut out or off.  so, if you want the full experience, get the dvd.  if you simply want to listen to lindsey perform live without any chatter, i suggest the cd.  again, i'm a fan, so i had no qualms about getting both.

our family loved with lee in virginia! as a mom i am so grateful to have these amazing audio theaters to listen to. we don't have a dvd player in our vehicle and honestly - we will never have one. the chance to listen to a story that teaches history, character, morals, etc from a christian perspective that engages and entertains our entire family is golden! we have fun discussions and my kids ask questions that amaze me.  when we travel i have noticed far less arguments and fighting between my kids. thank you heirloom! i highly recommend all of heirloom's productions.
