i received my copy today from a seller in the uk (far less than the stated price on amazon), and i haven't stopped listening to it; cd has "not for resale on it because it was only distributed in the daily mail newspaper in the uk. you can hear shades of previous sounds from earlier in his career (pre-purple rain). however, when you listen you won't feel as if he is reverting, but instead moving you through his musical career as he grows his sound. one of my favorites is walk in sand. prince's ballads are always sensual and sweet, and this one is no different. sea of everything and act of god (a staple singers feel), and the funky lay down are next on the list, but there are other gems as well. as i continue to listen i hear melodies that remind me of music on his art official age album from 2014. like so many of prince's post warner brothers albums, they were overlooked because he moved to a different sound and a whole new musical level; a true musician. i'm not a professional critic just a long time prince fan, who, at this point, am a bit miffed that with such a vast catalog of music, and different genres, we only hear a mere fraction of the songs from his 39+ albums.

i have used this product dozens of times. when i am tired but have no more than 30 minutes to relax, i play this cd through a set of comfortable headphones while lying in bed. i awake refreshed and peaceful. i will not attempt to describe the theory behind this product. the program narrator, robert monroe, and the audio technique, hemi-sync, used to induce a sleep-receptive state [...].  the program narrates instructions that lead the listener to a deep state of relaxation. the listener is encouraged to drop off to sleep at any time. in the background are surf noises and innocuous tones that produce the hemi-sync effect.  after 30 minutes the program wakes the listener.  of the many times i have listened to this tape, i failed to fall asleep only one time and i slept beyond the thirty minutes only one time. most sessions i awake feeling sleepy but quickly return to an alert and contented condition before the program ends. this contrasts with a non-assisted 30-minute nap in which i often awake groggy and remain so for 15 minutes or longer. i definitely prefer the catnapper cd.  i should mention that the relaxation achieved at the beginning of the tape is conducive to the body remaining in one position for the entire 30 minutes. this means the listener is not prone to toss and turn which would be uncomfortable while wearing a set of headphones.  stereo headphones or stereo speakers placed equidistant from the ears are required to achieve the hemi-sync effect. if the hearing in one ear is weaker than the other ear, it may be difficult to achieve this effect without a playback device or headphones with a right/left balance control.

if you really want to hear deb talan cut loose with her full unbridled rock-out musicality, this is the cd you were looking for!  she does lovely things with her voice you will never hear live or on any subsequent cds, and again the backing hummingfish musicians do a great job in executing the last (unfortunately!) of their two collaborations with the celestial deb talan.  four tracks stand out:  "chocolate", which is bouncy with a really funny and clever lyric delivered with rapid-fire eloquence; "real life", a rhythm guitar that would make tom petty envious coupled with deb's powerful strongly accented country-northern vocal; "she", a catchy country tune with an effortlessly gorgeous wide-range dipping and soaring vocal reminiscent of the later "sincerely" from bird flies out; and the more melancholy "living room" which is of a piece with her subsequent solo album, "something burning". as wonderful as deb talan's subsequent work is, and as one privileged to attend several of deb's glorious live performances, i find that there is an enchanting energy in "love traktor" that may never come again - perhaps as joni mitchell would say, "..something lost and something gained in living every day...".
if you like poetry, english poetry, you can't help but love it.

autres voix, autres blues takes the mighty bop another level higher. though their keen sense of hip-hop is on full-display (like on the stripped-down "excursion mentale"), they also show a more nuanced and integrated approach to melody. needless to say, louise vertigo's lovely voice on tracks like helps stitch these elements together - - just listen to the deep, funk groove of "peau d'ane" or the neo soul of "je n'ai pas le choix." "un jour..." carries a heavier beat, and it pushed forward by vertigo's expressive vocals. if you're in the mood for something more upbeat, "initials mb" and "moody's mood" throw a house beat into the mix that's as deep as a hole in the earth. outstanding.

a treasured collection for the new age and world music fan. this music captures your mind and spirit and is an evocative and exciting collection which will open your mind and take you above the plain of ordinary consciousness.  "yeha noha" takes you into the mind of an eagle as it soars high above the earth swirling to the sky. you can feel the energy in the sky and see the sun rising. they say if you see an eagle soaring up to the sky, it means good things will happen to you. this title of this song means: "wishes of happiness and prosperity."  sweet lullaby makes you think of the scent of rain and fresh earth, perhaps a walk through an african veld in the afternoon while you listen to the beat of drums somewhere in the distance.  a good set of speakers or headphones is a must so you can enjoy all the nuances of this collection. this music will engulf a room and promotes peace, joy and a feeling of harmony with life. you can literally drift away to another world by listening to this music. it is very uplifting and evokes images of peaceful places and blissful journeys.  "chi mai" is an incredibly sad piece of music so i guess this is not all joy and happiness but there is a certain poignancy in the music which speaks to future happiness and an feeling of being engulfed in love no matter what happens in life.  "prelude" will take you to india. yanni's music was my first introduction to mood music and it is fitting that his music is on this cd.  "cavatina" is a beautiful piece which is extremely evocative of romance and country picnics. happiness and hope are the feelings this music will evoke in you. perhaps the start of a new day.  on the second cd, "children" is a deep water piece which reminds me of whales playing in the ocean and of ships sailing in the wind. you can almost hear the cries of whales. the beat is very up tempo and is in contrast with the first cd which seems to be a slower pace. you never want the song to end and it does seem to have the feeling of eternity.  "chacharpaya" has south american/mexican flair and is filled with flutes and drums.  "protection" was more light smooth jazz. "the sun rising" is perhaps the best song on this cd as far as mood music goes.  "sadness part 1" will be one of the most recognizable songs. "brideshead" is classic music with violin and harp and is followed by "pie jesu" which is ethereal. "schindler's list" is a haunting piece with a sad violin and a sense of unfulfilled dreams.  there were a few pieces i fast forwarded over, but overall, i think you will enjoy this set. i would choose this imported selection over the other cd's because you just get so many more selections. i think you will play the first cd more than the second, but it depends on your mood. return to your senses with this beautiful compilation.  ~the rebecca review

whoa! first off, i could just kick myself for not listening to this cd sooner. as it's been sitting around in my computer room for at least two months. total of seven superbly played full-blown psychedelic cuts that sun dial had recorded around 1990-91. why hasn't this trio been better known? first off, i thought i was losing my mind when i heard this disc start off with a tune that was originally done by the little known late '60's band open mind, with an astounding take on "magic potion". then there's the wailing "north eastern", the stellar "fireball", the foot tapping "through you" and the epic, thirteen-minute "sunstroke / mindtrain" to cause you some even further brain damage. who could ask for more? line-up: gary ramon - guitar, bass & vocals, anthony clough - keyboards and john pelech - drums. it rarely gets any better. so extremely highly recommended, it hurts.

we have 9 of t.c's cd's, and each one is a favorite for late night  relaxation and good listening. gave 2 to a friend who was in hospital for 5  days. they made her stay very tolerable and she hasn't given them back. my  massage lady plays them in her massage rooms and has had many requests from  her clients. very unusual sounds. i highly recommend any of his cd's. he  has a new one, "live at sydney opera house". wish that i had been  there. tony and his wife are two very talented people.

if you are a lover of nana mouskouri, then you will love esther too; and even if you find nana outdated, you may still love esther. if you are a pop music lover, you will easily fall in love with her, for esther will make you find even mary black simple, dull and flat. if you are a classical music lover, you will be impressed all the more, for she went further than nana who just got a classical training in music. she gets right into the source and life of music in almost the same way as bach did. that explains why she is so appealing. i do suspect that esther will never get outdated, for her voice and music is the embodiment of music itself, so rich and yet so fresh. my attention was first drawn to this record because the singer was accompanied by munich philharmonic, a first rate orchestra by whatever standard. the orchestra also accompanied pianists like fredrich gulda, but the latter was a gold medalist in a world competition when a teenager, and had later become the masterclass teacher of both the renowned conductor abbado and equally renowned pianist martha argerich. it was such a pleasant surprise to hear esther. my family are so addicted to her that i'm now obliged to check out more of her music. this is just a brief supplement to the previous reviews.

i bought this cd based on the rave reviews on amazon, and it's a disappointment. the collection on the cd are not as beautiful as those on the jane austen companion album, which i think is much better and more reminiscence of the jane austen period, or at least the movie remake. the music on this cd are beautifully played, but they aren't and won't be my favorite pieces. mediocre pieces at best. if i get to preview this album on amazon, i won't have bought it. on the other hand, the jane austen companion can be previewed on amazon, it's grander pieces, and it's even cheaper than this album.

a sweet sunrise of an album. full of orchestral pop. very beautiful and well done. there seems to be more of a french musical influence on chocolat than her contemporary j-pop peers. if you like kahimi karie or the cradigans, you should explore the world of chocolat. this album and "hamster" are excellent places to start. sure, these import prices are pretty high to pay, but i can promise you that it's well worth it. great packaging and design on this album too, by the way...always a plus. chocolat is great!

i bought klose's enhanced cd release a few years ago. when i saw this cd i figured it would be as good. but! ever get the feeling that a song sounds like 5 other songs mixed into one? "the strangest thing" about  this cd is that i feel like i've heard every song on it already. there  really isn't much original about this release. "real easy to say"  is actually a re-release of a cut from the enhanced cd. come on klose, a  greatest hits cd before you've even had a hit? that tells me jann klose has  come up dry and needed to go back to previous material to release a cd. i  have to admit that jann klose has a wonderful and soulful voice, but he  should stick to singing and leave the songwriting to others.

i discovered the old world on mp.3 and was immediately impressed by the standard and variety of intrumentation and quality of lyricism. the vocals are unique while the overall feel of the music has strong influences of  jethro tull, but with a much stronger sense of direction. the mandolin is  central to the group's sound and has never been put to better use in the  modern era. gypsy girl is a masterpiece. everything about this album says  that this group is going places. in an age of dull, repetetive,  manufactured groups, this fresh sound is music to the ears.

beatles on accordion, now that's a twist.  i thought i might get tired of 20 accordion pieces but these are full and varied arrangements with various instruments depending on the song, bass, drums, piano, guitar.  very lively arrangements and definitely keeping in the spirit of the beatles.  i'm ready for volume 2.  highly recommended if u like instrumentals.

you think that with an artist with the name of the railway raver would be full of nostalgia for the good ol' days of raves, but the railway raver seem much more invested in detroit than warehouses with his album drop acid not bombs. he opts for the mellower side of techno, with "mine storm" hitting the beats, yet still keeping itself on an even keel, and "my lacoste (577 n mix)" is surprisingly lush and melodic. "mantons' run (on the run)" does the futuristic mystery well, and "the elizabethan pornograph smugglers" has a smooth, sensuous groove to it. warmth fills up "to be a man like ingersol" and "land of conclusion." electro bloops its way onto "the eyes of garfield (part ii)," and "keith's trumpets" slinks its way into some summery house before exploding into a minor key blitzer. "acid for the 90's" closes the album with a quicker bpm, though staying within the same sedate vibe. a surprising album, and all the more strong for it.

no reviews? i don't have many. this one, this years model, king of america, and imperial bedroom. punch the clock imo is easily the best. i listen throu it strait. many of the tracks are about the superficiality of modern romance (punching in n punching out) of course u can get lyrics on the net but here are some choice lines include some of ec rude ones whos tongue now is tasting last weeks flavor? punch ghe clock and in time youll get pulled apart if you're married on paper and not in your heart the conversation melts like chocolate down their open jaws/ as the juniper berries slip down just like last drawers the little girl you dangled on your knee without mishap stirs something in your memory and something in your lap the themes of boxing (as in punching) and punching the clock run thruout everyday i write the book is very clever describing a relationship chapter by chapter shipbuilding is about war n bs round it pills and soap is basically the guilotine give me the needle give me the rope weer gonna melt them down for pills and soap there are a couple songs that integrate elements of media influence: but if stars are only painted on the ceiling above (movie theater) then who do u turn to n who do u love. in king of thieves the "news" sucking up misery to feed to the public.  theres so much more and its all tied together its one album...mostly

yeah, i thought i got lucky ordering mayall's the bottom line. although it is the bottom line, it is not john mayall - the bottom line. it's some various artist recording that has some fairly good artists like rick ocasek, graham parker, joey ramone, janis ian, luka bloom, and some others. this is not a critique on this album, but a warning that if you think you'll get mayall's the bottom line, you wont. when i called amazon the second time (the first agent must have been going through pms or something), i got a satisfactory response, but (between the first, and second agent) it took 30 min. my best recommendation is if you think you're getting a mayall album, don't buy this!!!!
this is in the top 3 of my favourite antonello venditti albums. it's just a delight - for 20 years now

this recording (also listed as 'passio iberica') is a program of sacred music by the vocal quartet known as la colombina;  it focuses on compositions for holy week, specifically, extracts from muandy thursday latin liturgy in spain and its dominions.  la colombina specializes in the sacred and secular music of the iberian peninsula in the renaissance era.  the group's name is derived from the colombina songbook preserved in the cathedral of seville.  these singers have perfect 'authentic' credentials as fully conversant experts in both the musical and linguistic vocabulary.  they have been and remain soloists in their own right but together make a  very compatible ensemble in every way.  they consist of maria cristina kier, soprano & argentinian; claudio cavina, countertenor & italian; joseph cabre, bass-baritone & catalan;  and joseph benet, tenor & catalan.  their important underlying message is a confirmation of the growing awareness that spain, long forgotten as a musical culture within the european classical tradition, had a fully developed and eloquent musical system of its own - and that only in recent times has it been overshadowed by italian contemporaries such as monteverdi.  and interesting concept do be sure!  be that as it may, the music on this disc is sacred liturgy at its best performed with finesse and beautiful beyond measure.  the dominating composer is tomas luis  victoria ( no surprise there). the other composers  are :  franciscus vasquez, estevao de brito, cristobal de morales, juan de lienas and frei manuel cardoso.  and it's all sixty-rhree minutes of glorious celestial music.  i knew that i would find it enjoyable mostly because this quartet is outstanding with their resonant sounds, very good balance, perfect diction and overall musical phrasing.  the other recording i have displays all of the above characteristics;  it is "christmas in spain & mexico" and includes a variety of spanish composers, notably padilla, victoria, fernandez, morales and guerrero. another la colombina  'gem'.  the accompanying booklet includes pertinent information about the recording, the performers and the libretto;  all in english, french & german, the libretto translated from the latin.

okay, so i am a huge grace bumbry fan, and as with all opera fans i wanted every recording i could get my hands on.  this was released years ago in europe and hidden away as it's not a great crossover album and i suspect that everyone involved knew it.  the singing is fine, but never exciting, the arrangements are canned and the use of synthesizers is so heavy that you often wish it was just the diva and a piano.  that being said it is a great chance to hear one of the greatest opera stars do something other than verdi, bizet or wagner.  all fans must own this!

bryden thomson has probably the best performance of bax worst symphony. the rich bax spent many happy years in ireland, was buddies with wb yates,and  wrote celtic twilight poetry under a irish pseudonym. bax, an englishman totally identified with the irish .he went around speaking gaelic to the quizzical stares of the uncomprehending irish until finally his buddy and fellow mystic poet  ae (george russell) pointed out to him that that was rude...  when the 1916 easter uprising against the english came, which was brutally suppressed by the british black and tans , machine guns against the unarmed irish, bax was enraged.. he wrote angry, violent, bitter symphony 1 initially for piano until someone pointed out to him only a symphony orchestra could capture the emotion he was after. so he revised.   he was also, at the time, trapped in an unhappy marriage with elsita, who wouldn't grant him a divorce, and in love with pianist harriet cohen  symphony 1 has little of none of the magic of later symphonies, like the wonderful bax 3 and 6.  thomson's version is a bit bright and harsh. that having been said, the second, slow movement is the best of the three, full of smoky ghosts and wraiths. bax slow movements are often to most intriguing, most listenable, with the least anger and angst.  the vernon handley version is quite a bit smoother and easier to listen to, aided by the latters 24-bit recording  tone poem christmas eve celebrates little of christmas and a lot of "500 years of british suppression of the irish", at least before the independent irish republic was created..  sorry, i call them as i hear them . not my fav. i dearly love bax works and thomson's performances,  but not this one.

the "laude" of the renaissance italian city-states have survived in just two manuscripts; until recently they constituted one of the last major genres of early music to be reconstructed and performed. essentially, they were the music commissioned by the guild-like confraternities (with members from the middle and lower economic classes of the cities) for performance by the members and by well-paid professional soloists, at festivals and in the side-chapels of the cathedrals where most lay people attended to their religious devotions. in short, the music of the people rather than the priests. they are basically monophonic rather than polyphonic, though harmonies were surely improvised by standard rules and practices. they are very joyful for the most part, and when performed artfully, they have a lot of "soul" in both the spiritual and the musical-slang senses. la reverdie has made the laude their core repertory, though they perform other italian and french medieval music quite convincingly. it's hard to vouch for the historical accuracy of any 13th or 14th century performance, but la reverdie makes enjoyable music of whatever they perform. doron sherwin, who sings and plays cornetto and recorder, is one of a handful of living cornettists who could have earned a goodly living with his chief instrument (the cornetto)even in renaissance venice or florence.
though i've been known to judge a record by its cover, after i listen to it i know for sure.  while this has a cool cover, the sounds vlach and company make are even better.

for once, a performance is equal to the music itself. i refer to mozart klavierkonzerte piano concertos no. 22 k 482 no 23 k 488 - christian zacharias. its flawless. nefertiti has lost one eye in perpetuity but theres nothing wrong with her hearing; being an exemplar of taste, she too endorses it. i was recently asked to compile a top ten list of mozart performances and i inanely ignored it. it medals in the very least. more widely, ive inscribed my admiration of zacharias cycle elsewhere on amazonia, even if paradoxically hes better in the bigger challenges than the lesser ones. the one exception to this rule could be his k 491 where hes accompanied by wand with the north german radio symphony orchestra. uncle gnter is a better mozartian than brucknerian if you ask me (as i don't rate him in the latter domain, this is not hard); his contribution here is stylish and welcome. itd be easy to dismiss this performance of the c minor as being bereft of fire in the outer movements, beautifully played though they be. the duo purposively take a more introspective view of k 491. i wouldnt want to hear it played in this fashion every time but it makes one listen anew. its subtle if nothing else. there are no reservations re k 595. due weight is given to its unique alloy of sadness and joy. it may not quite displace haebler or gilels. even so, as shadows lengthen, it tables melody as riposte to darkness and oblivion. great stuff.

i wore my cassette tape out and have boon looking for this cd off-and-on for years, so i was delighted to find it once more and ordered two copies!  having sung most of these pieces myself in choir, i greatly appreciate this particular choir for their outstanding performance and musicianship. a huge thank you must naturally go to the director for his leadership and close attention to every detail encompassed within this music and its execution. this is a must-have for any person interested in this genre.

this cd is not the best selection of sabbath songs, but there are some excellent tracks on here. this cd got me into black sabbath and ozzy (the only singer on the cd), and guitar playing. i recommend this cd to everyone  as these 4 musicians made metal what it is today.
beautiful music. haven stopped listening since i bought it a month ago.
one of my favorite cds. filled with anointed songs. play it all the time in the car. fast shipping.
om mani padme hum i know quite well. this cd has no association to this incredible music. the chants in this cd are scarey. i am not too happy with this.

i cannot find the words to say how i feel about this c.d... it's that bad. lolly cannot sing at all just whine. you may think that big boys don't cry but i guarantee you they will when they hear this ugly c.d. the music is  childish, stupid and the lyrics are horrendous. one of the songs goes like  "oh mickey your so fine, you blow my mind..." and some other  rubbish. i recommend that you don't buy this c.d ever! (you'll thank me  later!) save your money for buying an album by a talented singer like joe  or avant. much love to you if you can bear the first 3 seconds of lolly's  pathetic "my first album"! i'm not that patient!
sounds great! my husband was thrilled at just how good this sounded.

the first and probably only vision divine cd you need in your power metal collection.  the band features many of italy's best talent from the late 90's.  fabio lione gives a very good vocal performance here.  the guitars and production are well done and professional.  the music is more powerful and direct then some latter releases.  i find this release to be more memorable and enjoyable to listen to even after all of these years.
returned, was not my style of music.

this is one of the best big band remakes i have heard. sounds just like the original orchestras must have sounded live.  most cds of the big bands are just old recordings with poor quality sound. but this is the best!!  great addition to any collection. wish this orchestra had more cds.

without doubt giornovichi is the greatest composer i have discovered in 2015. this music is captivating as well as scintillating and one can almost imagine sparks emanating from the violin. if you like the mozart violin concerti, you will love giornovichi's more.

don't waste money on this. there is no passion in the singers, sounds like they are in a studio or something, not even running. i realize that the cadences need to be toned down for the public (ie: no swearing etc) but the  titles included in this set are lame and as unmotivated as the singers are.  check out some other titles like marine recon cadences, or even some army  ranger sets.

i like this album a lot, but i heard some of the new ep on a certain unspecified file sharing site, and my god, it is so much better than the brittle stars. i mean it's short cause it's an ep but it's really good. buy this, but defintiely buy the new stuff when it comes out.

having been an austinite for the past 4 years, i have become fairly familiar with the music of hidden speaker.  in their hometown of austin they carry a faithfull following to their very exciting shows.  i must say  i agree with my fellow reviewers that this album is excellent and is  unmatched in execution in the emerging genre of indie-pop-rock, but being a  loyal local fan i must correct another fan is his mistakes.  they are not a  band called a the brittle stars, but rather a band called hidden speaker,  and they were not formerly catch-22 but the springhill mine disaster.  that  cleared up go pick up this great band's great album.

interesting to see that viletones have released stuart harrisons song nailed, without his permission and without paying any royalties - so much for being a mate.,, completely santized version btw leckie

was this cd supposed to be intentionally funny? because i haven't laughed this hard since i used to listen to monty pyhton records.  it's quite clear that it's not supposed to be funny.  oh, well, i laughed anyway at the affected theatrics of mr. scudieri.  it should be filed under comedy.

spirit of the canyon is the kind of music you can play over and over again, never get tired of it, and hear something new. i listen to this music, alternating with david and dianne's other albums, several times a week while riding. one of my horses is so enchanted with this album that she stops next to the cd player and nudges me to put the cd in before she will enter the arena. why this album has not received more attention can only be that people have not yet discovered it. once you listen to this, you will want to buy all of their albums. i started with david arkenstone's celtic book of days and have ended up with all of dianne's and david's albums. spirit of the canyon is a blend of native america flutes and earth beats with a bit of celtic overtones. you can feel the warm canyon breeze, imagine the clouds floating buy and sense the vibrant colors of the soil as you listen to this album.

muchas gracias, fr stan fortuna. i hope everyone who listens to your songs will be taken to an elevated plane where heaven is. i particularly like the cd title track eternity, almost as though it was given a hint of heavenly inspiration that stan fortuna, cfr alone can translate. i am very inspired by listening to this cd (i have three others and this one is better than the rest i have!) and i am transported always by fr stan's love for jesus christ and his genius for music that is loved by him.

attila, being one of the greatest metal vocalists in my opinion, must have been kidnapped and drugged to do this sophmore release from tormentor. it is stupid, sloppy, psuedo-progressive garbage with very little worth or any similarity to what the black metal community knows of the true tormentor. 95% of the time, they are trying to plagarize italy's root while falling flat on their faces at the time. steer clear of this one boys and girls, and you might be a happier individual.

this "summer" release is the second of four planned cd-singles by monday michiru in conjuction with the change in seasons.  as on the "spring" single new beginnings, monday michiru has seemingly entered a new phase.  her previous melting-pot "acid-jazz" approach has morphed into what can  most easily be described as being "acoustic" jazz, albeit with a percussive  latin-flavored rhythmic foundation...optimista one year later! mysteries  of life runs 14 minutes, allowing the track to build slowly but  hypnotically. beginning with impressionistic piano, the track moves into a  syncopated jazz/funk groove with thought-provoking lyrics and a restrained  yet emotive vocal, and finishes with an extended instrumental coda with  scat singing, piano, and percussion solos.  the disco-like trance provides  a subtler indication of monday michiru's chronic eclectism. the  7-minute inspiration is a calm acoustic jazz ballad with a tasteful large  ensemble accompiament, possibly by the mingus big band (although there's no  personnel listed).  the 12-minute title track develops over an afro-latin  beat...more sophistication with a deeply soulful delivery, and ending with  a percussion/vocal jam. the first edition comes with a one-track bonus  cd, featuring monday michiru's version of the beegees' how deep is your  love.  it's a solid updating of the original, but not in the same league as  disc one (clearly it's meant to be a stand-alone cut).

the second all i ask disc brings rae & christian closer to brazil, particularly with the b-side, "the bacalau," which proves you can never have too much cowbell. it's a spare and sultry affair. but the "old english mix" of the title track brings a slinky, sly groove that lends a sensuousness. well worth checking out!

this disc is good, groin-grabbingly good.  it's got the kind of high quality mope rock that all of the flavor-of-the-month dandies of the indie scene wish they muster during their guest appearances on "the o.c." and "mtv college tv news."  it's got bass, it's got cacophony contrasted against big harmonies that manage to be catchy without being dumbed down.  as a means of comparison, overlord sounds kind of like the magnetic fields or the smiths, but definitely distinct.  for me, the highlights are "warm body" (which i heard on npr's open mic thing) and "landlubber," but i could listen to the whole disc, which is way more than i can say about a lot of cd's i've bought lately.  anyway, get into overlord before they get snatched by some big label and sell out and start having guest spots from ben folds.  this disc rocks (and i don't even feel self-conscious saying that)!
4 songs, not exactly worth it.

the follow up to 1998's 'all saints' album - the girls have really improved. you won't find a ballad on this cd i can tell you. but a lot of uptempo r&b sounds. you already know the hits 'pure shores' & 'black coffee' and may be thinking that they are the only good songs on the album - wrong! 'love is love' sounds like a jennifer lopez track which has a bucket full of attitude. 'all hooked up' is a raunchy number that may remind you of 'bootie call' but alot better. all the girls get to have sing on this album including melanie on 'ha ha' and natalie on 'dreams'. the most popular song on the album would have to be 'whoopin over you' which is a dance floor classic. the track shoul've been released as a single because its got all saints written all over it.
his best that i've heard so far! heartfelt, melodic, inspiring, i had the pleasure of seeing him in person years ago in sedona, amazing artist!

in 1977 i was in college listening to station kre berkeley and they played the whole dune side of this album, i stopped studying, sat up and listened - wow!  a few more plays and i bought it on vinyl - which i still have. i have never heard of dave matthews (the radio station never said much about him), had never seen anything before nor since from him (kept getting that other dave matthews). thank god for the internet i now know who he is (was), but i would like to know how he got such a all star band together, even those who were not under contract under cti.  the dune side just blows me away still, and like the other reviewer i never read the book until i heard the album, listening to the late gary king's roving bass solos on "sandworms" while reading about the huge giants of the desert just fit! (for those of know who the celestials are from marvel comics - sandworms is the perfect background music for them.)  i could never get into the other side. the original star wars was hot during the 70's and everybody was doing their own version of the star wars themes, so i never like that side.  however the dune side was more then worth the price - i am glad to review this, as in my travels i only met one other person who had this album.  when the movie finally came out years later (god it was horrible) i was thinking "they could've used the dave matthews track as i believed he caught the essence of the book!"

this is the most played christian cd i own..even though it is geared for kids, parents will love it as well.  if you're thinking about getting this cd for your kids, just do it, you won't be disappointed.  as far as i'm concerned, it's the best one on the market.  my four-year-old son listens, sings along and dances to it everyday, and falls asleep to it every night.  the worship music is very upbeat and fun along with some slower songs that are sweet and heartfelt.  i highly recommend this cd!!

svartahrid is a very late addition to the norwegian black metal scene with its first demo in 1998 and debut album in the following year.  they don't have much of a following, so if youve found your way here, chances are you're the type who thrives on the discovery of new black metal bands.  if i was to take a shot at why this band doesnt have a greater popularity, it is this:  svarahrid sounds like a black metal band just going through the motions.  nothing is really accented on as the sunrise flickers.  theres no way i would ever truly listen to this when i know i have something like immortal i can just put on, or another one of the really great bands.  the vocals don't ever step into the spotlight.  come to think of it, no one is really stepping into the spotlight or doing anything that really impresses me.  a lot of bands use the typical norwegian black metal riff.  i don't hear that at all here.  and a lot of the bands from other countries find something else great to do if they choose not to use that riff.  i can find some upsides.  the guitars play a nice harmony/melody.  and thats it.  the album as a whole is what i appropriately term exceptionally mediocre.  there just isn't anything that makes me want to hear this.  frozen shadows is an example of a band i yearn to listen to when this cd is over  a band with a lot of different layers to their music, a lot of different pace/pitch changes within a song.  the production doesnt allow for a lot of variation.  svartahrid doesnt really take any leaps that you look for in black metal bands as you look for the latest innovative thing for a band to do.  i, for one, like to see that one thing that a band does to make it stick out in the crowd.  all in all, a considerably unnecessary black metal album.  bands that released one 17-minute demo and called it a career have more to extract than svartahrid.
took a long time to get it but it was alright
how could irene cara herself take part in this "duet"? she probably needed the money....dj bobo is horrible and ruins the song

mediocre or poor sound from an assortment of live recordings (including artifacts from other recordings that were recorded over) ultimately cannot mask marvin's impassioned playing.  mr marvin prepared his own edition of soler's works, and he spent decades performing them, and it shows.  on par with larrocha or anyone else.

absolutely awesome trance song, although the wackside mix has a disco-esque flavor. the airheadz created this tune after hearing eminem's "stan" (and thus reworking dido's lyrics to "thank you"). perfect,catchy rhythms for a night of crazed partying with badger fans!!!

it only took one time of listening to jane marie's "gypsy cowgirl" to know that there is a true talent here with a lot of versatility.  her showmanship comes through with each song.  in "manitou moon" you can hear her inner soul being expressed.  her gypsy, free spirit sounds real which makes each song easy to listen to and identify with.  in "right as rain" she explores finding true love and the excitement felt when this happens.  you can identify with real life experiences through jane marie's music making this cd a keepsake.  it's highly recommended to anyone who enjoys good music.

a masterpiece of creamy goodness from young ginger baker, jack bruce and eric clapton.  iconic great performances show why these performers became legendary. also the japanese vendor held true to delivering a good condition used disk, securely packaged and on time.
taking me back my cool kats day

i ordered this cd thinking it was a soundtrack from the movie of the same name.. not so... a japanese import with one song from the movie... save your yen.... not worth the trouble... very miss leading.....

this is an impressive digital remastering of 50 year old high quality recordings of the the maestro playing his own compositions. when played through a high quality system you get depth of overtones and dynamic range not normally associated with recordings originally done in that era. think dsd quality.  in order to get the full sound you have to order the 2-cd set from japan. amazon has converted some of these tracks into mp3. even the mp3's  streaming sound fairly good,  but the quality is not as good as the 20-bit cd played through a decent sound system.  this 2-cd set is a very joyful compilation of piano music  interpreted through the caribbean-trained ear and mind and played with gifted hands of a composer who can play for us his own unique creations. ernesto thus manages to give even spanish flamenco music a unique cuban rythm.  considering that lecuona was composing some of these pieces and performing them in a concert hall gig in nyc over a hundred years ago, the music captured by these cd's achieve a time warp. you are transported to a wwii era concert hall with the composer showing us how his music plays and feels.  note: the author of this review grew up in a (1950's havana) home with a piano-playing mom where lecuona piano music was always resonating. at that time and place, lecuona music was also a staple of tv and radio station broadcasts. think of piano music reproduced through the single 4" speaker in a 1956  ford am radio.   i can tell you ernesto lecuona has never sounded this good.

a nice addition to the music collections of metal fans everywhere.  a rarity that is like a cherry on top of your sundae.  i know no other band that is like killing joke.  their style is welcome in my book.  i cannot comment on their other albums because i don't own them, but pandemonium is killer good.  this is the newer version with a couple extra tracks.  buy it!

marina is an astounding musician.  her words can be both heartwarming and piercing, her skills as a pianist are nearly unmatched, and partnered with her co-writer nick baker they can do no wrong.  i agree with the review above - a must for any cd collection!

live or in the studio lourds is a lustrous and little-known gem of the contemporary rock scene and this cd serves as a worthy showcase.  the range displayed here, from heartfelt ballads to tongue-in-cheek philosophizing to kick-ass rock 'n' roll - often in the same song - is as impressive as it is thoroughly enjoyable.  this is that rare cd, a full-length effort in which all songs are strong, an album you fall in love with on the first listening and keep turning to long after you've memorized the lyrics and calculated what it might cost to buy an electric violin and a distortion pedal and try your hand at her cool riffs. i don't know if the fact that you can still catch lourds playing intimate new york rock clubs where you can walk right up to the stage, rather than impersonal stadiums where binoculars are de rigueur, is proof that there is a god or proof that the universe is entirely random.  but in any event, the cost of this cd is a small price to pay for what you get, one of the best hours of music recorded in recent years and a powerful piece of evidence that the real creativity in popular music these days is taking place outside the purview of the major labels.

this is a great cd for the 4th or any patriotic holiday or celebration.  update: i played this cd at top volume during a 4th of july boat parade and between it, the decorations and putting a recently retired air force sgt on the upper deck we won the contest hands down, beating a long standing yearly winner. of course the 125 decibel air horn blasts at the right times and the requests of other boats didn't hurt either.

i did not realize my error until i retraced my order. i did not want, song of the marines. i thought i was ordering the music of the marines. the cd was part of a tribute to my marine corps vietnam veteran husband who is currently in a nursing home.... due to agent orange.  that is what i get for not double checking myself.  the cd is fine it is just alot of music that he did not recognize.  so sad as it was for an early acknowledgment of the marine corps birthday. he is fiercely proud of the corps and all his military brothers. thank you for this chance to state my view.

multifaceted depth with enough rhythm to push a train.  sinister, evocative moods that play right through you... beautiful, forceful...  kenny g's evil twin on steroids... play this loud in your car and you will get arrested for speeding!
very sad occasion, but great live music.

because this cd left me begging for more!  i got this cd not knowing what to expect, and got an incredible musical work that is at the same time a biting commentary on the world of suffering artistic types and a touching reminder of what it is to truly love a family. i cannot pick a favorite song, because all of them speak their own message, and i'm still finding treasures after two months!  this is a work of amazing musicianship, great singing, and wonderful arrangements.  you won't regret this one!

i've seen them play several times, and these guys are awesome!  i love this album.  it's hard to find bands like this in hawaii.  our choices are pretty slim.  so buy this album!  i got mine on ali'i drive after one of their shows.  one blue eye is good too.  buy that too.

johann jacob froberger was one of the great pioneers of baroque keyboard music, his influence extending to bach and beyond. unlike the more exuberant and capricious style of the french keyboard school which was beginning to develop during his time, it is the gravity and austerity of his music which are its most striking qualities, at least to my ear. bob van asperen's systematic froberger survey, covering several cd sets of which this is the second volume, is not only superbly organised and produced, but is also a delight to the ear. on the first disc of the present two-cd set we have the six suites of the libro secondo, and the second disc brings us five more suites from manuscript and other unpublished sources. they mostly consist of allemand, courant and saraband, in some cases also with a gigue. it is the saraband movements that are the most affecting for me - profoundly contemplative, graceful and dignified music, beautifully played here by van asperen on a superb-sounding couchet-blanchet-taskin harpsichord from kenneth gilbert's collection. at the end of the first cd the partita "auf die mayerin", variations based on a cheerful traditional melody whose title is not explained here and its origin perhaps not known, is an especially attractive work - with, once again, the sarabande standing out. at the start of the second cd is the noble suite xviii, its allemande dedicated to madame sibylla, duchess of württemberg, froberger's great friend and patroness, and giving the cd set its title. all this music is superbly played by bob van asperen with energy, insight and immaculate technique; his style seems to suit froberger's music to perfection - and vice versa. the sound of the instrument is also beautifully captured in the recording and, to cap it all, the booklet is splendidly produced and illustrated and the player's own booklet notes are detailed and fascinating. altogether, this is a very strong recommendation for all baroque enthusiasts, especially if you are serious about making a substantial collection of froberger's music; its companion discs in the same series, especially volume 3 "hommage à l'empereur" (hommage a l'empereur, vol. 3 (2cd), are also highly recommended.

i first heard this being played over the audio system in a shop in sedona az when i was visiting from the uk and brought a copy of the cd back to england with me. anyone who loves the guitar knows that you can play perfectly and still be missin something, not a chance with "the sons of cisco", this music is played with a sense of pleasure that carries thro to the listener and brings these old classics to a new level. i would rate this as the most inspiring set of recordings i have heard for many years, hell it even made me blow the dust off of my old guitar. easy listening for all but something special for enthusiasts of this genere of music. thanks frank and the boys.

this was a big disappointment.  the organ at la madeleine is one of my favorites in paris, and music from nicolas de grigny is one of my favorite pieces for organ.  i'm not sure if it was the recording but it seemed like the choices of stops was never favorable for the music at issue, no matter who the composer.  that would seem to be an organist issue.  anyway, i would not recommend this cd to anybody really interested in good organ.  for recordings at the madeleine, the ones by the current organist there (francois-henri houbart) are better.  when i was 20 years old ((1959), i happened to hear jeanne demessieux one sunday at the last mass at the madeleine.  wow, she was brilliant.

i very much enjoyed this album, especially for the snow-storm works, of which i had only one of the sections on an older russian music compilation album.  and, as a result of finding the album, i also got to enjoy the russian choral music of pushkin's garland, which, while not normally my usual musical interest, i found very enjoyable, too.

i accidentally met kylie in paris about ten years ago and she told me: "you're from canada? i didn't even know i had fans left in north america! thanks for recognizing me." fast-forward to 2001, with "can't get you out of my head", kylie minogue had a second chance at fame in north america. the single sold over four million units worldwide and made its way in the top 10 in both canada and the united states. the single was lifted from "fever", kylie's most successful album ever. in my opinion, "body language" is to kylie what "around the world in a day" (atwiad) was to prince: the hugely anticipated follow-up album. after purple rain, it seemed prince could do everything right but the cryptic religious imagery of atwiad proved to be too much for even his fans. the album was a hard one to love. in 2001, it seemed kylie could do anything at all. to north americans, she was exotic, a taste of foreign glamour and to british and europeans she was uber-sexy and back on top, where she belongs. her fever tour was a sell-out and her lingerie line was selling like hot cakes. enters body language! the first alarm went off when "slow" was released in the uk in november. it made it to number one but it was the slowest selling number one of all time! minimalist minogue was not as popular as projected. much like post-purple rain prince, kylie is trying to move away from fever. she might eventually release her "graffiti bridge", but for now, fans around the world should regale themselves with body language, a jewel of an album. it's official kylie's gone french-o-lic! you won't mind, it's all very refreshing. most of her fans won't even notice how she looks just like brigitte bardot on both the covers of the first single `slow' and the album. but you will! most people will notice that kylie jumped on the electro-pop van, how very french of her (air anybody). if there's something french can't be accused of it is of a lack of sophistication. body language is sophisticated, it's elegant, it's produced with quality in mind. dare i say it's a bit blend...sure, it will surprise you, it's not as pop as you'd like, it doesn't have a standout single and the songs can seem similar at times. at first, it'll take you aback. then, you'll put "fever" on and reminisce about pop-kylie. a couple of days will go by and you'll pop body language in again. chocolate will stick with you for hours: "if love were liquid it would drown you, if love were human it would know me". slow will hypnotise you and red blooded woman will teach you new expressions, namely freaking around! body language is kylie's ninth studio album and arguably her best. the canadian and american version is even better as it is full of extras. two excellent bonus tracks, the r&b infused cruise control and the mellow you make me feel; the slow video in all its glory. odds are you won't see the video on much music or mtv so here's your chance; the making-of for the slow video (very interesting to see how nice and genuine kylie is in almost real life) live performance of can't get you out of my head from kylie's exclusive money can't buy show in london. it seems that with body language, kylie is trying to push the envelop and mess with the formula that put her back on top of the charts. pop-kylie has evolved. did anybody want pop-kylie to evolve? after hearing body language, you'll be saying yes!

i just purchased the songs for worship - tranquility and none of the songs on the 2 cds are anywhere near what they say they are.  the songs are nice but not what you would expect.  in fact, the first cd shows it is "all creation worships" disc 1 and the second cd shows "holy ground" disc 1.  for a $6.99 cd it's not worth the time or money to return the cd, but i am disappointed not to have received what i paid for.

that's the only explanation i've come up with to solve one of two mysteries surrounding this cd, namely: why on earth aren't these songs performed at indulgers shows?  i waited for several months to get this cd (can't complain i suppose, it is out of print and was hand-delivered by mr. promise himself), and i have to say it was worth the wait. i like the indulgers, but "a matter of indulgence" is really something else. listening to the cover of "freebird" and "sail away" (off of other cds) in concert gives only a hint of what damien is capable of, and this cd shows a different, more romantic side. "crystal's eyes," for example, is the equivalent of paul mccartney's "maybe i'm amazed," and "soldier of fortune" is one of the better irish-themed songs out there. mike nile plays the bass, which doesn't often happen these days, and it's a shame because he's one of the better bass players out there. i wonder what it would have sounded like if the other indulgers had played on the cd, but the difference isn't necessarily a bad thing.  i suggest a letter-writing campaign until he agrees to sing this stuff in concert again.  the other mystery is why he'd put out a cd full of irish ballads, take a cover photo in the guinness brewery, and then adopt an anglicized stage name. he's thankfully reverted back since.
such cool unique sound really like it and great messages too....so anyways if you like new type style music in christian

terribly underrated and nearly forgotten, the heights of abraham's humidity is a classic trip-hop album that never really got its due. and that's a pity, since the band comprises of one half of fila brazillia and vocalist jake harries. "still waiting" is an absolutely gorgeous track, and, to this day, i still sing along with it when i hear it. "sportif" is a wonderfully, bouncy mid-tempo track, while "in the cold" takes us back to romance. "love flows down" becomes an ethereal track, but "10.55" returns things to earth with a humorous spoken word riff on a small town. and the final track, "tides," ebbs and flows like the real thing, if instead of water, you had electro. listen to this album and keep the spirit alive.

i first began buying these (now 7) sets of praise songs in the 1980s on cassette, and have given a handful of sets out as gifts and often listen to them still while driving or mowing or doing other work. i love them because they are, in my experience/opinion, the only set of worship music that truly is encouraging and designed to lead you into worship along with the singers. all others seem to convey a strong tone of entertainment, which i see in many churches unfortunately. the voices are soft enough to not drown out the music or yourself, and yet clearly enunciated for the sole purpose of helping you to join in and sing out loud or in your heart. it's hard to not sing out, though.  the songs are a mix of choruses and traditional hymns, with minimal and meaningful comments between most of them, otherwise one songs leads right into the next. even after listening to these 7 cds/tapes for almost 30 years, just writing this review has made me want to worship with them again.  for listening in loud environments, i suggest using these: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/b00h27e6nq and and loading these songs to your phone or other mp3 player.

i came to hear about joel engle through a focus convention in 2002. focus is an annual convention held by the bsu (baptist student union), which meets on college campuses around the usa. mercy me was scheduled to play there, but they couldn't make it, so joel engle played there instead. i enjoyed his live performance so much that i bought two of the cds he was selling, this being one of them. having heard most of the songs during his performance, i knew much of what to expect, and the rest of the songs were also very good. my favorite songs on this cd are "redeemer", "simple song", "i sing holy", "wonder of your love", "rock of my salvation", and "fountain". most of the songs on this cd are rather slow and easy listening, though "wonder of your love", "simple song" and "rock of my salvation" are more of a moderate tempo, and every song on this cd is great! i can't see any of these songs getting boring quickly, and joel has quickly become one of my favorite contemporary christian artists. it's too bad that not many seem to have heard of him - nobody else in the worship team at my church had until i mentioned him.

if you enjoy small chamber works for violin, the kind sometimes dismissively termed ``salon pieces" but which have graced concert halls since paganini's day in the form of encores, then this disk will be a real treat for you.  all of kogan's warmth and humour, all of his talent and technique, come together on this disk of short encore pieces to dazzling effect. always one on the lookout for little sparks to delight his audiences, kogan apparently had an enormous repertoire of small works he would wheel out in his encores. on this disk, we get a wonderful and varied selection of these pieces. there are no stand out pieces here; every piece is outstanding.  kogan's wonderful tone is stunning, full, front and center. perhaps my only (admittedly minor) complaint about these recordings is that his accompanists are some times a little too distant. in a few places you wish the balance of the recording was more even, especially in the duets for violin and guitar (if the disk wasn't so much fun to listen to, i'd take a star off for this). otherwise, this is an incredibly inexpensive disk that is enjoyable the first time through, but still rewards repeated listenings.

this cd has one of the most fascinating country christmas carols and songs, i have ever heard. i first heard it back in 1997 when i was listening to this on the cassette. now i have the cd and its wonderful to listen to this, no matter what time of the year i may be in. for christmas i always buy new music, and this is an early entry into my collection for 2011.  being an indian, from india, i have grown up listening to country music, since my childhood. my dad was and still is very fascinated with country music and so am i. what more is, my would be wife is from southern united states, and she too loves country music.  this cd is one of my most favorite collection of country music. "silver bells", "santa claus is coming to town", are some of the most amazing music on this cd. "have yourself a merry christmas" and "please come home for christmas" are also some notable ones.  i would say, if anyone loves country music, just like i do, then this should be in their collection. thanks and have a merry christmas 2011. god bless all, and may god bless america.

i am a vietnam vet and the song "armed forces radio" tore me up..."ride to the wall" brought tears to my eyes...the tracks "rolling thunder" and "gotta get outa this place" were heart-wrenching - the whole album is that way...and i gave it 5 stars don't know why it came up 1...

liszt: hungarian rhapsodies i thoroughly enjoy listening to this recording. the performance is accurate to the music, artisticly interpreted, and flawlessly executed. the recording method has produced a very clean, pure sound of the piano which is a pleasure to hear. i would highly recommend this recording to anyone.

this is vic dana at his very best.  it doesn't have all the songs of the complete hits of vic dana (most notably missing are:  i love you drops, a million and one, and if i never knew your name), but it does have two songs that you won't find on that cd.  i bought this cd for his version of softly as i leave you.  it also includes somewhere my love (lara's theme from dr. zhivago) which is also wonderfully done.  this cd was originally released as an album in 1966 on liberty records.  this album was a favorite of my brother and myself and even my mother and grandmother used to come listen to the songs back when we were kids.  below is the track listing:  1. red roses for a blue lady (2:49) 2. moonlight and roses (bring mem'ries of you) (2:50) 3. garden in the rain (2:15) 4. love is all we need (2:24) 5. bring a little sunshine (to my heart) (2:37) 6. shangri-la (2:05) 7. more (2:21) 8. i will (2:40) 9. crystal chandelier (2:56) 10. somewhere, my love (lara's theme from dr. zhivago) (2:36) 11. softly, as i leave you (2:44) 12. little altar boy (3:22)  this is a great cd and the sound is great for recordings of that era.  every song on here is a winner and vic's voice really shines on this cd.  he was definitely at his best with this group of songs.  the cd flows easily from one great song to the next.  every song is enjoyable.  i recommend you buy it while there are still some new and used copies available at a reasonable price.
time-life has the best quality cd's bar none and this is a good example of good music done correctly!
well jason morant is new to me. he has a great voice. his songs touch my soul. give him a chance, you'll be glad you did. i am looking for more of his music. love it, love it, love it.

this collection of guitar music from william elwood and another artist are so soothing! i purchased it because i've had other cds by william ellwood and enjoyed them very much. while each piece is different, they've been chosen to blend very well, one after the other. (there's nothing more jarring when listening to a cd than to have some crashing music after a gentle piece!) i play this music when i'm drawing or painting and it is great to help me let go of stress and get into the beauty of color and design. i think it'd also be good during meditation (which art is for me.)
fantastic relaxing music. i encourage any one to get it who would like a bit of solice and peace for a while.

tim hughes came to many christians' attention when here i am to worship became the most-sung worship song in 2002 and 2003. that entire debut album speaks volumes of how tim hughes is more than a one-song wonder. this follow-up album, when silence falls, puts tim hughes at the top of a growing heap of worship leaders.  the album begins with "beautiful one", a mid-tempo praise song that many churches have put into their repertoire of songs. among my favourite songs is the next one, "you". this one just reminds us of how amazing god is, and how we cannot compare anything or anyone to him! then comes "consuming fire" which meant very little to me until one sleepless night when i realized that my passion for jesus' name had been quenched in recent months. this album continues with a great number of wonderful, introspective songs that lift up the name of jesus, while also challenging listeners to examine their relationships with god. other highlights on this album include "when the tears fall" and "beauty of your peace".  unlike many worship leaders, tim hughes does not seem to write his material to be sung in church, or to be big hits. rather, he writes from his heart, expressing the entire range of emotions beyond his god. i love both his lyrics and the accompanying guitar work. this project goes highly recommended! praise the lord for music like tim hughes' when silence falls!

the slow crack is the title of a steve kilbey cd that is instantly enjoyable. it's loaded with great songs including "fireman", "woman with reason", "this asphalt eden" and the dramatic "like a ghost". steve kilbey is the exemplary and multi-talented lead singer of the church. his solo cd's are haunting, solacing, spiritual and surreal. "the slow crack" would apeal to music fans who like pink floyd's early music and any of stan ridgeway's cd's.  kilbey is a master of pschedelic music that emanates from mystical origins. he's also a great painter, poet, writer and blogger. his "the time being" blog is a must read.

when i cleaned out my fifteen-year-old car for trade-in, i found an old, beat-up "cas-single" of rosco martinez' "neon moonlight/captura me" and, although i could barely recall the tune, decided it had once been worth ordering in the cassette format of the day, so i set about obtaining it on cd or download, to give it a listen. cd was available, d/l was not. when i ordered the cd, i thought i was paying for and getting just the two interpretations on the "cas-single" -- so i was pleasantly surprised to receive a 13-track album of mr. martinez' music, most tracks unknown to me. 'neon moonlight' sparked memories and the other songs are representive works of a very good artist. i thoroughly enjoyed all. there is a sincere passion and longing in this music that is still relevant today.

..is slow but much redeemed by the deeply expressive conducting of tennstedt and singing of popp. it is one of the longer versions of tod and verklarung c.f. szell/sony/cleveland or haitink/rcoa/philips, but it does not drag and the sections leading to its explosions are expertly calibrated. in the four last songs, popp sings incomparably as usual and is irresistible if one loves her voice as much as i do -even more than gundula janowitz and kirsten flagstad comparatively. the only other singers that i can imagine preferring are elisabeth grummer, elly ameling and (if in her range) erna berger, none of whom unfortunately recorded it/them. on disc i have long admired the more quickly paced della casa/bohm set

the duo piano works are a unique corner in the output of arnold bax. though he and york bowen often accompanied student operatic recitals with duo piano arrangements he never pursued the form on his own inspiration. in fact most of his works for solo piano are from his early days and he generally did not pursue a career as a performer. with the exception of moy mell (1916) which he wrote for royal academy friends myra hess and irene scharrer, the other works might have never been written had he not become friends with the piano duo of rae robertson and his wife, ethel bartlett. they needed new material and bax, ever the good friend to those who knew him, happily obliged with all the other works on this disc, composed between 1928 and 1931.  the sonata for two pianos is one of the real highlights of the disc and a major work for duo piano. it is written in bax's own idiom of modernist harmonics and elements of his early impressionist style with a strong influence of debussy. as is usual with bax much of the inspiration comes from nature. the first movement depicts the coming of a rather rambunctious spring, the theme also of works like spring fire. the second movement is a depiction of the sea, another bax specialty, and leads to a finale which is a joyful little dance. it's really a summation of some of the most typical baxian moods.  red autumn is a tone poem much in the mood of november woods, though it stays in the dark palette without november woods luminescent middle section. it's interesting but i think it needed more expansion to leave a more lasting impression. it may be a window into how bax composed his major orchestral tone poems at the piano. in this light, graham parlett did orchestrate it and it had been recorded on chandos by vernon handley.  hardanger is an homage to grieg, one which so soaked in the earlier composers' style that you could describe it as a work grieg might have written had he been an impressionist. grieg's influence is not particularly obvious in most of bax but is very strong in dance in the sunlight, the third of the three pieces for small orchestra.  the two pieces that follow are another highlight of the disc, exploring the dark and more sinister sounds that can be made by the piano. i do not know the origin of the poisoned fountain, whether it is a legend of some sort or bax's original idea. i imagine the latter, since i would trust booklet author lewis foreman to elucidate a written source if there was one. it is a piece of supreme eeriness with a sudden and jarring climax that must have stunned audiences in its day. the devil that tempted st. anthony is a piano depiction of the story of the saint as handed down by bishop athanisius of alexandria. this st, anthony is not the familiar one of padua but the ascetic hermit of the desert in fourth century egypt. it depicts the part where anthony s trapped in a cave with many demons. it reminds me of the darker side of liszt. foreman suggests that the work was inspired by the famous painting by matthias grunewald. i am including a picture of it below.  the disc ends with the early work, moy mell, an irish fantasy from 1916. bax had an extreme affinity for ireland and its legends and visited there frequently in his youth. he was terribly shaken by the disastrous easter rising of 1916 and this was one of several works written soon after that. as such it is a more somber meditation on ireland than one might expect. it's also a window into his more debussy-influenced style of the 1910's which, should you like it can be found in abundance on eric parkin's series of solo piano works on chandos or ashley wass's third volume on naxos.  the playing here by jeremy brown and seta tanyel is as good as i imagine it could be with playing of great feeling. the two pianists always seem as one with each other without any muddled passages. the chandos sound is bright and clear as usual.

my late wife thought she had found a bargain, finding vol. 1 & 2 for only $9.99.  i quickly pointed out that original artists does not mean original recordings.  each of these songs may have an original member of the group singing, but they are not & do not sound anything like the original recordings, with many quite a bit slower than the original.  the only bright spot on this cd is the rerecording of the tremeloes' "silence is golden".  i have to admit that i like this version better than the original.  it is done almost accapella, with a faint organ in the background to keep them on key.  this one song is a must hear.

rebirth is absolutely fantastic.  there was a slight disappointment when i discovered i'd have to pay another 2 dollars to pick up ocean's sky and broken hearted on itunes [they apparently exist on the vietnamese release].  weeks later, i've moved past that...  happy and consequence are both terrific tracks.  those alone practically warrant the purchase of rebirth.  now, i'm usually not one for remixes of mainstream or widely circulating songs in general but the remixes on rebirth work.  they work great.  i can't say if i'd prefer the remixes to the originals or vice versa, but they are most most impressive.  the a dose of you acoustic is also an awesome bonus.  i personally love to hear acoustic versions of songs.  i don't know why.  although, at first it may seem like half of the tracks are just rehashes of previous songs from i never knew, they are well worth a listen.  even if you are the kind of person that feels like remixes can't make a complete album, the new material easily makes up for anything you may feel you have "already heard."  bottom line:  for the fans, i don't see why you haven't already purchased rebirth via itunes or cd.  if you liked i never knew, i'm confident you'll find rebirth well worth checking out.  i never really know how to give recommendations for newcomers, but i play rebirth fairly often and pretty loud in my dorm and i don't get any complaints.  kristine sa's like something you've never heard before, so no guarantees on matching your style, but in any case, you can always listen to samples from [...]

it is out of this world! i have several recordings from many gipsy and classical violinists but nothing like joszef lendvay! he, as all genial violin virtuoses, makes you think that is easy playing that way, but hardly with so much feeling, some kind of lament in the more sustained notes that only slavonic violinists can exprime. the recording is very good, but the interpretation is wonderfull! this cd is made in south korea and is the only one i could find in the internet, but there are few videos of lendvay at youtube.com, they are unbelievable! everybody who liked lendvay will surely enjoy another hungarian violinist called roby lakatos. is another slavonic genius, relative from the violnist who inspired johannes brahms to compose the ungarian dances. i bought all cds i could find, but the most beautiful is "roby lakatos (and his ensemble play...)". finally, i can say that lendvay, lakatos and vengerov play the most beautiful ksardas ever recorded. i wish i could help. paulo vitor petruzzelli

morton downey, jr. was a controversial and influential american television talk show host of the 1980s who pioneered the "trash talk show" format.  he rose to fame in 1986 when his program featured screaming matches between downey, his guests, and his audience members.  he released this album in 1989.  it features songs based on his conservative persona, written by david lloyd (who?).  most of the songs are performed in a country music style, with a few of them having a jimmy buffett flavor to them.  most songs are about things that make mort mad; greedy doctors, drug dealers, yuppies, crooked politicians, greedy lawyers, prostitutes, pollution.  david lloyd sings the song "blue collar king", which is about mort himself.  "zip it" is a terrible novelty song based on mort's catch phrase.  morton downey, jr. could sing a little, but he was no morton downey, sr. (mort sr. was a fairly popular irish tenor from the 1920s to the 1940s.).  this is a terrible album that should be avoided at all costs, unless you want to have some laughs at how bad it is.

journey is not an ordinary collection of songs. it consists of just one composition, in which russian and bulgarian traditions are blended together in a surprising new way. musical director mikhail alperin combined four folksongs from both russia and bulgaria, which each have their own story to tell. still, together they sound as one.  two of the folk songs ("travelling tartars" from russia, and "i was fooling the turkish" from bulgaria) form the main theme of this 35-minute composition. they are repeated throughout. the repetition combined with the intense sound of both russian vocalist sergey starostin and four bulgarian female vocalists gives journey a strong, meditative quality. it is folk music in it's most pure form - no instruments, just deeply felt stories being told.  the result is not just music to listen to, it is music to 'be' in. mikhail alperin explains: "when you listen to these songs they slowly become part of your whole being. the repetition pulls you into the music. i think all folk music in the world has this strong, meditative base. it has to do with the basic needs of folk people. they have a strong connection with nature. meditation in the form of prayer - for sun or rain - is part of peasant life. singing repetitive songs also helps them relax after a physical job; it brings them into a trance. they tell stories as part of their cultural tradition, using a meditative, musical basis.  journey was recorded at greyfriars kirk in edinburgh during the edinburgh festival 1999

some of the earliest pieces of christian music are the various kinds of chant. these hearken back to synagogue singing; there were various kinds of chant, including gregorian, old roman, mozarabic, cistercian and anglican chant. these tend toward the monophonic, singing with a single 'tune' or lone. they are generally without regular beats or set meters. of the different kinds of chant, gregorian is the most famous and popular. when the monks of the monastery of santo domingo de silos topped the charts in the 1990s, there was a flood on the market of the chant, chansons, motets, polyphony and all sorts of other kinds of music.  much of what people took for being 'chant' was not in fact chant at all. however, this disc is pure gregorian chant.  unlike the earlier 'chant' cds (three volumes), this one is not done by the monks of the monastery of santo domingo de silos, but rather by a choral group, schola cantorum of cologne, in germany, under the direction of gabriel maria steinschulte.  there is a difference in tone and feel to this disc; for one thing, the background tone and reverb sounds a bit different.  this was a live recording in st. martin church in cologne, but there is still a bit more of a 'studio' feel to this album.  in some ways, the recording quality is a bit better at times because of this, but one does miss the authenticity of monks whose chant is a daily spiritual practice, rather than a performance.  according to scholar patrick kavanaugh, 'there are no parallels to chant in the history of music in terms of its longevity, importance or influence.' chant is generally without regular beats or meters, so different communities will develop their own sense of the chant. chant can be designated as syllabic or melismatic, meaning that each note will be a different syllable for the former, or extended melodies on the same syllable for the later. most of what is commonly understood as chant is melismatic, and that is what is represented here on this disc.  the chants here are all fairly standard pieces, with magnificat, alleluia, introit, offertory, psalms and responsory settings, including one hymn (hostis herodes impie).  they are selected with ideas of light and advent in mind - in the packaging of the cd, the advent of the millennium, whereas in the chants, they are looking for the light of christ and the advent of the christ child.  this isn't quite the same as the discs by the monks of the monastery of santo domingo de silos, but it is still a wonderful recording.

if you are reading this review and the picture and description of the item being reviewed appears to be an album of spanish art songs rather than selections from "le nozze di figaro" from the metropolitan opera, it is because (although i have reported the mix up twice)the staff at amazon continues to say "no corrections are needed." brilliant!  the "great operas at the met" is a series of  recordings, each highlighting a particular opera, published by the metropolitan opera in conjunction with rca/bmg.  each boxed set has 2 cd's containing excerpts from the opera as sung by artists who sang the particular role at the met. the first cd consists of older excerpts from the earlier part of the xxth century and the second cd has selections from more recent productions. there is also a small booklet of around 70 pages containing a short essay on the history of the opera as produced at the met, very short synopses of the scenes, texts of the excerpts with translations, and around 50 photographs of the singers and sets from the productions.  i have posted an image of the back of the box, showing the selections and artists, on the "customer image" selection in the upper left hand corner.  all of the selections are in good sound (i would guess that the earlier ones have been lightly filtered.), and the artists, representing the premier singers of their era, range from very good to great.  if you are familiar with historical opera, you do not need any recommendations for singers like farrar, scotti, de luca, pinza, baccaloni, steber, tajo, de los angeles, siepi and della casa.  if you have not heard the earlier singers, this series is an excellent and relatively inexpensive introduction to them, and i recommend that you give it a hearing - you will not be disappointed.
