and this year's crud-fest winner, the person who received the most votes from every brain-dead glossy eyed plankton watching ..... who even cares anymore?  yet another drone pulled off the production line, this gimp being another in the long run of inoffensive handsome white boys, aimed primarily at stupid people and, judging by the popularity of this single, there are an awful, awful lot of.  so let's talk about the single. with the exception of the excrement that was last years winner (steve brookstein, currently missing in action - yet another one-hit wonder who we'll never see again) first (and only) solo attempt - the dire phil collins cover, this is easily the worst actual attempt at a song yet.  originally planned for westlife, "that's my goal" was panned and rejected by them (them! westlife!) for being too weak, but it sure wasn't weak enough for shayne ward, currently number one for the fourth week running as i type this.  but what does that mean, exactly? i'll tell you - nothing. the general public are such idiots, such pathetic, "tell us what to buy and we will" easily led cretins, that they would buy anything after seeing it on a reality program. shayne ward could have released a record of him whistling the marmite theme and it would have gone straight to number one.  and it's going to continue, isn't it? this was a massive hit, the show was a massive hit, so we're going to continue to be bombarded with bland, generic singers and pointless songs like this. if you bought this junk, or if you watched this junk, the curmudgeon holds you personally responsible. you should be ashamed of yourself for bringing yourself down to the gutter masses, watching this easily-digestible pond-life program, and buying its cynical, disgusting products.  one day, i hope to live in a world where television is not swamped by reality television, where tv schedules and budgets are not ruled by programs aimed at the great unwashed, where the charts are not in the vice-like grasp of dire tv talent show winners (and losers). that, ladies and gentlemen, that, is my goal.  the_curmudgeon_hates_you@yahoo.co.uk

ahhh!!  a very pleasant excursion, even if there is "no destination." in the sea of keyboard players out there, how can you say that one person plays in a style that is truly unique? hubert koop indeed does something unique. on some cd's, the prevalence of any one instrument can drag down the whole effort, but not here.  koop is a personal "circus of sound" who constantly surprises and delights.  there is, i must warn, one painful moment:  "long tall dorothe."  i just had to wonder how the lead vocalist could emit such painful falsetto sounds on this one otherwise excellent tune, when he did such a good job elsewhere on the cd. someone cover it please!! - is it too late for the tremeloes to take a stab at it?  another caveat - the singer is german and his english is heavily accented but, with the exception of "dorothe," i found him to be quite listenable.  not surprisingly, they do a version (actually two) of the four seasons "sherrie baby" but, fear not, they don't sound like klaus nomi would if he tried the same thing.

if i could choose the time and place of my own death, i would pick a shonen knife concert. maybe towards the end while they're bashing away through cobra versus mongoose. naoko sounds great here. etsuko was the fiercest drummer they ever had. and atsuko......well.....apart from being badass in every sense of the word, she has incredible stage presence. she's pure joy. i'm kinda in love with her. perhaps i will meet my demise by electrocution from suddenly getting caught between her and naoko as they head bang their way through antonio baka guy. there will be a smile on my face as the lifeblood drains out of me and my soul flies to a better place where there's cotton candy clouds, concrete animals, froot loop dreams, deer parks, bbq parties, and a very big big big cat.

this was the 2nd-to-last show for up with people, the international non-profit educational organization, before ceasing operations in 2000.  the group re-started in 2005, working with a program called worldsmart, but at the time did not use a musical show to travel the world...in 2006, the group returned to its musical roots and incorporated songs old and new.  up with people started in 1965(including acclaimed actress glenn close) and had a 35 year run, as well as producing dozens of cds from their shows.  their famed concerts were  internationally known, from 4 superbowl half-time appearances, as well as performances for many dignitaries like pope john paul, several presidents and supporters like bob hope, anthony quinn and john wayne.  while the music was changed every 2 years from 1971 on, in its last decade, the songs supported a themed "plot".  all types of music comprise the show, and "roads" was no different- from the exciting opening song "ayiko"(which, in japanese, means "come together") to the main theme "where the roads come together"(which remains amongst the alumni as one of the most beloved songs ever written for the group), the music will keep you bouncing, and the spirit of this musical will encourage you with a positive spirit.  a talented group of up with people alumni was recruited to record this album, and you'll find yourself listening to this music over and over!

over time, various mystics (such as therese neumann, the bavarian stigmatic) have claimed to see the events of good friday. after all, its the most famous death in history (in his decline of the west, spengler claimed that the johannine confrontation between pilate and jc is the height of dramaturgy). being a semi-bonkers catholic mystic myself, i had been hoping that liszts via crucis (s 53) would enhance my second sight like boosters on the space-shuttle. it was not to be. if any vista comes into view, its the gehenna of good intentions and nineteenth century piety. it begs the question: is this the most boring music ever written? i can understand what liszt is trying to do: compose a passion that could be performed by a well-endowed parish (indeed, this intention is broadcast in station vi which explicitly quotes the main chorus from the matthew passion). even so, i cannot detect a skerrick of inspiration in these glorified dirges. and yes virginia there are fourteen of them. god almighty, he who understands all things, must grasp this work. i dont. having drunk the devils beer, perhaps liszt was compelled to compose this atrocity to discharge his debt. its eminently successful in one sense: one suffers like jesus did not from thorns, beatings and nails but from sheer monotony. those poor devils in the philippines who grace the news bulletins every good friday would be better advised to ditch the self-crucifixions and load up on this disc: the end-game differs not. as expected, the philips recording is excellent. one cannot impugn the dedication or musicianship of the participants. i trust that they recovered from this trial. i close on a minatory note. it has come to my attention that an american-based operative of the australian knappertsbusch association has exported a copy of liszt: christus to the penal colonies. what is a man to do? "o lord, allow this cup to pass - i cnbf-ed!"

the beach boys tracks here are ones that the group recorded before they signed with capitol records in 1962. none of them were hits; in fact, half of them weren't originally released at all. the ones that were released are "surfin'," "luau," "barbie," and "what is a young girl made of." the former two tracks were released as the group's first single; the latter two were released under the name of "kenny and the cadets."  "surfin'" was included on the group's first album, but was sped up for some reason. the group later re-recorded "surfin' safari" and "surfer girl," and those remakes were the versions that were hits for the group. most of the jan & dean tracks are not the hit recordings; they are re-recordings that were made in the late '70s without jan. they can't compare to the hit versions. in fact, although j&d had recorded "little deuce coupe" in the '60s, it wasn't a hit even then. "heart and soul" is the only hit j&d recording here --- not only that, but it's also the only hit recording on this whole cd. not really a terrible cd, i guess, but don't get it looking to find the hits.

i remember this one.  i was a bit excited to see that some of the top of the pop's cd's had made their way towards the usa.  but then after getting this and listening to it, i remembered that i never really liked top of the pop's cds even when i lived in england, and it was nothing but the familiarity that was endearing to me.  a lesson learned too late!  this is one of their 2000 releases, and it features, to its credit (or detriment), the same consistency as its predecessors.  and what is that consistency?  choppy, repetitive, annoyingly optimistic, cheesy and did i mention annoying? dance and pop tracks form the uk and usa circa the mid, second part of 2000.  you have some real doozies here.  but who can put a price on the memories?  i can... and if you spend more than $10 for this, you've spent too much (its out of print and apparently people now use them for beer coasters at 50p - 5 pounds).  artists included that were popular at the time are sisqo, all saints, numerous boy bands from both sides of the ocean, oasis, blink 182, artful dodger, moloko and whatever flavor of the month trance star had a popular cut (in this case, angelic and sonique).  i have to admit, looking back, it is a real bringer of nostalgia.  summer 2000... france edges italy to win euro 2000 (boo!) & alan shearer (some say finally) retires, then a few months later we have the us presidency debacle, and in general the world was different than it is now some four years later which makes me sort of sad in a way.  but the music - that cheesy poppy feel... at least for some it can conjure up innocent memories.  otherwise its one for the pre-teen/teen crowd of the time.  if by some strange dark force, you happen to enjoy the musicianship and singing (i use both terms lightly), then do check out several of the saturated uk compilation markets' unlimited rip-offs, including "now that's what i call music" and... well... the cannibalistic "top of the pops 2000 v. 3" released all of 3 1/2 months later.

the linde consort's performance of the orchestral suites of j s bach is a worthy counterpart to their brandenburg concertos issued a few years earlier. it was more revelatory to me when it came out because i had always thought the suites to be a rather dull collection of leftover movements, with a few scattered warhorses like the air, compared to the titanic brandenburgs. the brandenburgs could survive even soggy orchestral performances although i preferred either lively modern instrument versions or selected period performances. not so the suites. the 70s era recording of the suites by the collegium aureum indicated that the suites required period performance interpretations to sing. however i had to wait for these performances by the linde consort to hear the suites so perfectly in the manner i'm sure that suits them best. the linde consort performs these suites impeccably, spicing controlled exuberance with the occasional heartfelt slow movement. the time flies by and i no longer find the suites tedious or uneven. there is no scratchiness or sour intonation to the playing. the recording is fairly early digital. i would not call the sonics warm but neither is there any digital hardness or graininess. at worst, instrumental textures are slightly opaque. a real winner all around

the title of my review refers to the content of russian romances brilliantly sung by pavel babakov (1946-1994). there are two reasons to own this cd. for the first, the singer here was endowed with a terrific deep bass. opera fans look for voices of this type in vocal archives of 1900-1930s famous basses of the pastfamous basses of the past, vol. 2. here you can enjoy a well comparable profundo voice in a 1990 sound. just imagine that mardones, andresen or frick came to give a recital in your local concert hall - and you will forgive them even if their program consists not of bach or mozart arias but of popular hits. for the second, babakov just owned this repertoire and was able to make some light or sentimental russian songs sound better than they are. to my subjective taste, he is one the three greatest exponents of traditional russian fare among low male voices, along with the legendary bass feodor chaliapin (1873-1938) and the bass-baritone ivan skobtsov (1900-1983). each of them had a special field: chaliapin was especially great in art songs and traditional cantilena songs like `nochenjka' or `luchinushka' feodor chaliapin song book, skobtsov was awesome in folk ballads of the 19th-early 20th century, as `mezh vysokih hlebov' or `raskinulosj more shiroko' ivan skosbstov - russian folk songs, while babakov owned city romances - the poetry of night revels and morning remorse - track 2,( `bubency'), excessive drinking - tracks 6 (`tipsy street'), 9 (`vyjdu na ulicu'), 12 (`vypjem ryumku vodki'), courtship and flirtation - track 4 (`gaj, da troika'), love and betrayal - track 13' (`the reed was rustling'), boldness and desire - track 15 (`korobejniki'). if you at first listening identify the bass with the characters and take him for a russian bear, you will be mistaken: babakov is a very fine singer who just wants you to believe that that he a russian bear. his ability to adjust the timbre to the song's mood is amazing. in `gai da troika' (track 4), the singer's is hoarse, since it is winter and it is the coachman singing about a flirting pair. in the beginning of the `vyjdu na ulicu' (track 9) babakov's is singing the first lines through the clenched teeth, imitating the languor of a country bumpkin longing for girls. in track 6, where a drunkard returning home finds the moon `in a drunk condition' and the street `tipsy', babakov's voice is indeed intoxicating. babakov's voice was very different from chaliapin's (high bass) and skobtsov's (bass-baritone): it was a true basso profundo, yet the low notes were not muffled but sonorous - as with mardones great spanish bass - operatic arias & songs or the british bass robert easton. babakov had a classical training - he graduated from the gnessin school of music - but never belonged to any opera group. this is a pity, since leading soviet theaters in that period lacked basses with his range. if you compare babakov's recording of the romance `bubency' (track 2) with the performance of the acclaimed bass of the kirov/mariinsky theater, boris shtokolov, you will notice that shtokolov's voice wobbles on the long phrases, while babakov doesn't. the low notes of `shumel kamysh' (`the reed was rustling' - track 13) are a plague for an average singer but babakov makes them his visit card. his high register was equally impressive - try the cadence of track 15 (`korobejniki). the jazzy arrangements of russian songs on this cd were made by the conductor, vyacheslav grokhovsky. somewhere they are irritating but in the last song, `korobeiniki' (i.e. `pedlars' or `hawkers') the instrumentation is great: it adds much to the dashing mood of the romance - when the lad and the lass start kissing sax solo begins. in short: great singing and a great voice. recommended.

i bought this cd years ago and it has been one of my favorite christmas treats ever since. as the last reviewer noted, the authentic celtic sounds are a joy to listen to, like a medieval celebration. the contemporary cds that wear the label "celtic" are poor impostors, at best.  i love the music so much that i decided to buy a cd as a christmas gift last year. i didn't know it was out of production. i searched everywhere and found one copy...for $30. i had to pass, but this year several amazon sellers are offering "pre-loved" cds at very reasonable prices. (thank you, sellers.) music doesn't evaporate when the shrink wrap isn't there.  celtic at its authentic finest. it will make your ears smile.

i purchased this for the purpose of a research paper in my graduate music history course.  this was a piece i was focusing on, and was excited to learn of its existance.  the electronic tape recordings were all remastered, and all of the original harpsichord parts were individually recorded. and it all sounds crystal clear.  the 2 tracks at the end with the parts separated is a nice addition.  it also comes with a poster that you have to tape together, and has many interesting entries from those who are still alive and were present at the event.  obviously this recording is only meant to document the event and give you an idea of it, not let you really experience it like it was meant to, and with that in mind, it gets 5 stars from me.  now to go finish my 12 page paper....

***************personnel dave brock - guitar, keyboards, vocals huw lloyd-langton - guitar, vocals harvey bainbridge - keyboards, vocals alan davey - bass guitar, vocals danny thompson - drums lemmy - bass guitar, vocals ("silver machine") dumpy dunnell - guitar ("silver machine")  ***************technical stuff this was recorded for a bbc show called "the friday rock show" at the 1986 reading festival.  the beeb didn't record the whole set and they cut silver machine off early so it would fit in the time slot, so this album is not all of hawk's '86 reading set.  the recording, mixing, and mastering are all good.  so as long as you're ok with live albums, you'll be ok with the sq on this one.  ***************the music 1986 was the height of hawkwinds 80's straight ahead metal phase.  simplistic beats and lots of pointless guitar braggadocio and grandstanding dominate this record.  so the songs pretty much receive a hard rock makeover.  "hassan i sahba" and "assault and battery" suffer the worst from such treatment.  pretty much the whole album is stale motorhead-like riffing.  heck, lemmy even appears as a guest vocalist on "silver machine".  **************summary your attitude towards this record is going to depend on how you feel about the hawk's 80's pop metal phase.  i don't like it, and so i don't like this record.

maria grinberg lived a sad, sad life under the censorship of the then communist regime under stalin. both her father and husband were assasinated for being free thinking intellectuals and her own career was limited to the slavic block countries. there was even a ban on any reviews of her performances. she was not allowed to be televised. but....she was the equal of richter,van cliburn,gillels, and many others of her generation. a huge sound with a huge technique. the final great sweeping melody of the rach 3 reminds me of the composers own performances. not all here is perfection,but this a true great performance as is the schuman. the sound is excellent for its time and being live. this is a must for any fans of the russian piano school. and in a day when we get rather(in my opinion...dont get mad at me) bland performances of wang, lisitsa(sp?) and other technically profficient performers,its wonderful to hear a performance in the grand style we no longer hear...get it!

this must be one of the strangest cover pictures for classical cds: gavrilov with the pilot glasses and worried sideward gaze. for my opinion, this is the stellarest scriabin program out there, including horowitz' and richter's efforts. this is a very fine selection from scriabin's early 48 preludes - 24 selected by gavrilov. these are mostly miniatures, very much in the vein of chopin's op 28. with scriabin, the text can be even more austere compared to the rich chopin items - there are not loads of notes and intimacy dominates. gavrilov starts powerfully with op 13 no 1, a really interesting work, exposing some pianistic bravoura and no 2 following it is a magnificent, fast, mostly quiet flow of notes. the leaflet interestingly says there was a publisher and philantropist belyayev as a sort of supporter for young composer, even by betting about composition timetable. another interesting item is op 11 nos 6 and 8. the leaflet does not explain why gavrilov plays them as a pair - they are on the single cd track as well, but they really seem to form a sort of wholeness, a short, fast octave study and a typical, agony-ridden short piano poem after that. in op 11 no 11 there is more than just a hint of chopin - and positively so, music has more optimistic quality compared to deep, melancholy thoughts nurtured in most preludes. the case with scriabin preludes is very much like with nocturnes by faure - chopin is a sort of starting point but the maturing composer will find his ways in idioms and expanding the genres. op 11 no 14 is a very scriabinesque study, like the heavy-handed no 19. gavrilov use his full command on keyboard - i have always admired his using full scale, whisperings and loud outbursts are his, and 1984 melodiya-emi-supraphon technical co-op shows reasonable results. after preludes, sonata 4 and the famous affannato etude op 42 no 5 completes the program. the second half of the sonata is restless, fast, quiet, loud pianistic feast in andrei's mighty hands. and he is brave enough to challence papa horowitz in etude. i think andrei emphasizes the apollonian side of this piece, for more dionysic view you should grab vladimir. the original cd is worth having, but can be difficult to get. there is a 2 cd rerelease with all scriabin sonates and other works from emi scriabin: piano sonatas 2, 4, 5, 7 & 10 / preludes / etudes. all the preludes of this original cd are included and the 4th sonata, only the etude is left out, but there is op 42 by another pianist in this set. even with the new edition, there seems to be the cover problem, what picture would work with scriabin? mona lisa? kate moss? my choice is kate - she is more modern and could capture the agitation and the uneasy feeling this music is all about.

if one pays careful attention to any of the great artists, one will find simultaneously a loyal devotion to the traditional foundation of their art-form, combined with a fierce desire to build on that foundation with new and innovative inspirations that reflect both the artist's prevailing cultural environment and stimulus, plus the artist's own unique creative genius, without compromising the original integrity of the previous masters' intent and discoveries. this is very difficult to do. there are so many gifted artists who unfortunately lose sight of this and allow their arrogance or insecurities to interfere with their work. as first done by paco de lucia, and recently by vicente amigo among others, now jason mcguire is one of those rare individuals who contribute to the evolution of great tradition. and from texas of all places, to further prove the universality of great music. this debut album is indispensible to all who appreciate the mystery and emotion of flamenco music. from the lilting lullaby in rachel camela (alegrias), to the astonishing solea, suenos de fragua, we witness the great passion of flamenco introduced again in fresh new forms. buy this, listen often and have fun, and let's hope for more soon from this exciting, new interpreter!

martin wrote this symphony for the performers on this cd with their performance style in mind and once described it as 'a story for charles'.  they gave the premiere in january 1955, and made this studio recording just over a year later.  in the meantime the czech philharmonic with conductor karel anerl had given the czech premiere, and also recorded the work just a few weeks before this recording with the boston orchestra.  few works can ever have been so lucky in their first recordings - tho dissimilar they are both superb performances which have rarely been equaled since.  what is also clear in this reissue is that the boston performance was recorded in excellent stereo sound.  it has been available in stereo before, but never nearly so clear as this, so even those who have the earlier cds should obtain this one.  it also has the original artwork from the lp sleeve, the original coupling - a worthy symphony premiered in boston in the same year by the italo-american composer walter piston - and newly added the violin concerto by another italo-american, giancarlo menotti.  the concerto was recorded earlier than the two symphonies and is in mono sound.  i would say that for the martin symphony this cd, and the supraphon cd containing the anerl performance, are both vital.  the same martin performance can also be downloaded from the munch emi in the great conductors series, but as mentioned before, the rca japanese reissue is far better in sound.  the anerl is also available in download form.

this sacd is in 5.0 multi-channel sound and i listened to it in 5.0 multi-channel sound. the sacd multi-channel sound stage is confined. one gets the feeling that everyone is cramped very tightly on stage and there is none of the beautiful reverberation that the concertgebouw is famous for! i would imagine that once the hall is full of people, the reverberation gets muffled just like it does at orchestra hall (now called symphony center) in chicago. the chicago symphony (cso) sacds suffer from the exact same confined feeling. i'm no longer going to buy cso or rco sacds until they fire the current recording team and hire better sound engineers. the san francisco symphony mahler sacd live recording team is exquisite! also, bis is producing some fantastic live recordings from sao paulo symphony orchestra that capture the sao paulo hall superbly! now on to the performance: even if this was an excellent recording, it would not help this uninspired performance! conductor jansons concentrates on producing beautiful music, but leaves out the passion required to pull this symphony off to its full measure. the sudden cry of "was vergangen, auferstehen!(what perished, rise again!)" in the last movement should have been much louder and inspired! then, the great cry of 'bereite dich!' is weak and the entire section feels lacking of passion right to the end, where the organ is barely heard and the final ff climax is too soft in comparison to the preceding pianissimo. this symphony is about hope overcoming death and despair which requires the utmost display of passion. time after time where there should be explosive drama, jansons gives us restraint instead. i heard this symphony performed live in person with micheal tilson thomas conducting the chicago symphony orchestra and chorus 5 years ago and it was an incredibly inspiring performance. the chicago symphony chorus sang "was vergangen, auferstehen! (what perished, rise again!)" at full volume and it sent chills through my body, unlike this performance! this is how the great conductors have done it in their recordings like bernstein, mehta, levine, abbado, solti and possibly others i have not heard yet. even janson's own older recording with the olso is much better than this one:symphony 2 in c minor resurrection. however, i loved the chorus' basses nice voluminous full b-flat below the bass clef (the lowest note ever written for basses) which comes across better than any other recording i've heard. it's heard 3 times in the hushed entrance and again on the words "hör'auf zu beben". the dvd would not play in my blu-ray/dvd player, so i had to watch it on my computer. i see much passion on jansons' face and conducting but it is not being translated to the concertegouw orchestra or the netherlands radio choir. in all, i came away from this performance extremely unsatisfied and unfulfilled. when it comes to mahler, janson's should have known better, plus we pay premium prices for sacd format, so i at least expect passion, so i give this 2 stars, that's what i feel it deserves.

we just landed is a 4-cd set, packed full of bob & tom show laughs.  i have been a bob & tom show fan for several years, laughing at their clever antics every weekday as i drive to work.  i have purchased many of their cd collections over the years, but we just landed is by far their best compilation yet.  you'll hear tracks with comedy greats like paul & storm, jim gaffigan, scott dunn, henry phillips, mike birbiglia, bob zany, tom mabe, sean morey, keywood banks, and many others.  you also get to hear the familiar kenny tarmac, mr. obvious, jumbo the elephant, floyd tucker, donnie baker, sid and bart, larry king, ernie furglar, and many of your other favorites.  there are 87 tracks spanned across 4 cds, providing laugh after laugh.  the artwork of the cover and the cd faces is great, and the audio quality of each disk is very well done.  you can purchase this collection right here on amazon.com, or by going to the bob & tom store:  [...]  i highly recommend this cd set for any fan of the bob & tom show.  even if you have never listened to the show, this collection is a great way to discover their quick wit and creative humor.  just remember that this is adult themed this was the original cover put forward, not by jimi (it is often stated he hated it), but by the uk label boss (chris stamp) who liked to push boundaries in order to get attention. hence it was only released in the uk like this and was banned from many stores. this mini lp replica is mainly for collectors. it should also be noted that the artwork requested by jimi himself was also rejected and now we have the famous red and yellow art photo.  i never purchased a jh experience studio album until after his death. my only hendrix album during his lifetime was smash hits which did me just fine but left me wanting more, later, after his death. are you experienced was an amazing stoner find which i discovered only after entry into college and joining the club. yeah, that was groovy. i gave axis bold as love a listen or two but it didn't do the thing for me. it was missing something essential. i nailed it down, what it was missing only after i heard electric ladyland. that was what it was missing! now electric ladyland was the culmination of everything great about jimi. here is his masterpiece! i used to play side three (the psychedelic side) over and over and skipped side two much too often, and side four was my favorite side so the second vinyl disc just plumb wore out! then i sat without any hendrix for a couple decades 'cept for a reissue cd of smash hits (again). so about 6 months ago i ran across this remastered work of art in a hold-over hippie record store, shoo'd the moths out of my wallet and have been happily eating electric ladyland once again for a while now.  now, if you are one like me, pop into the way-back machine and figure out if you grooved to melodious beatles, mamas & papas, simon & garfunkel; or you liked to trip out with the doors, the airplane, the dead; if you were adverse to screaming wailing guitar noise (as you used to think of it) but you could knock down a platter of led zeppelin or the who, well maybe initially hendrix just wasn't your bag, but you could easily dig red house, all along the watchtower, foxy lady; yeah you were a smash hits kinda fan. now you are all growed up and you are in need of a little history. so what's the real deal behind the mystique? everyone says this is the album, the masterpiece, the hendrix sgt pepper, even rolling stone mag bows down before it. huh? well, let's look-see...  bear in mind that bob dylan and frank zappa threw pop convention out the window three years earlier and released the first ever double lps from the pop-rock community; the double lp had basically been the providence of jazz performers like ella who released a number of them; then donovan released a gift from a flower to a garden in a fashionable box with trinkets in '67; and cream's wheels of fire in '68. chicago would make the trend a habit beginning in '69 and progressive rock acts would make it almost a requirement after that. my purchase of the album was after it had become fashionable, but in october of '68, jimi had joined an elite handful of artists with great expectations. now that fabulous double dinner treat fits on one cd but it's a full cd with a smorgasbord of sound!  jimi likes to ask his listeners pertinent questions before he kicks off the set. in '67 it was are you experienced? 15 months later: have you ever been to electric lady land? both albums answered the questions with amazing results, but ladyland simply entreats the audience to a diversity of compositional talent which is unprecedented (at least at that time): psychedelic sounds and experimental guitar works, pop, rock, and r&b confections, jazz licks and blues jams; ladyland is like a premiere at an art gallery. it chomps off huge chunks of varietal genre, fuses them together or lays them down against each other in odd meter and arrangement, the end result is one of the most satisfying demonstrations of crossover musicianship you will ever encounter. and when you listen to tunes like his cover of earl king's come on you will understand, you will perceive where the likes of stevie ray vaughan and joe bonamassa arose from. little miss strange seems almost out of place as a 60's pop-rock candy tune with noel redding on the mike, but pay attention to guitar layers, the wah-wah, fuzz, fills, and solos, anything but bubblegum folks! the live voodoo chile and its' slight return variant are sheer monuments in music history, and the psychedelic stretch from rainy day to still raining is one of the best guitar god runs ever laid down on tape. let's not forget that all along the watchtower teams the "voice of our generation" with one of the greatest guitar-god icons ever, into a smoldering track that featured revolutionary guitar and bass work all laid down by jimi himself, a song that has become a soundtrack piece defining an era and one of the greatest recordings of all time.  young dude's: if you are wondering "what jimi hendrix album should i buy?" can't recommend this one enough. yes, i know, are you experienced is an attractive issue, being the debut and containing huge amounts of popular hendrix trax, and it is definitely an item you should own (be sure to pick up the re-issue containing red house which was only available on the uk release for years, red house is one of hendrix' best recordings as well)... but... electric ladyland is jimi's definitive masterpiece, his magnum opus, the pure art gallery of all his talent distilled into one creative everest.

as with their performance of the brahms first concerto, the kovacevich/davis  brahms second concerto is fairly brisk in the first, second and fourth movements.  it differs from the gilels/jochum/ bpo/dg version which is larger scaled, slower and deeply poetic/metaphysical. kovacevich/davis/lso are more akin to the larrocha/jochum/weitblick version , the live gilels/jochum/rcoa version and especially the fleisher/szell/sony and serkin/szell/sony +serkin/ormandy/sony versions. also the dynamic live arrau/gibson/bbc version. however, this philips version is not insensitive to the abundant poetry of the concerto which was written during a relatively softer edged period including the second symphony opus 73 and the violin concerto. these strains are sufficiently balanced with the requisite  fire  and cragginess. the 0pus 76  piano piece here are excellent  though i have long treasured those played by tamas vasary/dg   other selected peers: curzon/knappertsbusch/decca, richter/leinsdorf/rca, pollini/thielemann/dg

creole lady, "dindi", "maiden voyage" and the title track make this cd a smooth jazz/quiet storm gem. like billy eckstine, luther vandross and will downing the late jon lucien was one of those singers who could soothe your soul and warm your heart with his ultra-smooth and classy voice. in many ways, it is very sad that columbia records did not know how to promote jon lucien and this album subsequently fell by the wayside. thankfully bbr records has properly remastered it and this cd edition's sound quality is truly amazing. enjoy!

what burns me more than anything else is when i hear of yet another scammer (bill harris)  playing on people's "needs" for quick-fix easy solutions to life-long, often centuries-old problems. it's the exact same "pop-a-pill" mentality, but most people aren't so cretinous as to steal from the hungry by selling them 21st-century snake oil. look, it took you years - decades - to get to where you are, like it or not, for better or worse. harris would have been a lot smarter to tone down all his claims - "meditate like a monk!" - in order to sound a little more credible, but just go look at his list, and remember that old saying about things looking too good to be true. this isn't just a poor product. it is a pure scam. go spend the same amount of money on a children's burn unit or an orphanage or an animal shelter and you know what? i'll guarantee that you'll feel a lot better about yourself than you would buying this crap.

i've always like the "no angels" group when they first came out, when i lived in germany. this cd is great the music is interesting.. it's a mix between house and techno.. so most europeans should find this a comforting at home feeling.. don't know about the westeners though.. i enjoy this cd and turn it up high when i'm driving down the street.. no complaints.

why is it so difficult to get hold of luminous orange cds? rie takeuchi's melodic & energetic songs deserve a much wider audience. from her earliest work to this latest collection, she's clearly built upon classic shoegaze -- pale saints genius ian masters is present on this very cd, in fact -- so fans of the genre will find much to love here.  but this isn't just an accomplished imitation of english shoegaze. there's both a japanese pop sensibility at play here, and something quieter & more intimate as well. a song like "every single child" blazes with fuzzy sunshine & glorious guitars; but there are also gentler songs like "mithrandir in the lilac sky" to provide a different, almost psych-folk atmosphere. you may be reminded of later tracks by lush -- but again, this isn't a mere copy of other bands, but a distinctive voice of its own.  there's a real joy to this music -- and if you like it, you should track down all earlier luminous orange cds as well -- most highly recommended!

i love the old time radio shows and haven't heard the hercule poirot stories.  recording was excellent.  many of these old radio shows have very bad volume control and often to a point unintelligible.  these are clear

the story lines are very good, typical of ac's hercule poirot plots, but in a shorter half-hour format. what is so unexpected for me, however, is the excellent audio quality of these 70-year-old soundtracks. i am hard of hearing, yet have absolutely no problem clearly understanding the script.  i've come to rely on subtitles when watching current-day uk dvds, so this was a pleasant surprise.

in and effort to keep his classic songs available and put them on cd, don francisco released this second project.  it features 12 of his classic songs, mostly from the 70's and 80's. this cd contains a real mix of songs, with many focusing on how we live now that we are forgiven.  there are classic ballads like "jehoshaphat," "beautiful to me," "balaam," and "voyage to gennesaret."  for some challenge, we've got "steeple song" and the tongue in cheek "everybody else but me."  encouragement comes in the form of "there is no condemnation," "give your heart a home," and "it ain't no sin to get the blues."  he does a beautiful new rendition of his wedding song "i could never promise you."  finally, the cd closes with "still your soul in silence" and "lullaby." production is simple, with the focus on don and his guitar.  but fans who want these classics on cd will love it.

finally on cd! from 1980, this is a classic by a "one album wonder" band. though, the guitarist did produce an ozz ii later in the decade it was without angel t. alexis on vocals and just didn't compare. the songs here are all original and stand alone. classic rockers from "sister madness" to "ain't no money" to "lonely rider. musically, the style is not completely original but it just kicks major ass. it reminds of the whitford/st. holmes album a bit that came out around the same time but with just more balls. that's brad whitford (aerosmith) and derek st. holmes (ted nugent) for those of you who didn't know about that particular one-off rockin' album. ozz had plenty of fans in the business as you will see in the liner notes: from carmen appice to jimmy page. they just never got the promotion from the label which i believe was cbs at the time. in case you need a comparison this is like a mix of aerosmith, nugent, and other late 70's bands at their best but like i said the songs are all original, production is clean and spacious, and they just don't remind me of any any particular band. worth your dollar if this is the style of rock you're into!!!

was there ever a band that you absolutely despise with a passion?  was there ever a band that made you want to commit suicide?  was there ever a band that was so soul-crushingly horrible you felt like jumping off a building?  divina enema does that to me.  do not get me wrong, this album is original...  ...but for these guys, that's where the horribleness comes in.  as many times as you tell yourself that there isn't a woman in this band, you'd be wrong. the vocals are completely feminine, out of tune, noisy, and an absolute nuisance. hell, if you can sit through this album, let alone a 7 and-a-half minute 'song' from these fools, i salute you.  bottom line, all of the copies of this album should be locked away in a cellar in hell with brokencyde's debut album. it's a disgrace to metal, and a disgrace to it's sub-genre itself. as paranoidave on youtube put it for slipknot...  "there are 5 people in your band...  ...but one ****** in a dumpster would make the same sound."  1/5

dueto miseria is an old group and i was really happy to find their recordings available on amazon in cd format.  i first heard a recording of theirs' in the 70's while i was in mexico.  i found a local music store and bought a cassette of their recordings.  i have been playing that cassette ever since and have been afraid that it would eventually break.  while searching on amazon for a cassette to mp3 converter i also found several cds.  what a lucky break! they are brothers who sing a lot of the old songs and their voices blend with each other so well that even though they sing harmony they sound like one voice.

i finally got to see jung hae kim in concert early this year. we wondered initially who this person was who hobbled out early in heavy duty leg braces. it's clear her legs could not handle the pedals of a piano, so she turned to the harpsichord. in the concert i saw, she did a good job backing up a couple of very good baroque violinists.  in this recording, she solos. the instrument she plays is a smaller version of the harpsichord, called a virginal. it features one string per key, and a plectra arrangement that plucks more toward the middle of the strings. the resulting tone is very different from the typical harpsichord, and should be played at lower volumes. this is an instrument for small rooms.  there are a lot of hit tunes from the late renaissance and early baroque here, many very dance like. while she opens with sweelinck, the remaining composers are mostly english, with names like farnaby, dowland, and byrd, lots of byrd. there are also some pieces by my favorite composer, anon.  kim obviously likes this music, her interpretations keep crossing the line into "delightful." i'm glad i was able to talk with her after the concert to tell her how much i liked her album. it's the perfect pick-me-up after a hard day, charming, bright, and often singable. well worth the download.

any transcription, e.g. playing a composition on another instrument or instrumental ensemble than the one it was conceived for by the composer, is legitimate as long as it is effective. a transcription brings new timbral colors to familiar compositions, in a way that can be ear-catching and even revelatory and more convincing even that the original. bach played at the piano is a transcription, or even beethoven played on a modern grand, and the customary arguments in defence of the new instrument seem to me pure twaddle: that bach or beethoven would have composed for the modern grand if they had known it, that beethoven composed for an imaginary instrument that transcended the limitations of the fortepianos of his days, and what not. fact is, we don't know what bach or beethoven would have done if they had known the modern grand, and fact is, what they composed for and what their compositions were played upon were the instruments of their days. so what makes playing bach or beethoven on the modern grand entirely legitimate is not those spurious reconstructions, but simply that the music "works" on the modern instrument, which brings to it a range of color and expression that (but i am aware that not all the admirers of the harpsichord or the fortepiano will agree with me on this one) does transcend the sonic limitations of the original instruments and that is entirely convincing and gratifying in its own right. and if it worked played by a kazoo orchestra, then the kazoo orchestra would be as legitimate as anything. but there is, other than those general considerations, a special legitimacy to transcribing and playing mussorgsky's "pictures at an exhibition" on other instruments. mussorgsky's cycle, originally composed for the piano in 1874, is so descriptive, graphic, evocative and, well, picturesque, that from the outset it seemed to call for more colors than (thought many, although i don't include myself with those) the piano could provide. orchestrations were essayed about as soon as the work was published, among which ravel's is the most famous, but neither the first, nor the last. but many other instrumental possibilities were explored, from solo instrument (organ galore, as an introduction see my review of anne chollet plays bach, liszt & mussorgski, even guitar - there is a version by kazuhiyo (sometimes spelt kazyhito) yamashita, available on cd on the japanese sister company under asin b000v2rwlm; i haven't heard it, but i'm rather sceptical about the instrument's ability to add and vary color) to brass ensemble (pictures at an exhibition: night at the bare mountain), chamber ensemble (ravel: le tombeau de couperin / mussorgsky: pictures at an exhibition), synthesizer (tomita's famous version, see my review of mussorgsky: pictures at an exhibition - tomita). i'm not sure it was ever done with a kazoo orchestra, though. the concert accordion (or, as here, its russian version, the bayan) is one of my favorite instruments. it shares with the keyboard instruments (piano or harpsichord) the sharpness of articulation and attack and the digital virtuosity, but it draws from the woodwinds a continuity of breath and ability to sustain tones that the piano, with its strings struck by felted hammers, and the harpsichord with its pinched strings, can only simulate. it has more bass clarity than the organ and is more capable of conveying polyphony and counterpoint. its eerie and reedy timbres may not be to everyone's taste, but i find that it conjures a great variety of colors, and they seem particularly appropriate for mussorgsky's depiction of viktor hartmann's gaudy russian pictures. because of the reminiscences of the barrel organ it conjures, the accordion returns "pictures at an exhibition" to their popular/folk roots. the old castle is particularly effective in its evocative wistfulness, and lips' market at limoges evokes memories of petrushka's fair. the shrieks of the unhatched chicks are graphically depicted, and catacombae are suitably evocative of the organ. the instrument may lack a touch of power in gnomus, goldenberg or the great gates of kiev, but this is more than compensated by its timbral ear-catching originality, that i find totally appropriate to mussorgsky's picturesque evocations. the instrument is one thing and the performer is another. born in 1948, friedrich lips is one of the great virtuosos of the bayan, the author of the fundamental textbook "the art of bayan playing" and he is also a fine interpreter. his promenades do not attempt at probing for great depths of expression - they are lively and joyous, and obviously the promenader is tremendously enjoying his visit at the hartmann exhibition - and his bydlo doesn't quite trudge as your fantasy of a ponderous oxencart, but he commands the full range of expression called by pictures, from the meditativeness of the old castle to the whimsicality of the unhatched chicks and the fury of the hut of fowl's legs. fans of mussorgsky's pictures should not miss this. i don't have much to say about leon boellmann's gothic suite from 1895, originally for organ, as i don't even know the original. but the timbral richness of the accordion is ideally suited to the acoustic explorations of contemporary music and has inspired many contemporary composers, of which lips has been an indefatigable champion. two fine specimens are offered here, gennadi banshchikov's sonata no. 1 for bayan from 1977, evocative and dramatic although still rooted in some sense of melody, and gubaidulina's stunning de profundis, a study in the instruments eeriest sonorities. tt 70:20, and this is a great disc. see the comments section under my review of vivi felice! accordion music by domenico scarlatti for a discography of classical accordion.

i have to admit, i am one of the songwriters, but damn it, i was always proud of this little gem, and i was thrilled to see it appear on amazon one day.  i've never had a bad review, except from a guy who thinks the sex pistols were a small orchestra out of new zealand, and you don't want to know what he's done.  there are louder albums, and slower albums, and albums that have a lot more blue in their cover art, but this is the only album that is what it is.  if you combined steely dan, pink floyd, led zeppelin, the beatles, queen and the allman brothers, without anyone with the last name "allman," you'd have a band that would be about the same age as this band's older brothers, and maybe one sister, but no cousins.

i've been listening to wm ackerman for many years, and always liked his stuff; however, when i started hearing songs from this production, i sat up at attention!! he has clearly come into his mojo, and there is now something of his musical genius and whatever is in his heart that is clearly coming thru his music! i think the cd is appropriately titled; it makes you sit there and meditate. he has found the perfect blend of cello and guitar as well as other instruments that are playing as strongly as he is, and in fact, his humility is evident in that he is wiling to be in the background, supporting the cellist. my favorite pieces are "was it this lifetime?" and "when the moon sings", which are new productions--those are the ones that grabbed my attn. the rest of them are mostly older songs but redone with his new "contemplative" style. he has won the right to have his old stuff purchased in its newer form. he is one of the few artists that i would love to meet and be able to talk with, but i'm just a gurgling fan......

mike stax's ugly things records has struck paydirt once again.  this time he has located and gifted us with the 6 tracks originally released by this rialto, ca quintet in 1965 and 1966 along with 21 previously unreleased tracks all gathered from the original master tapes and demos.  67 minutes of rocking ca garage psych, bush play with plenty of punch, not that jangly west coast stuff that peope pass off as garage/psych.  this is the real deal.  fronted by lead vocalist steve hoard who also cowrote much of the material with lead guitarist allen henninger.  the sound is like early stones or pretty things.  driving rock.  plenty of fuzz as well as bluesy rock numbers.  the bush evoloved out of an earlier band, the bushmen, and mixed tasteful cover tunes with solid original material.  like so many other bands of the time, the bush just never quite got the break they deserved.  but thanks to the good mr. stax, the bush get their just deserts on got bush if you want it.  ca psych expert alec palao performed the disc transfers, yet another indication of the tlc given this slice of ca garage/psych with more than a tinge of blues rock added to the mixtue.  highly recommended.  5 stars at the very least.

i am listening again to passage, perhaps for the 8th or 10th time in the past few weeks.  i find the music exhilarating and powerful -- sets of variations over many moods, variations that are at once simple, emotionally  complex, and lyrical, with exquisite, surprising transitions to unexpected  places.  the return of the themes in their original keys is like returning  to a lover or a loving home.  shaun tirrell, whom i have heard play before,  plays with his usual sensitive touch and mastery.  his wife jina woo  tirrell joins him to play shubert's "fantasy" -- the appetizer  for this feast.  this is as good as it gets, folks.

orlando leflemming is a acoustic bassist originally hailing from london uk & now residing in the jazz capital of the east nyc. up until now leflemming has paid his dues as a first call gigging and session bassist working with most of the up & coming talent on the nyc jazz scene most notably with seamus blake appearing onway out willy & also with drummer ari hoenig on his latestbert's playground as well as guitarists gilad heckselman & lage lund. here you have leflemming stepping out as the leader of a top self ensemble featuring some of my favorite players going to work live in brooklyn at freddy's back room. on drums is antonio sanchez best known for his trio work with pat metheny. on alto sax is fellow brit will vinson who has used orlando on bass on his last two albums. on guitar is my current favorite lage lund who has played guitar on will vinson's last two albums along with orlando on bass,orlando also played bass on lage's first albumearly songs. the great thing about this band is each player has worked with each other alot & it really shows. the first tune false dilema starts things off on a smooth note with lage's piano like chord voicings & a tone resembling a fender rhodes comping a chilled out vamp that reminds me of something off an old tribe called quest album. the smoothness gives way to some more aggressive & funky three way cat & mouse between vinson,lund & sanchez. the second track which happens to be the title tune starts off with leflemming playing solo for about a minute an a half,he sports a beautiful tone on his upright with shades of dave holland & marc johnson. other highlights include rummaging for significance & the last tune deceptive lizard, the lizard is the groups romp with the funk. for the money this is a very enjoyable album. if you've recently enjoyed any of the music by lage lund,will vinson or seamus blake than i highly recommend this album. if your looking for more of a traditional blowing date rooted in straight ahead post bop swing you won't find much of that here, this is modern jazz with what i like to call a hybrid sound with influences from many different styles of music. the band functions as more of a simultaneous improv unit more like the bill evans trio. this music is not for the faint of heart but serious jazz listeners. enjoy!

there are dozens of fine collections of yiddish songs out there, many performed by the great interpreters of the last 100 years, from cantors (hazzanim) to famous opera singers, to popular singers of the day, many heavily orchestrated.  i have had the music cassette version of this recording since the late 1980s. once transferred to cd, i picked it up immediately. this is a most intimate approach, giving one a feeling of sitting at an outdoor cafe on a warm summer evening, listening to moshe leiser (voice and guiitar), ami flammer (violin), and gerard barreaux (accordion), while sipping a 'petit noir', under a clear starry night.  in the marais, perhaps, rue des rosiers or the rue des ecouffes ?  or in metz, or in brooklyn.  songs recalling a childhood and parents, a world mostly gone for many.  and the 'classics' are featured: rhozhinkes mit mandlen (raisins and almonds), az der rebbe (when the rabbi sings), mamele, ...  thirteen songs in all.  'tendresses et rage', a gentle time, a normal time, of a close-knit family, and of friends and community, but also a brutal end of time, remembered in shock and sorrow.  sweet memories savagely crushed, many people and communities exterminated, millions of souls lost.  hashoah. the holocaust.  hence the title of the album.  a cd to listen to quietly, when the mood strikes, not for grand public occasions.  (there are plenty of great recordings of yiddish songs for such events.  loud and proud.)  this rendition, more private, one of recall and discoveries of an exuberant culture.  a group of young artists back in 1985, at the time connecting to their past, a thread hopefully linking to the next generation.

jussi at grona lund - complete recording the swedish tenor jussi bjorling gave frequent concerts at stockholm's grona lund ampitheater and on these three discs are all the known selections available - 63 songs and arias from nine concerts with piano accompaniment. bluebell records had preciously released two discs of assorted grona lund performances, but besides the 16 additional selections(by my count)this set has the added virtue of placing the selections in order of performance with informative liner notes. there are many gems on these three discs - an outstanding "o colombin" from "pagliacci", a "m'appari" from "martha" that is matched only by his rca recording, an extraordinarily intense "mamma! quel vino" from "cavalleria" and ... well, i could go on and on. some are less than perfect - bjorling was not a machine and also, in some instances the sound is not up to ideal standards. but these are live performances by one of the finest, if not the finest, tenor of the 20th century. and since bjorling often sang the same selections, there are different versions to compare. five "til havs", four "morgen", three "come un bel di." and as the liner notes point out, there is a "barcarola" from "un ballo in maschera" in which he sings the octave leaps from high a to low c flawlessly and without a pause, something he did on film and in the theater as well, but which few tenors will even attempt. so, yes. buy this set. and then start collecting bjorling to see what pavarotti and domingo lack.

i really like this bruckner 9th! the swedish radio symphony orchestra plays in a hall with wonderful acoustics--the kind of deliciously resonant hall that is ideal for bruckner--painting on a vast and spacious canvas and projecting the music as majestic landscape. and svetlanov, recorded live in 1999, delivers a well-proportioned and deeply felt reading that i found especially convincing in the final movement (no 4th-movement completion here). this is live, and it isn't berlin or vienna, but the orchestra does well enough; strings often have a nice sheen and woodwinds are often sweet and characterful. at certain crucial, mystical moments in the final movement the horns play with perfect repose and timing. just one or two distant coughs can be heard in the course of this long performance, and are only very briefly distracting. if you're looking for sheer physical perfection in execution, for beauty of tone and immaculately sculpted phrasing, then stick with karajan/berlin or giulini/vienna, but if you're looking for a refreshing view in a live performance, try this.  svetlanov performed with this orchestra nearly as often as with his own, and toward the end of his career (which this is) he was performing bruckner with more regularity--the 8th more than the 9th. this i believe is his only complete recording of the 9th. the timing of 28:30 (roughly) in the 1st movement puts him in giulini/vienna territory (just barely beyond it, actually), but not quite in the vaster territory occupied by remy ballot. the second and third movement timings become more conventional, a la karajan's later reading. i heard what i thought were a couple of minor tangles in execution in the second movement, but none in the third, which i found uplifting. svetlanov here seems to be a master of the kind of long, slow crescendo that you don't even realize is happening until halfway through, when you find yourself happily being borne higher and higher. and as in his brahms set with the ussr state orchestra from the early '80s, he seems able to produce clear and distinctly enunciated phrases, paragraphs, and textures, but within a musically flowing context where there is no hint of an overly analytical quality. his insightful and unexaggerated handling of many sections makes this a distinctive performance.  i wouldn't presume to rank this or recommended it to those who already have 50-some versions of this work, when i myself have only 10 or 15. but it seems that any completist certainly ought to be interested (and not just for completion's sake), and beyond that, any who have found that they respond to this conductor and admire his gifts, which i do. (and i move quickly to reassure all readers this has nothing whatsoever to do with any bias that might have been introduced by the discovery that svetlanov and i share the same birthday.) i'm certainly glad i bought this, and i'm certain i'll be listening many times. i provide this brief review since i don't know how much longer this cd will be available.

i have three other carmina burana cds pretty much memorized to compare this to, and have seen it performed twice in different cities.  this cd is a ddd recording of kurt prestel conducting the salzbur choir and orchestra...  the vocalists are mostly very good performers. they enunciate. they hit the right notes. most of them are just about perfect. but the baritone is horrible. he has no strength or focus. there are two important parts during which he cannot even hold a note!! he actually takes a breath where no one else ever needs to.  and the orchestra is small. there is no gong during the last few seconds of o fortuna, for example. and they sometimes sound like a high school band. the musicians almost always hit the right notes, but they are clumsy at times, and the conductor just doesn't seem to get the feel for any of the music, or the work as a whole. the timing is way off. it's staccato too often, and way too deliberate, like a literal reading of music. it's just not magical or professional.  technical quality of masters classic cd from holland this ddd recording sounds hissy if you don't turn the treble down to -1, where most cds sound best at +3 (on my car sound system). plus some loud parts are very distorted. it actually gets much worse in the second half, which never happens on ddd recordings.  * * *  now, if you'd like to know about the other two in my collection...  * * *  carl orff trionfi - rundfunk sinfonie orcheter leipzig  this is a 2 cd set of carl orff's carmina burana trilogy.  after carmina burana, the catulli carmina and trionfo di afrodite are quite disappointing performed by anyone, but worth hearing at least once. it's just that i cannot recommend this box set for the performance of carmina burana.  the vocalists and orchestra perform accurately, but...  1. several parts are sung much too fast. 2. in a few parts there is so much r rolling that it is distracting. 3. too many parts are sung deliberately instead of joyfully. 4. it sometimes sounds angry instead of magical.  the technical quality is ok. the highs are bright and clear, but there is hardly any bass, and really much more dynamic range on this cd than most classical cds. this cd goes from so quiet that you cannot hear it, to so loud that it hurts the ears much too often. and again, it does this much more than most classical cds!!  * * *  the philadelphia orchestra, eugene ormandy ****  my favorite so far is not as bright and clean as the ozawa, but is the best performance i have heard on cd. it is an older recording with the philadelphia orchestra led by eugene ormandy, and the rutgers university choir. harve presnell is the featured soloist in this performance, which is a claim to fame for my area since he went to modesto high school. also, if you watched the pretender (1996-2000), he was miss parker's "daddy."  this was the best performance over all that i have heard on cd, but if you want the best sounding cd of carmina burana...  * * *  the berliner philharmoniker, seiji ozawa ***  seiji ozawa conducting the berliner philharmoniker is not the very best performance, but definitely the best sounding cd of carmina burana that i have heard. it's bright, deep, clean, and clear with full range and no distortion. it also doesn't get too quiet in the quiet parts, and then too loud in the loud parts. that never happens on this one. it just sounds fantastic.  but apparently others are even better. i'm going to get the highest rated one i can find.

if you like this album, you must make a beeline to "going places" from 1965. recent;y i listened to them side by side. both lps are very adventurous within an easy-listening paradigm. both are impeccably arranged. "fandango" holds together better as a whole, perhaps because it was intended for the latin american market, while "going places" is a bit more "over the map" in its selections. "going places" hit number one on the billboard charts while "fandango" didn't, but that was not for the lack of critical acclaim. listen to them both and you'll hear easy listening music at its best!

i once came across the words of alan watts set to jazz - and this is what i was reminded of most strongly while listening to "rumi, fountain of fire." the rhythms, music, and words are at once deeply restful, and  engaging.  one can not help but be drawn into a personal  introspection. sadly, i know little of sufism, or rumi, but i'm finding  this an excellent introduction.  my reading has taken me through buddhism,  kahlil gibran, taoism - and now in these words and music i've found a new  direction that already feels welcome and familiar.

nina hagen is one of my favorite artists. i have seen her perform at least 50 times in concert since she came out with nunsexmonkrock in 1978 or so.  i have videotaped her performances and we have chatted through email. i do not like to disapprove of any artist's product, but this particular cd is not her best.  it has an old feel to it, like recycled 1970's rock, which would not be a bad thing if it was in any way interesting. but it is not.  the lyrics, all in german, may be compelling, but i don't speak german, so i cannot comment on their potency.  however, not knowing the meaning of the lyrics does not necessarily affect the appeal of the whole; other albums all in german are superb, e.g., freud euch (in english bee happy) in exkstace (in english, in ecstacy) as well as angstloss (in english, fearless) which has never appeared on cd.  but somehow, this album does not quite cut it.  after playing it a few times, i sold it on amazon. one day, i may encounter it again and love it. but today is not the day.  this is also the only album of hers that i have ever sold.  all the others, i adore and play pretty regularly.  this one was not compelling.

a trusted music-head friend of mine recommended i check out side fx, and i'm so glad i did. i got this cd a few weeks ago, and since then it's been in constant rotation on my car stereo.  side fx has a huge range of sounds/styles. they can sound like a modern update on the police, then they throw in some tasty santana-esque lines and a flute solo. their jazz songs are elegant and grooving. and kim, the singer, really does sound sultry!  overall, i really like this album's feel. from start to finish, each song sounds unique and interesting. no filler songs here. you can tell that the musicians in side fx are first rate, but their skills don't outshine the songwriting.  definitely check this album out!

while the party groove series used to bring the hottest club songs by the biggest divas and best remixers to cd, what we get now is a rehash of songs that were hits over a decade ago--in cover versions! and the problem is, the new versions are almost note for note duplicates of the original songs.  club music used to be `progressive' and ground breaking, and all we're getting here are imitations of what are now basically `classics.' wayne g (who has done some pretty good club remixes of current hits) offers a remake of madonna's "beautiful stranger"--that is nearly identical to the victor calderone mix of the song from 1999. same goes for the remake of the 2000 club hit "don't want another man", which is still the dynamix version, but now has some other vocalist replacing tina ann. we get a pretty good remix of billie ray martin's 1994 club smash "your loving arms"--with her actual vocals. wayne g gives us a new version of "age of love", originally recorded by age of love--and sounding pretty much exactly like the 1992 remix of the song. wayne g remixes tony moran's 2004 song "the promise", which was a remake of the when in rome 1988 club track.  so we get a remix of a remake... there's a dance cover version of gaga's "you and i"--while it's a pretty good version, why not give us one of the actual gaga club mixes that went to number one on the billboard charts and haven't appeared on cd at all? the amazing song "night of your life" by david guetta featuring jennifer hudson is here--in a cover version. the disc ends with a cover version of rihanna's "we found love."  are there highlights? i found a couple. first, a dance cover version of the song "bad things", which everyone will recognize as the theme song to true blood! and the song "devil in disguise" by k-poff is a pretty cool electro house track with male vocal. other than that, this disc is sort of like...dance muzak....  track list:  1. beautiful stranger...wayne g with melissa totten (8:55) 2. don't want another man...dynamix (5:55) 3. night of your life...dreamette (5:54) 4. outlaw...paul goodyear with caroline lund (7:26) 5. your loving arms (wayne g atlantis anthem)...billie ray martin (5:48) 6. age of love...wayne g and andy alder (4:53) 7. the promise (wayne g mix)...tony moran (4:55) 8. you and i (dig-it mix)...dame dance (6:07) 9. don't make me wait...7th heaven (5:58) 10. bad things...alva and allder (4:58) 11. b*tch...ralphi rosario and wayne g (5:14) 12. devil in disguise...k-poff (4:36) 13. we found love...parasol (5:27)

i already had the bach performances on other albums, but bought this for the "harmonious blacksmith."  as usual (for richter fans like me), he does a great job and i enjoy it greatly.  i love his handel organ concerti, although i prefer marie claire alain's recordings), but i really prefer richter's harmonious blacksmith to ignor kipnis (no hatred or dislike for mr. kipnis).  it's pure richter - concise, what some would call metronome, but his interpretations never hit me that way.  if you like the music, buy it and compare with your other performances.  it's definitely worth a listen.

this cd has helped me to move on from my anxiety over leaving my last job and being unemployed.  i have been having a terrible time finding a job and have been looking for 19 months!  there is nothing magic on here, but while you are listening you will be saying, yes, i know, i should do that.  then you do it.  then you realize it works.  i am one who thinks meditation is something everyone should do, but i never do it myself.  something is so hard about stopping and taking a few moments to calm your mind and actually focus on your own dreams and desires.  clarity is priceless.  buy it -- you won't be sorry and you'll probably end up buying the set afterward, like me.

i googled marimba music, love the sound. very similar to steel drum. i want to enjoy listening to both these melodic percussion instruments. that said, this item came up in my search for marimba music. there is one track billed with a recognized marimba artist. it is headlined in the website. well... this music is boring, not fresh. all of the pieces are boring including the one track that includes mr. anderson playing marimba. each track has the same symphonic character, midwest, pedestrian and midwestern. this is pure elevator music. it should be played when you are prepared to give it an equivalent attention to elevator moosic. not even good enough for phone 'on hold' recordings. save your money for something better, fast food, shopping coupons, or taking surveys.

i love sharlene's music!  her voice is deep and throaty and soothing and natural sounding.  the music itself is both calming and rousing and full of spirit!  she sings from her soul. my favorite song on this cd is "at rest, at peace" which is written from the earth's perspective.  what must it feel like to be the earth and witness and feel all that goes on here? this cd came out when i was a teenager and added some much-needed calm to the room i shared with my sister--we fell asleep to it every night.

this is the first album from the nerve (from new york city, not the english band) and that's what it sounds like. poor lo-fi production, sonically flat and kinda one-dimensional, and lyrically and musically hokey, affected and immature. that being said the disc is worth a listen for a few standout tracks like "sensitive new age guy", "a kind of girl", the surprisingly poignant "years" and a "hidden" live version of a song that already appears earlier on the disc called "chirp the crown dead". i'll take the live version over the lack-luster studio version anyday. the rest of the disc leaves little to be desired. but there's still something strangely likeable about it. the cool thing about this disc is that when listened back to back with their last album, "the nerve!" the evolution of this band is monumental. in just a few discs, i believe they had only 3, this group evolved from a kids band sounding like they never got out of the garage trying to play an awkward version of punk rock, into a well-oiled, mature, powerhouse rock machine and released one of the best albums of the early 2000s (see my review of "the nerve!"). for any music fan it's worth the price of both discs to hear a band evolve and become something special.
