so, if you're looking for some latin brass to dance to, look somewhere else.  i'd recommend the afro-cuban allstars for that classic cuban sound, or cecelia noel for something more modern and energetic.  this collection,  instead of being backed by a six or eight piece brass section was backed,  it seems, by some dude with a synthesizer, and maybe a guy with some bongos  (although that might have been the synthesizer too, i'm not sure.  i could  only stand listening to it once).  tito puente it ain't.

ske48, the sister idol group of akb48 that is based in nagoya returns with their 11th cd single "choco no dorei" (which translates to "a slave for chocolate"), a track which becomes the group's seventh cd single to reach #1 on the oricon weekly charts and also surpassed "kiss datte hidarikiki" in becoming their highest selling single for its release day and for its first week with over 620,000 singles sold.  and it's another testament to the marketing machine created by akb48 producer yasushi akimoto. ske48 was created as a test for akimoto to see if his idea of having an nationwide 48 project would work, considering he had received offers from other countries to develop his project for their country.  and here is ske48 having celebrated their third year anniversary and to achieve great success.  but as the single will be noted for its mature dance tracks, it will also be a sad single for fans of nine members of ske48 who are graduating.  with "choco no dorei", a total of four cd single versions were released.  type-a, type-b and type-c (note: limited and regular edition of all three types have different covers) will include a dvd with music videos but also a video celebrating the group's third year anniversary broken up into three parts.  a theater edition comes with both exclusive tracks from type-a and b plus an 11th single medley with no dvd is also available.  the version i will be reviewing is "choco no dorei" (type-a). the cd insert is a tri-fold featuring jurina matsui as the center on the cover.  when opened up, all 16 members holding red balloons are featured on one side, while lyrics and production credits are featured on the other side.  reverse cover on the back features a photo of the 7 dancers.  the first track on the single is "choco no dorei", an upbeat synth/brass dance track.  an addictive single with great vocals from the group, "choco no dorei" is about a guy sitting in a classroom looking at a bag with sweets and is hoping the bag is an answer from a person they love on valentine's day.  a slave to chocolate, as the guys will hold out their hands in hopes to receive chocolate form a girl they like, and if she does, he may shed a tear of happiness.  the second track is titled "darkness" and is performed by 7 dancers (which is comprised of  team s members jurina matsui, kumi yagami, yuria kizaki, yukiko kinoshita and mizuki kuwabara. team kii member anna ishida and team e member mai takeuchi.  and i have to say that this is the group's most mature upbeat, j-pop dance track and its wonderful!  despite the upbeat dance nature of the song, "darkness" is actually quite sad.  the song is about  one wanting to be loved and be in love.  she wants to disappear in the dark and sadness where stars don't shine.  she wants to be in love with this guy, but it's one-sided love and feels she will be chasing after the guy for all of eternity, so she wants to hide in the deep darkness.  the third track is titled "sore wo seishu to yobu hi" and is performed by tabidachi sotsugyou-gumi (journey alumni) which consists of the nine graduating members of ske48: kumi yagami, mizuki kuwabara, shiori takada, kanako hiramatsu, shiori ogiso, ririna akaeda, kasumi ueno, minami hara and emiri kobayashi.  a sad but hopeful graduation song of each member singing about being in the theater in front of an audience to say their goodbye.  saying thank you to everyone and remembering the days of singing and dancing with friends and looking at their locker of the things they cherished.  and as they prepare for the future, they hope that they can come back someday to see their friends that they have grown up with along the way.  the remainder of the three tracks are the instrumental versions of the first three vocal tracks.  as for the dvd, the dvd begins with the music video of "choco no dorei" and focuses on ske48 performing and dancing on stage, with videos of the members practicing their choreography, stretching and visiting the theater.  the second music video is for "darkness", members of the seven dancers are dressed up in suits and are seen performing the song on stage and showcasing their choreography.  the third and final video on the dvd features part 1 of the group's third year anniversary challenge celebration.  the members of ske48 walking into a restaurant and jurina matsui and rena matsui greet their fellow members to celebrate the group's third anniversary, while everyone is having fun eating.  afterward, the group partakes in putting pantyhose on their heads and which team can walk with pantyhose with the farthest distance without breaking it or having it come off their heads.  it's important to note that this is a region 2 dvd and will not play on a region 1 player (unless you have a non-region dvd player) but can be played on a mac or pc using free video playing software such as vlc or daum potplayer.  judgment call:  overall, "choco no dorei" (type-a) is a pretty cool cd+dvd and is possibly my favorite ske48 single yet.  featuring three awesome songs and also as an ske48 fan, to have the graduation track is a must but "darkness" by 7 dancers is an awesome song!  also, the dvd content is very cool and this includes the first part of the ske48 3rd anniversary celebration (a reminder that if you want the other two parts, you will need to purchase type-b and type-c).  featuring two pretty cool upbeat dance track and the graduation song plus a dvd with an hour's worth of cool content, "choco no dorei" (type-a) is highly recommended!

kiki dee is far more than a pop singer; she is an interpretor of songs. she is an artist who has done rock, ballads, and she has one of the finest voices to emerge from the 60s british invasion. i was elated when this cd came out in 1996 and i am thrilled that her entire back catalogue was reissued by emi and edsel (which reissued the great album perfect timing). almost naked now has added tracks making this beautiful album even more enjoyable. apart from the title track, all of these songs were taken from different concerts and kiki dee is more than ably accompanied by carmelo luggeri. this is an intimate album and the listener feels they are there in person. the songs are new, covers, and reinterpretations of songs kiki previously recorded. i highly recommend this marvelous album by kiki dee and i hope you'll be spurred on to purchase more of the reissues now available by one of britain's greatest female singers.

i am familiar with many of gateway worship's songs so i was excited to see some of the most popular compiled together in the first ten years.  i love that worship groups such as this showcase a variety of singers. it really adds variety and distinction to each of their songs. hailing from gateway church, their worship team is a huge staple of the church and their popularity continues to grow as they reach the masses all over the world.  i have always preferred slower worship songs. i feel like they have the ability to reach deeper and touch you as you really reflect on the words. that made no sweeter name, and the more i seek you among my favorites.  my absolute favorite is new doxology. it gives me chills every time. i grew up in a small baptist church, the daughter of the pastor and this song brings back so many memories of church services from my younger years. i love the tradition of using such an old hymn. i think it's a delicate task to modernize a hymn but they have done it effectively and well and my current church now sings it, spanning the bridge from my youth until now.  i love when i listen to worship cd's that has the same songs we are singing at my church. it makes me feel i can continue the worship throughout the week and bring back that feeling i had in church sunday that begins to fade the day after. gateway worship: the first ten years is a magnificent worshipful experience.

lovely recording of hungarian folk, popular and classical music by zoltn kodly, franz liszt, jen hubay, and hector berlioz. it is all wonderfully played by the hungarian state symphony orchestra & mtys  antl. i enjoyed the delightful performances and strongly recommend it.

a must buy! i have been waiting for this soundtrack to come out for many years and i was not disappointed. elmer bernstein's great score is evident throughout and i was very pleased to see that charlie rich's "a man gets to thinkin'" was included (twice)! unfortunately many times, soundtracks are disappointing, as they differ (sometimes considerably) from the actual film score (ex. "emperor of the north pole" and "midnight run" soundtracks that infuse 'vocals' with these great instrumental scores....what were they thinking?!?!). however, cahill is left in tact, right from the film! for all you john wayne fans, cahill fans, and elmer bernstein fans, this is a 'must buy' soundtrack you'll listen to for years to come!

this is a great 3cd set of various dean martin songs. there are quiet a few songs from dean's radio show mixed in with songs dean recorded in the studio. that could be considered either good news or bad if you are a dean martin fan. the sound quality of these songs are not as good as the studio cuts, but they are still great to listen to. ironically, it is four of those radio songs that make this cd set worth having. included are four rare christmas radio transcriptions of "baby it's cold outside, "silent night," "silver bells, and the bing crosby song "it's beginning to look a lot like christmas," which was a song dean never recorded commercially. to my knowledge, the only other set that contains these versions is the expensive bear family "return to me" boxed set. so if you enjoy dean's christmas music and have all of his other holiday cds, you might want to check this one out. although the sound quality on these old radio transcripts are not as clear as you might like, they are a must have to complete your dean martin christmas collection.

bill mumy is an amazing musician who pours his heart and soul into every album. illuminations has profound lyrics and bill once again covers all vocals and instruments. i was introduced to bill mumy music several years ago and every album he has released has been more powerful than the last. if you have never listened to any of bill mumy's albums then you owe yourself to explore his music.  bill displays tremendous talent and creativity in every album and does not disappoint. bill has been a musician since he was ten and has played and wrote songs with the band america. this is not your father's billy mumy. you can see all of bill's albums at his website [...] i will be buying this album for friends and family this holiday season!

karl ancerl was one of janacek's greatest interpreters and this recording is the proof. ancerl recorded the sinfonietta several times; this is hands down, his finest effort. the sinfonietta easily surpasses the many recordings of janacek's most popular composition with its crisp, lively, stunning tempi and rich orchestral sound. the czech philharmonic proves itself a world class orchestra, playing this music with understanding, insight and pride in their native sons, janacek and martinu. the finest sinfonietta on record.
really, really bad...style is all over the board - the only thing linking tracks is a pervasive insipidness

these are wonderful realizations of respighi's great tone poems. sir malcolm has a superb grasp of the musical heart of these pieces and the london symphony orchestra responds beautifully. for my ears this recording stands right at the top of the list with other outstanding recordings by fritz reiner, eugene ormandy, arturo toscanini and others. the recorded sound is open, full, detailed and allows one to really hear the performances. highly recommended.

if you like the music (and i do) this is one of the two best performances of it ever captured on record. and the sound is crystal clear and virtually free of distortion in this very expensive remastering of the original 35mm tape by king records who was responsible over the years for most of the japanese pressings of the decca catalog.. you don't need an sacd player to hear how fine the sound is. fistoulari was a great ballet conductor and anything done by him is worth seeking out. my advice is to move quickly if you are interested, because this is a very limited edition and no doubt the price will skyrocket once it has gone out of print.

while this appears under the heading for the pioneering eugene ormandy recording from 1945 the actual recording in the download is the london symphony with josef krips from 1959 ... the rating is for the performance of the krips version [i cant comment on the download, although if it isn't derived from the everest master tapes it will contain some serious distortion at the beginning of the finale, as do all transfers not so derived] ... there was once a particularly wretched and inept transfer of the ormandy available on amazon which has now apparently [and gratefully] been removed ... undamaged but slightly over-filtered transfers of this excellent ormandy recording may be auditioned on yootoob ... youll know what to do then ...

it's always a pleasure to hear jorge bolet play, particularly the piano works of franz liszt and the choice here is magnificent. the pianist respects the composer - that much is apparent - and his feeling for line is well represented.  what a joy!

warning if you are looking for an actual rock album you should look elsewhere.  starting with 8eight* and then sync, the current of electronic pop iteration of kaela is now complete.  this feels like a quick turn around for kaela and her new deal with victor music. the music sounds slapped together and inorganic as it is almost all synthesizers, the vocals are well below what kaela can deliver as a performer and the sound engineering is a notch below garage band.  this album had a lot of potential and a fun song mix (take on me, funkytown, my generation, heart of glass and fight for your right to party) but it is so far below what a top musician on the japanese music scene should deliver that it is impossible to recommend it to anyone be they new to kaela or a longtime fan like myself.

hello all. i was introduced to keri noble by a friend and since then i've been extremely infatuated with her work. she has the most beautiful voice. it's so peaceful. her "lullaby" album is absolutely amazing. it's so peaceful that you could fall asleep listening to it. just listen to the music and hear her voice; you'd swear you heard an angel.  here are the lyrics to my favorite song, "father, father"  (piano intro)  the world just got bigger all in one night  the ground feels a little shakey  will i be alright?  i don't know, i don't know  on my knees at your feet  i am at your throne  father i'll hear the angels sing  and i feel so alone  and i see  what i see and love  (chorus follows)  father, father hold me  closer even tighter  father i'm afraid to fall  make the dark a little lighter  father, father make it stop  all this pain inside  father hold me now  in your arms is the only place i hide  hold me in your arms  hold me in your arms  i made a big mistake  i just didn't think  i thought i did what seemed right  god, i just didn't think  and i was wrong  i was so wrong  a canopy of dark sky high above my head  there's no fear to lead me  and my heart still says, 'hold me now. hold me now.'  (chorus)  the world just got bigger  all in one night  i'm trying to be strong but it takes all of my might  i'm not as strong as i think  i need you to hold me  i'm not as strong as i think  i need you to hold me  (chorus)  hold me  hold me now  hold me now  hold me now  hold me now  father, father, father, father  hold me now  hold me now  hold me now  hold me now  father, father, father  hold me  (fade out)  ------------------------------  she's better than alicia keys and it pains me to say that because they are both excellent artists. don't take my word for; check it out yourself. i'm sure you'll enjoy it just as much as i do.

this is a wonderful collection of songs that are touching, humorous, dreamy, and just downright fun. brian oliver's smooth vocals, joined by some awesome musicians and backing vocalists, make this a great album that kids and their parents will enjoy. my friends' children love this album and listen to it over and over. i'm 41 and have no children--but i love it, too! in fact, once you've heard "pollywog in a bog," i dare you to get it out of your head!

i bought this box set when it was first released since i was in the process of replacing my vinyl with cd's and did not want to spend too much. there is very little filler and there are also a lot more cuts than a standard hits package. now that i am about to see them live after almost 25 years, i went back and checked for any full cd's that i should order besides the five that were already added to my collection after buying this. guess what? for the casual moody blues fan, this set will suffice. it also included most of the fantastic blue jays album.  since i am too lazy to review all of their studio albums, i have listed each one below with my own star rating to the left. i don't even count that very first album before justin hayward joined. they started off as a psychedelic band with great pop melodies from 1967 to 1971. as my title says, you just had to be there to understand!  since that phase could not last forever, they then took the road towards pop stardom.  3 days of future passed (1967) (too many dated sounding vocals other than the two big hits) 5 in search of the lost chord (1968) (a psychedelic masterpiece) 3 on the threshold of a dream (1969) (too many love songs mixed with good psychedelia) 5 to our children's children's children (1969) (my ultimate favorite mb album, quite trippy) 3 a question of balance (1970) (trying to get away from what they did best with mixed results) 5 every good boy deserves favour (1971) (a return to form with great psychedelic lyrics) 3 seventh sojourn (1972) (the pop trend began here with an active break from the past announcing that they are just rockers) 2 octave (1978) ( a few good songs as mike pinder leaves after regrouping from everyone's solo efforts) 4 long distance voyager (1981) (one final return to form except for the awful gemini dream) 2 the present (1983) (too much time in the studio ruined this one) 2 the other side of life (1986) (and down the bad road they go) 2 sur la mer (1988) (a few good songs) 3 keys of the kingdom (1991) (i was the only one who liked this one) 1 strange times (1999) (this was awful and i never bought december that followed it)  hope this helps any possible new fans.

its hard for me to not to think of bob dylan in terms of the duel nature of the stars he's born under. much as with the case of three other famous gemini signs in miles davis,paul mccartney and of course prince,dylan has had a personality that could be best described as elusively overflowing with creative ideas. on the other hand,he also seems to have a strong level of control over how this is delivered and withheld. during his 60's heyday,dylan was renowned for being writing out of character in his own lyrics-very much the actor/trickster hero. and how many times did that role he played made him out to be an iconoclast of something which...disappointed people when he moved onto his next musical role? well unfortunately for his personal life,his marriage to the mother of his children at this point was coming to a conclusion. it would've been very easy for dylan to act this drama out as one of the many faces he wheres. not even sure if he realized that this time,he'd actually be playing himself.    for the most part this album is musically as uncomplicated and primitive as dylan himself would likely hope it to be-built more or less around dylan's folksy style of guitar,trademark atonal blues harp and steel guitar from buddy cage. musically it is the vivid lyricism of "tangled up in blue",with it's thickly layered instrumental harmonics,the sleek and shiny contemporary singer-songwriter sound of "you're a big girl now" and the straight up 12 bar electric blues of "you're gonna make me lonesome when i go" that represent the broadest stylistic changes. songs such as "idiot wind","lily,rosemary and the jack of hearts",and the iconic closer "buckets of rain" do not differ much from dylan's late 60's musical style. otherwise these songs lyrically focus in on what appear to be more story songs and character sketches. took me a bit of time to realize these were all elaborate metaphors describing the long and strange life cycle of his marriage and the perfect storm of mixed emotions that flowed from its beginning to its end.    when i was first getting into dylan's music,most people recommended this album as the one to go for when it came to his 70's era music. one reason i could see for that is that it was probably the most personal album he ever made. even with his noted wordplay and sense of poetry still operating at full power? all of these songs had a strong ring of truth to himself about them. as far as the compositions themselves,dylan's performance and writing had continued to evolved. often someone who i hear as singing very much against and outside the rhythm and melody of his own songs,dylan actually goes with the flow here. and the nature of his vocals are far less flamboyant here than they could be during his 60's prime. not only that,but all of the songs here are very richly and melodically crafted. dylan always tended to venture outside the traditional verse/verse nature of folk composition by introducing a lot of pop structure. but here dylan takes it to the next level-scaling up and down a note or so on a verse/chorus to express the intended emotion. have a feeling these are the qualities that make this album so appealing to so many.

i've never been a huge foo fighters fan - i've always liked their music, but didn't buy a foo fighters cd until just last year.  the first cd i bought was their greatest hits album, which was a good buy.  i read that this cd is heralded as one of their best (if not the best) album that they have released.  over 15 years after its original release, this album does not disappoint!!  aside from the tracks like everlong and bakerstreet, which were radio hits back in the day, this album is filled with track after track of good music that puts most of today's rock music to shame.  the extra tracks are great, and in my opinion its well worth it to get the deluxe edition, but you don't have to pay the high price, since best buy is currently selling this cd for about $8.  certainly one of the best (if not the best) $8 cd i've ever bought.  an easy 5 star rating for this album.  if you don't own it / have never heard this full album before, buy it... you  won't be disappointed.

i'll keep this short and sweet, since that's all that's really needed for this album.  i got this record several years ago for free from my brother, who got it from one of his friends. i had only just started getting interested in music, and this was only the second record in my collection, so at the time i thought it was sooooooooo cool and rockin' and whatnot. but after a few years of gaining more musical experience, i went back to this record a few times and became completely unable to get any enjoyment out of it. musically, it's generic as hell, something very typical to church youth group rock bands but not necessarily the case for all christian rock--and you're hearing this from an atheist, but one who spent several years while he was religious only listening to that genre. this is simply a very boring, uninspired sounding record, though it sounds like they at least had fun making it (that's about all the credit i'll give it). also, a lot of the songs are rather dumb lyrically, like "three legged chair" and "rsvp." it would've been great if they could've been more inventive all around.  all in all, i'd say it's best to just not waste your time/money on this record, and instead look into the vast amount of much better music out there...even if it's *gasp* secular. but if you really, really, really want it, it looks like there's some people on here selling it for as cheap as 1 cent, so it's not like you would be losing too much if you bought it anyway--it's just that it would be rather pointless.

albee's piece produced 52 years ago still puts to shame most modern playwrights.  his sense of dysfunctional psyches run amok plays beautifully in this excellent recording.  i have the original 4 vinyl discs in their iconic package (reproduced in the art work for the cd) but it is such a pleasure to  have only one break in act ii to disturb the flow of  verbiage that hagen et al play out so brilliantly.  saw the movie?  well, it was a big deal at the time (language etc.), but it could have been brilliant.  jack warner was approached by bette davis who pleaded to do the film with henry fonda..."what a dump"????  only in hollywood.  wish it has been a reality......but box office success beats artistic integrity.

england is never at a loss to come up with some new music sound, even when it comes to the time honored surf-rock instrumental genre. case in point is schlock singles by the trio known as the terrorsaurs. wild is right word as these guys go primal on an all instrumental cd that mixes punk angst with surf-rock and you get something called punk-surf. anyway the instro mags and web sites are buzzing about the terrorsaurs saying they must be on to a new sound that revamps link wray and the ventures while the results are an exciting blend of nitro instro. speaking to mwe3.com about the terrorsaurs sound, group guitarist carl harris, alias el guapo, confesses, we'd describe it as proto-surf. theres an obvious rock/punk edge which cannot be denied. we have no definite formula but its really based around obscure garage rhythms and tracks of the early to mid 1960's. the way-out looking cover cd definitely puts this one in the goth-surf instro realm. the terrorsaurs are rough and ready and they get their sound in focus on their appealing, self-produced set of "schlock & roll". caution: the terrorsaurs make savage rock & roll and is definitely not for squares.

i thought i'd post a recommendation here to all my flute-playing friends about this recording. there are precious few non-baroque concertos for two flutes (the cimarosa comes to mind), so this robert stallman transcription of the mozart sonata for two pianos, k. 448, into the sinfonia concertante for 2 flutes and orchestra is a wonderful addition to the repertoire. it is pure, joyous mozart, and deserves a place alongside the existing concertos that we have. so listen to the cd, and if you can, play this piece!

several years ago naxos released a fine recording of film music by william perry entitled music for great films of the silent era. it was a delightful excursion into the world of silent films and evidently enjoyed great success, because naxos has now released a second volume that is every bit as engrossing as the first. as silent film buffs know, perry was for many years a composer and performer at the museum of modern art in new york and his scores were featured in two emmy award-winning tv series called the silent years. having this material now in beautifully-recorded orchestral versions is simply wonderful.  a featured work is a suite of eight songs called silent film heroines, saluting eight famous actresses of the silent screen including lillian gish, mary pickford, greta garbo and gloria swanson. a young canadian mezzo-soprano, wallis giunta, performs these with high style and panache, giving each song a colorful and musically-appropriate characterization. i particularly loved her bluesy approach to garbo and a full-out comedy reading of pearl white in the perils of pauline.  perry also scores with an expanded treatment of his eloquent music for d.w. griffiths world war one film, hearts of the world, and he has transformed other of his film music into pieces for flute and orchestra and, surprisingly, ophicleide and orchestra, both beautifully performed and recorded. the riches in this cd are many and varied, and naxos should be congratulated on bringing it to us.

right off-if you're a fan of this trio you need to add this 1989 2 cd set to your music shelf--but it won't sit on the shelf much.  the sound is good/very good--fairly clean and crisp but with a slight bit of flatness.  but saying that i wish all live broadcast recordings were this good.  while the songs are complete the editing between songs is a bit abrupt and choppy.  but that's a minor quibble with such a fine performance.  disc 1 is 63+ minutes, disc 2 is 33+ minutes in length.  the six page booklet has an essay on the music, and that this was  a benefit for children of the americas, which helps rural guatemalan children.  the set list is pretty stellar.  included are songs like "wasted on the way", "the lee shore", "just a song before i go", "wind on the water", "guinevere" (with some harmonica in the opening), "wooden ships" (with some great acoustic and electric guitar work), "our house" (which is a bit of a singalong), "suite: judy blue eyes" (a very fine 9 1/2 minutes version vocally and some incredible guitar from stills, but it sounds like there's an edit (?) towards the end), along with various solo performances like "house of broken dreams", "tracks in the dust", and "midnight rider", and too many other fine songs/performances to mention.  things end with a fine, moving "daylight again/find the cost of freedom".  in a nutshell--the songs are well chosen, well sung (listen to those harmonies!), well played (i don't know which is better--the acoustic or electric guitar playing), and with little things like stills' fine piano work, this is one of the best albums this group never officially released.  get this.

there is no one else like ted drozdowski. he is part bluesman, part psychedelic rocker and he manages to fuse the two into something magical. with the support of the scissormen, he takes listeners on a real musical trip, from the rock of the first two songs to the haunting, poetic "the river" to the almost pure blues of "let's go to memphis." he's a born storyteller, sharing tales of watermelon slim. here renamed watermelon kid, the late r.l:. burnside, and his grandparents who died of black lung disease from working in the pennsylvania coal mines. sometimes he sounds somewhat like dylan or even. on "dreaming on the road, like donovan. but he always sounds unique, and with all his vintage guitars, amps, pedals and a  diddley bow or two, he and the scissormen create something wonderful.

i have been a rolling stones fan for 27 years at the time of this writing and i barely recall wasting my money on this album when it came out. i wanted to like this album and expected much more from jagger. there is one good song on this disc, "god gave me everything" which is a pretty good rocker. every other track is slow and not really entertaining. i got through one listen of the whole album and it sat for over a decade without being listened to again. it's sad. i have to agree with keith richards when he supposedly said of this album "more like s**t in the doorway!".

this live recording is amazing. it was done at a time when the recording industry was shifting from monaural to stereo recordings, and both formats were offered. this recording is an audiophile's dream. it demonstrates the live performance as well as the shift from mono to stereo.  the songs are vintage classics and are preserved in their entirety. i highly  recommend this cd.

im nobodys baby; sam, the old accordion man; shaking the blues away; the song is ended, but the melody lingers on; keep sweeping the cobwebs off the moon (tl); back in your own backyard; when youre with somebody else; ramona; happy days and lonely nights; because my baby dont mean maybe now; beloved; sonny boy; my blackbirds are bluebirds now; youre the cream in my coffee; ill get by as long as i have you; button up your overcoat (db); mean to me (db); more than you know; cryin for the carolines; love me or leave me (doris day) cd two: ten cents a dance; funny, dear, what love can do; dancing with tears in my eyes; dont tell him what happened to me; just a little closer; if i could be with you one hour tonight; body and soul; love is like that, what can you do?; nevertheles im in love with you; shine on, harvest moon; guilty; me!; a faded summer love; cuban love song; it was so beautiful; ill never be the same; linger a little longer in the twilight; close your eyes; smoke gets in your eyes; riptide; easy come, easy go; life is a song, lets sing it together; you (jw); its a sin to tell a lie (jw); theres a lull in my life; goodnight, sweetheart db  dorsey brothers; tl  ted lewis; jw  jay wilbur ruth etting graduated from the chorus line to singing solo in chicago nightclubs, and began recording for columbia in 1926. her gangster husbands persuasive powers gave her the pick of tin pan alleys new songs, and such was her popularity that the frequency of her recordings was maintained throughout the great depression. she had an idiosyncratic style, often embellishing the melody by sliding around the notes. she needed a big voice for the theatre, which she reined in for the studio, where its clarity was ideally suited to the medium of recording. her accompaniments were often quite sparse, with rube bloom on piano almost a constant, which gave the vocal more prominence, and created an air of intimacy with the listener. that successful formula resulted in approximately 200 sides over eleven years, many of which were the first recordings of songs that would become future standards. this very judicious selection includes her sole outing with ted lewis, and two of the six sides she recorded with jay wilbur in 1936. she was the subject of a 1955 biopic, the title song of which, sung by doris day, is included also. the package includes a very thorough discography and an excellent liner note, and is highly recommended. note: for some reason the price here is exorbitant, far dearer than on the uk site.

this review pertains to the hallmark cd release of "christmas hymns and carols". the material itself warrants 5 stars and this is one of my all-time favorite christmas albums. the poor sound quality of the hallmark release and problems getting the cd to play in a couple cd players is why i'm rating it 1 star.  mario lanza's christmas performances from the early 1950s are golden classics. i have several copies of this album on vinyl, cassette and cd, plus the collected songs on other christmas cd releases on rca by mario lanza.  this hallmark company cd has the worst sound quality of all of them. it is labeled "original recording" on the cover, but that doesn't mean remastered, and it is definitely not from the rca master tapes.  when i received this new cd, my cd player rejected the cd as incompatible. i put it in another and the same thing happened. but after repeated insertions, it did play.  this hallmark issue was not issued by rca/bmg, camden, rca red seal or sony, the companies that have the original masters. rca red seal was mario lanza's original record company. nor is this "hallmark" the same company that has the greeting cards, ornaments, or hallmark hall of fame tv specials.  this hallmark is a foreign company, and the cd is marked "made in the netherlands" under the upc bar code. which is odd because the company's website (pickwickgroup.com) identifies itself as a british company, and laughably boasts (this is copied verbatim from their web page):  "the company has often been at the forefront of the british music market. from humble beginnings in the west end of london, pickwick grew into the largest player in the budget field, one of the first companies to launch a dedicated budget label (hallmark), subsequently offering the expertise learnt to such major companies as cbs, rca and walt disney. pickwick was one of the first companies to have in place exclusive licensing deals with the major record companies, one of the first to embrace the then new medium of the compact disc, the first to release product directly aimed at the childrens market and undertaking an extensive classical recording programme that was the envy of the industry."  wow, it's great to know that cbs, rca and walt disney learned a thing or two from pickwick/hallmark's generous offer of their expertise.  despite these ridiculous claims of hallmark about their company being "the envy of the industry", this cd won't play in every cd player and has very poor sound quality compared to the official rca releases. it sounds like it was copied from a consumer-level product, either a cassette tape or an old mono copy of the camden lp with the treble control rolled off to suppress surface noise or tape hiss. there is even a skip in one of the songs, and that wouldn't be there if this cd wasn't made from an old vinyl record. the sound quality is dull. there is a minor amount of bass in the dynamic range, but little clarity with the treble.  i compared the sound on this hallmark cd to some of the earlier, official rca/bmg cd reissues. the 10-track "a tenor's christmas" has excellent sound, which is bright, clear, has some minor bass and (good) expanded range/artificial stereo imaging. the cd, "christmas with mario lanza" with the red cover, released by rca back in the late 1980's, is also excellent. those two releases have the best sound quality. a couple prior official cd issues of "christmas hymns & carols" on camden/rca are in mono and have lower volume, but still better sound quality than this hallmark release.  all of the official rca/camden/red seal/gold seal cd releases are still available here on amazon either new or used, and are good purchases, but this hallmark cd should be avoided.  update: the same can be said of hallmark's issue of "perry como sings merry christmas music" which also has the worst sound quality ever issued for that album. again, stick with the official rca/camden company cd releases

the album itself is excellent. not as great as primo victoria, and without truly standout songs like some of their other albums, but solid throughout. sabaton does not disappoint. however, if you're thinking of getting the "last stand (ltd/cd/dvd/booklet) (one pressing only)  import" version, thinking it's the limited earbook version that is sold on nuclear blast's website, don't. it's an asian import, not a european import, and is the exact same as the regular version, but with a paper insert and a $30 higher pricetag. amazon doesn't actually sell the limited version. if you wanted it, you had to go to the source for it, and nuclear blast has sold out.  update: amazon now has the spiffy limited version available. however, it is more expensive here by a fair amount than if you were to buy it directly from the nuclear blast usa website, which has it back in stock as of this writing. it's listed here as "audio cd | double vinyl, box set, import". it contains the earbook edition of the cd, which means a big record-album-sized book with a two-page spread for each song (art, battle history, lyrics), with the two cds (studio album, live performance) and dvd (same live performance) in slots on the inside covers. it also contains a double vinyl picture disc, a poster, an insert suitable for getting signed at a concert meet-and-greet, and two guitar picks with the sabaton logo on them. if you're into sabaton enough to want all that, it's a great set.
